To me they seemed over cooked because the inside wasn't juicy and the outer shell was overly crunchy/hard. We also got the kimchi fried rice, cheese corn, and jap chae. The portions for the latter two we're a bit small, as for taste they were all typical.

For drinks we ordered the apple, mango, yogurt, and peach soju. They all tasted like juice so if that's your thing go for it! Be careful when you pour it though because the fill it with crush ice and you can easily spill. Overall though I wouldn't get a ton of food here but this place is good for soju juices.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Bbq short rib - 3/5
Bbq short rib spicy - 3/5
Fried chicken - 4/5
Fried chicken tangy - 4/5
Seafood pancake - 3/5

Overall, "I'm a fan." Definitely better than 707.
author: Mark O.

description: You put the bang to my korean craving. I had some delicious kimchi fried rice, kal bi, and I guess soju too. However the fried chicken was not as good as I hoped. The original and tangy sauce was meh. But I'm super picky with fried chicken. Would like to revisit but they don't open for lunch... :(
author: Ann L.

description: I used to came to this place at least once a week, the waitress is super nice, I love their fried chicken, Army soup & Rice cake. Four days ago I finally order it online. As expected so good!!! Good job! I will definitely fine time and come again.
author: Merry H.

description: Don't mistaken this Cocobang restaurant with Cocobang night club in Cancun. There's usually a wait at Cocobang whenever I go. Which tells me the food is really good and it is. My friend and I came here on a Saturday night where it was down pouring and there was still a wait to be seated. We got seated at 8:13pm and ordered a half order of fried chicken with sweet sauce, kimchi fried rice and fire spicy chicken with cheese. This was my first time ordering a Korean dish with cheese in it. Surprisingly the cheese goes well with the dish. I love cheese and it was gooey, my fav! Our food came out at 8:22pm which to me is pretty fast service. I would opt for a full order of fried chicken, it's so darn good. A half order is 5 large balls of  boneless chicken meat.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Food's great, service is great, and if only the wait didn't take forever, I'd be coming here all the time.

------------------------------------

I could eat 2 of those Kimchi Fried Rice dishes all on my own, their Sweet and Spicy Chicken are to die for, and the boys working there are really good at their job.
author: Eileen ..

description: Good hangout place for the budget.  Their chicken is pretty good.  They get little crowded during weekend.
author: Andy L.

description:
Late night eats that did not have a negative impact on my overall mood and weight the following morning. Walked around late one night and we decided to go w/ this place rather than Philly cheesesteaks. Rob ordered the beef and I ordered the spicy chicken. Each came w/ white rice, kimchi, and other small tapas-style stuff (I don't know much about Korean food). 

Two words that describes the place rightfully: 

- small 
- always packed 

It was either hot in the restaurant or was it because we had a sodium overload w/ our donut burgers earlier but I must have taken in at least 6 glasses of water during our wait. Rob kept refilling my glass before we realized I drank hella. The wait was nice because we got a chance to talk about our life... he got to know me and I got to know him, too. He became my initial motivation towards a healthier life. He's my best pal. When I stand next to him, I feel out of shape because he's so cut but since I met him, I went down 9lbs-11lbs and I cannot be happier w/ myself. We have not hung-out since that night but we kept each other in check through random texts from time to time. It's nice meeting people from all walks of life that has the same mindset as you. Thanks for linking us, IG! 

Anyway. 

I had 1/4 of my sizzling spicy chicken platter and he had more than 1/2 of his. It was very good. Mine had a kick to it. I loved that the chicken was juicy. I did not eat the rice but Rob benefited from it. Service was super friendly. Even the patrons were friendly and fun. We boxed the rest and on our way back, we got hustled out of the to-go box. Oh well... hope the couple that hustled us enjoyed the food as much as we did. 

Thanks for treating, Rob.
author: Tram N.

description:
Not very good.
My bibimbap was cold, devoid of flavor, and the cook who prepared my dish tortured the fried egg on top as it was terribly overcooked. Granted, we descended upon Cocobang very late, but that's still no excuse for them to put out a product that isn't up to standard. The waitstaff seemed only concerned about getting us out of there as soon as possible so they could close. My dining companions weren't overly thrilled with their selections, either. 

I did enjoy the little complimentary side salad with thousand island dressing, but that was hardly what I was there for.  Overall, an extremely disappointing experience.
author: Gary R.

description:
After watching the Warriors game at a nearby bar, we were hungry! Stopped by Wednesday, May 27th around 10pm. The wait wasn't too bad. I think we waited around 15-20 minutes before we got seated.

*Army soup: kimchi hotpot with sausages and ham ($13.95 small)
This comes with ramen in it as well. Not really my favorite Korean dish as it normally has a bunch of other ingredients that makes the soup thick, but Coco bang's rendition was lighter which was nice.

*Spicy tofu soup: seafood, spicy ($10.95)
Not spicy enough for me and could have used a little more seafood, but had good flavor. Very comforting.

*Beef short rib bbq ($15.95)
I was surprised by how inexpensive this was as I normally pay $20+ for kalbi. Tasty, but I've had better kalbi elsewhere. Still a solid dish.

*Braised pork feet ($14.95)
I love jok bal.This was probably my favorite dish of the night!

We also got a 1.6 liter of OB ($12.95). Can't have a meal without a drink right?

The one thing I wish I also ordered were the chicken wings! I love wings, so I'm surprised it didn't occur to me to get them. I guess a little too much drinking will do that to you. Next time!
author: Elena N.

description:
The place is really small and unless you get a booth, it can be pretty tight in there but the chicken is good! They offer some really good korean fried chicken and other dishes that pair well with beer and soju. The only thing that I did not like on the menu was the jokbal (pig feet). I've had some really good jokbal and the one they serve here was mediocre at best. But the other dishes are well prepared and the service is always good too. 

If you're planning on going in at night on a weekend expect to wait.
author: Jamie K.

description: Really good korean food for late night meals. Arrived in the area around 10pm and was starving! I ordered a bulgogi and shared a seafood pancake with my friend. The pancake was crispier than what I've had in the past and the bulgogi was tasty! Would def come back!
author: Kasey C.

description:
Great Korean food at a reasonable price! Good for late night food cravings. 

Ordered the seafood tofu stew, seafood pancake, and the jap chae and loved everything. Everything tasted like pretty typical Korean food but especially liked the seafood pancake. Good portions and the right amount of crispness. Only complaint is that the small dishes has very little variety. They only gave us 3 little dishes for 3 people and we had to kept asking for refills. The service was a little slow but that's because they only had 1 waiter and 1 guy at the cashier. 

Overall good food and open till late! Heard the yogurt soju hear is great as well but didn't get to try it this time.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. To be perfectly blunt, if it wasn't for the Korean eye candy of a waiter with braces who helped us, I probably wouldn't even give it 3 stars. Upon entering nobody greeted us. I get that it was busy considering it is Memorial day weekend but even an "I'll be right with you" would've been nice. I walked towards the back (where the register is) and asked an older gentleman how long a wait for 3 would be. He said about 10 minutes, however didn't ask for my name or anything. My family and I waited to be seated near the front door. That's when the tall, cute, friendly waiter/server asked if we'd been helped. I told him we were waiting for a table upon which he said it would be about 5-10 more minutes and handed us menus while we waited. He told us we could even let him know if we were ready to order while we waited.

The food was alright. I've had better bibimbap elsewhere. Again, I realize it was busy so instead of waiting forever to get the check handled, I walked up to the register to pay (thank goodness that cute Korean server was working the register). He apologized that is was so busy. I told him it was understandable and that it happens. It was nice to see that he was still friendly and apologetic since the other 2 servers seemed a bit more overwhelmed/annoyed. 

Would I come back for the food? Probably not. Would I come back to watch kpop videos playing on the wall/to see/talk to that attractive and nice waiter? Yes. Yes I most definitely would.
author: Jessica N.

description: Hole in the wall but I love it! One of my favorite places to visit while I'm in the city of SF. They have cheese corn, KBBQ, and other delicious entrees like fried pork.
author: mcrandall m.

description: Go for the wings mix! The outside is pretty crispy and there was a TON of meat. Wish they hadn't been boneless but pretty solid non the less. Definitely get the original and the avoid the "spicy" which is really just tangy and overly sweet. Also grab some beer cause it goes great with the chicken!
author: Amir M.

description: Food was fairly authentic, just wish that they'd give you more appetizers (banchan). Service was ok, did not even check in with us though restaurant was not busy at the time.
author: Maria C.

description:
2nd visit to Cocobang and its awesome.

It's a tiny shop with very limited seating. We had to wait approximately 20mins before we were seated and its just two to us. It was dinner time around 630pm. We noticed two tables of guests where there when we were waiting to be seated and even after we paid the bill, there were still there. It's lovely to hang with friends over good food and drinks, but I can't imagine how the business survive with the limited turnover of their tables.

Anyway, we ordered glass noodles, fried chicken, spicy pork tofu soup and a strawberry soju.

By the time we were seated we were really hungry, thankfully food came swiftly. They served Korean  appeitizers, not the best and from what I last recalled, the portion is much smaller now. The glass noodle was fantastic and so was the spicy pork tofu. The fried chicken which supposedly was one of their key highlight wasn't that great. The last visit, I tried another version of the flavored chicken and they were good. 

Love the strawberry soju. Taste almost like drinking a strawberry soda but highly potent one. With Est to have 20% alcohol content, you find your heart racing and all warmed up if you down them too quickly. 

Overall, we enjoyed our meal apart from the disappointing fried chickens. Will come back next time I'm around the city and craving for Korean food.
author: Cindee T.

description:
First time I went I was drunk and it was 2am so everything was amazing. 
Went another time sober and it was surprisingly still really good. 

Pretty authentic Korean food and price isn't bad either for SF Soma. 

Drink some soju and eat some bulgogi.
author: tsubasa m.

description:
Hot and Tangy Chicken came out cold. (1/5)

Soon Tofu came out extremely hot (5/5)

Bachan was only refilled once (2/5)

Flavor of the food was alright. The soon tofu was the best. The chicken came with sloppy amounts of corn syrup. I felt like the employees were lazy.

707 Sutter is 6 stores away. Go there.

Will not come back
author: Jeff H.

description:
Drinking on an empty stomach is no Bueno.  Drinking on an empty stomach when you can't handle your alcohol is even worst.  We were in the neighborhood and I wanted something meaty, something filling.  Cocobang has been on my list for a while so now was the right opportunity.

Kalbi - F yeah, that hits the spot. My friend proceeds eating kalbi with a fork, how!?!? Why!?!?  While I look like some barbaric animal using my hands cleaning off each bone.  Whatever.

Tteokbokki (Spicy rice cake with ramen) - My absolute favorite dish.  I love the texture of the rice cakes.  This dish can get messy as I splattered spicy sauce all over my clothes and phone but just as long as some of that gets in my mouth, I'm good.

Great service.
author: Linda N.

description: This sliver of a place is the spot to be when you need Korean comfort food.  It was very lively at 10 on a Thursday night which said others were enjoying their meals too!  We ordered The homemade thick noodle soup which had clams and a delicate broth.  The marinated grilled sliced beef was rich tasting with just the right amount of onions.  Add soju, kimchi and rice and you have a great meal at a great price.
author: Jeffery H.

description: I'm obsessed with this place and everything about it. From the K Pop music videos in the background to the kimchi appetizers, you will be entertained and happy. *You should only come here if you are a group of 4 or less because its a very small restaurant.* Cheese corn is awesome, fried chicken is bomb.com, and spicy wings are a favorite. We've been six times now and still love it every time.
author: Kristan S.

description:
This place can get a little crowded in the weekends. The vibe is really nice. They have Kpop playing on the wall, and the place is a little dark.

The food is great. I always get the fried chicken (all the kinds). This is a good place to come with your friends to hang out, especially late at night.
author: Do P.

description:
Best Korean fried chicken joint, and other things too!

I love the ambience of this place. It's very casual, dim, and there's always Korean music videos playing in the background. Perfect place for group drinking and late night snacking. I've been here with many friends and all of them have fallen in love with Cocobang. The servers are also very attentive and nice, remembering some of our names and occasionally stopping by to chat with us about what we've been up to. Opens until very late.

Half Garlic/Half Spicy Sweet Fried Chicken - This combo is the best. The Garlic is sweet and very savory. Spicy is also more on the sweet side but it tastes great when paired with soju and the cabbage salad. 

Chicken Gizzard - Flavorful with sesame oil and pepper; very crunchy; does not have the gamey and bitter aftertaste

Seafood Ramen - Korean style ramen with actual seafood inside like shrimp and mussel. It's filling and great for a hangover.

Omelette - Super filling but so so so good! It comes on a block of wooden plate and is drizzled with 2-3 types of creamy and spicy sauce.

Kimchi Fried Rice - Not very spicy; slightly sweet; bits of sausage, kimchi, and peas
author: Tiffany C.

description: Amazing foods! Order the cheese and corn!  Everything I order I was more than happy with
author: Nina A.

description: The food is medicare but the waiter is so bad! We are not going to come here again!! Come on, there are dozen of Korean restaurant in SF. Here will be the last choice ever. If you guys looking for korean restaurant close to Post st. There is One korean cuisine just next block away. The taste is not different but the service will be mug more better.
author: Tanawat S.

description: We were waiting for the long line since we saw the sign "please wait to be seated". It had been about 30 mins until the waiter came up. THE WAITER asked for the name but we didn't have the name on their list since the waiter didn't show up until there was the table available. He put us to last queue because we didn't tell him when we arrived. I told him to ask the group before us because they witnessed that we came before all of the others that were waiting behind our group. He didn't listen and said "It doesn't matter. You wanna put your name to last queue or not?". We wasted our time for no reason. Their system handling on the busy hours is profoundly unprofessional. The list of the customers waiting should be placed in front of their restaurant or at least hiring some hosting staff. We deeply hope that they will improve !!!!
author: Atimuttaka S.

description:
Okay Korean joint. Came around 1am on Saturday night. Had a short wait before we were seated. 

Fried chicken: we got the original and the hot and tangy (half half). They first few bites were good and then we got sick of it. 

BBQ beef short ribs: yummy. Chewier than I expected, but the flavors were there.

Spicy tofu soup: ordered it with vegetables, medium spicyness. Probably my favorite item of the night. I wish it was less tofu and more broth though. Good spicy level. 

Did not stand up to the kbbq joints back in Los Angeles.
author: Amanda P.

description:
Wow, this has a pretty average rating for what I thought was an amazing restaurant...
 
I came with a large group of people, which was great since it gave us a chance to order a ton of items...the standouts were the following:
 
Fried Chicken/Fried Chicken with Hot and Tangy Sauce
Cheese Corn
Kimchi Pancake
Kimchi Fried Rice
Dozen Egg Omelete
 
All these items were great, well-seasoned and bursting with flavor.  They have a huge menu, but these particular items were incredible.
 
I'm definitely coming back here!
author: Ken G.

description: The fried chicken is not bad, but the budejjigae is amazeballs! It's like kimchi stew but more with sausage and ramen noodles. Also tried the dduk mandoo guk and was pleasantly surprised! I like this place cause they open later than most other places. Oh and can't forget the corn cheese!
author: Jeana Y.

description: The chicken I had was closer to food court teriyaki chicken than anything I've ever had at a Korean bbq. They're also super stingy with the sides. Meh.
author: Brenton M.

description: My favorite drunchies place that's open till pretty late especially for SF. The bibimbap is the best here, so flavorful and incomparable to other places I've been to. Tried the dumpling soup and felt like the flavors were pretty bland. Would come back for bibimbap after a night out for sure.
author: Chelsea W.

description: Good Korean food.  Very fast, attentive staff.  No dolsot for the bibimbap.  Be prepared to wait out on the street.
author: Sean K.

description:
cheap comfort korean food, the restaurant itself is a bit small, but they open till very late.

was a bit turned off by the smell of the restauarnt at first, as it is a bit like a stinky back alley smell, but the food is very good, definitely compensated for it. the sizzling plates beef short ribs is so tender and mouth watering. the house special noodle is very fresh too with lots of clams in it. last but not least, the fried chicken is awesome! korean style!
author: Emily H.

description: the food was ok but their service was great. i was craving korean food and it did not satisfy me. the corn cheese was ok. the service was good. would not come back again.
author: Saw W.

description:
Love this place!! Cute n cozy with a super k pop vibe. Perfect for when you're hungry and down to drink. The food is so gooood. The service is great and very attentive. The menu is big too so you have a lot to choose from. Usually I don't like places that are so small but the small size of the restaurant adds to its charm. 

Solid 5 stars from me and I definitely will be returning!
author: Fredelice D.

description:
Talk about a crowded location! 

HAHA funny story, when we were waiting there was a party before us that was AT LEAST 10-12 people, and from the looks of it it was gonna be a while til they get their table. My friend who's relatively short was tempted to just go out side and tell them " Hey it's not worth the wait, should just go." HAHA but of course we didn't do that... or she didn't haha.

Any who:

This is a pretty cool spot to go to if you're out and about in the late night of SF. I've been here a few times, and only 2/8 times my party and I had to wait a while. The wait isn't ridiculous but don't expect to sit down immediately. 

My party and I usually order a few dishes so we can share among ourselves. 

Usually we'll get a bulgogi plate, with fried chicken (boneless and spicy) Kim chi fried rice, and seafood pancake. 

Never fails to make my tummy feel great! I just wished they had more side dishes. Don't get me wrong the side dishes they have are great already! But I LOVE side dishes, especially in variety.

The service is very friendly, and very on it. Not to mention they were dressed pretty fresh. Yea, I see you in them dope kicks, and smedium Tee. I see you bro.

If you're a female and you come here after getting ratchet at the club, hitting on men about how hot responsibilities are: Don't expect immediate seating.
Dress warm as well cause the "waiting area" is practically outside.

 This place is "OK" for dates.
author: Huy H.

description: A good place for a late night eat, very good ribs, chicken of course the soju and the beer. Very friendly and lovely crew especially the girl server
author: Ilca C.

description: Hole in the wall with okay korean food. I guess I'm spoiled living so close to K-town in Los Angeles, but the food could've been better for it's aesthetics.
author: Nancy N.

description: If you ever go here you should try the fire chicken with cheese ! That's prob the best menu item. If you want something else to go with it you should try the fried rice
author: Arash M.

description:
Fast respond great prices for value open super late great service 
lol don't even think to order the super spicy chicken it will killlll you lol even for a spicy lover I couldn't take it .
author: Aviad B.

description:
Ate this after a long delayed flight from Houston. They're open until the wee hours of the morning so this was the perfect place to grab a late night bite. 

Tofu spicy soup was amazing! Especially in SF's chilly July weather. Highlight of the meal! 

Korean fried chicken was ok. We got the half green onion and half sweet and tangy. Green onion is much better than sweet and tangy. 

Overall awesome for late night dining but I don't know if I'd rate it that high otherwise.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
I'd rate this as a four (3.5 for myself) for an overall experience between my entire party and I. Two of my cousins are Filipino so they do enjoy things on the sweeter side while I don't really like sweet dinner dishes. My tastebuds are starting to change so I do find things to be sweeter than I use to say a year ago. But even if it didn't change: it would be still on the sweet side. I like more savory Korean dishes as a preference. It might have been just the stuff we ordered as well which quite frankly was a lot of food.

This place is good... I would say the rest of my party would say it was a 4-5. Two of my cousins liked it more than my other cousin (and they've been there a week ago for the first time and liked it so much they wanted to go again after the first time). 

I really liked their strawberry soju (it was like a slushee) which my cousins found it overly sweet, they prefer soju that is stronger in alcohol both in taste and content. So my older cousin usually reorders another soju, but he didn't: too weak.

The fried chicken with hot & tangy sauce was sweet. The pork cutlet with special sauce was sweet, sweeter than the fried chicken. I would get the fried chicken again to share. I really liked the salad that was paired for both of those dishes I just mentioned before: half of the plate was of salad: really good portions. The beef short rib was really good. The girl told us the kimchi fried rice was like one person portion.. we ordered way too much food though. For four people: I would say get 1 only if you must order it and grab 2 if you don't order a lot. But it be safe to just order one and see how it is before and then order another one if wanted. We all agreed that their kimchi fried rice wasn't the best. We pefer 'The Garage''s kimchi fried rice more however.

Now onto the army soup which was a favorite amongst all of us, but I think I would prefer a simple kimchi hotpot or a regular tofu soup over that just because the spam/ham makes the soup a might sweeter. It was really good. And it was something I would have ended up ordering to try if my cousins didn't want it. 

I think for me: I would avoid anything tany or anything with the special sauce here and stick to spicy stuff in hopes that it's more savory..

We ordered the bigger sized portions for where there were two size options.. it was way to much food but great as leftovers. If you choose to order a lot: maybe just do half-portions to try out different things.
author: Lilian L.

description:
Oh Man! Came here last night after some drinking and everything was so good.. probably because of the alcohol I had already consumed plus more at Cocobang. Their peach soju was tasty. A bit on the sweet side but still pretty good. Food wise, we probably ordered almost the entire menu since we had 5 of us, but we did manage to finish it ALL! 

We ordered - cheese corn, jap chae, clear clam soup, spicy tofu soup, bulgogi, spicy pork, kimchee fried rice, fried chicken with the hot and tangy sauce, and the seafood pancake. The things that stood out to me and I would definitely order again was the cheese corn (simple yet so delicious), the clear clam soup (so tasty and the fresh clams really did it for us) and the fried chicken (next time I think we want to try it without any sauce).
author: Tiff C.

description: An Orgy OG Flava! Got some finger licking chicken, so good you want to slap yo' mama.  BBQ combo of beef and pork was on point.
author: Nelden D.

description:
Posted out of a bar/club at 2am and have a dying craving for korean food? Cocobang is your best bet. We ordered spicy cold noodles and a 1/2 spicy bulgogi + 1/2 short rib. We were seated in 15 minutes and quickly given water and side dishes. The waiter was patient in dealing with the rowdier folks of the group and made quick suggestions so that he could get the order to the kitchen. 

All in all, the service is incredible but food is truly mediocre. But what more can you expect for a late-night drunk fix of bulgogi.
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
The food here is good and it's open late! Not the best Korean food I've had in the city, but the best in the downtown area. 

Get the fried chicken and kimchi fried rice!

This place is super small, so the wait could be a while, especially if you have a group of 4+. But the time might go by faster if you're watching the Korean music videos they play on the tv.
author: Annie C.

description:
Came here after seeing Kygo at the Bill Graham Civic Center. Pretty popping late night spot.

Ordered corn cheese, spicy kimchi pancake, and kalbi. Corn cheese was legit, super cheesy. The pancake was average, could have let that go but when you the munchies you don't care. The kalbi was on point tho. I killed the whole plate by myself....regrets were had the next day but it was super flavor. Small spot in union square but it was't too packed when we got there around 1am. 

I'm not familiar if there's other korean food in downtown SF but this spot was decent. It has all your typical korean dishes. It's not very big so I imagine there's a line if you come later.
author: Jessie H.

description:
came here last night / this morning around 2 am, and there was a wait outside. WUT. but a table for 2 was immediately available, so we sat down and began perusing the menu. new menu - yay - cuz the old ones were so greasy, but its been about a year since ive been here soooo.. meeps!

we got - mango soju (which we had to literally finish in 15 minutes and i did most of the work because my friend was already wasted..), seafood ramen, and a sizzling plate of spicy chicken and rice cakes.  the banchan was pretty good, esp the tofu. but there was no kimchi? ehh?

ummmm. the soju was slushy and wayyy too sweet, but okay because it wasnt strong at all and i wasnt looking for anything strong.  the chicken was also okay, but didnt have any FLAVOR, it was just straight up spicy. now, moving to the seafood ramen -which sold for about 12-14 bucks? umm, there was ONE muscle, ONE sick-looking shrimp (head and tail both on), and NO OTHER SEAFOOD. my friend was like WTFFfffff?!?!?! and the noodles were obviously shin ramen, because i had cooked some earlier that day for lunch. LOL.. wut. 

there arent many places open beyond 2 am and with a full kitchen, so i do give cocobang some credit for their business model, but honestly. iono why anyone would come here for an actual MEAL.  but their fried chicken, on the one previous occassion i was here, is pretty good.  my friend said he aint banging coco anymore. non-deliciousness for 2 cost us 50 bucks.  

i will say though, super fast and friendly service! haha
author: Christina L.

description: This was top notch fried chicken. I ate a mountain of it. Crunchy on the outside, juicy in the middle. Ate a few other nice plates too! Definitely adding to one of my regular spots.
author: Dan G.

description: Food taste great. For two people service are 5 stars. They are able to handle so many customers. I am impressed. These guys are awesome. I recommend this to visitors in downtown sanfrancisco to try this korean food spot. I am glad i went here.
author: Eric S.

description: This is the worst customer service!!!!! We ordered food and it's takes forever and since we want our food to go coz there's no table available they want us to wait outside .. like wtf it's so cold outside they don't care about their customers
author: Carmina A.

description:
There aren't many late-night options in SF, and this is basically our go-to if we're downtown. Yes you have to wait for like 30 minutes but a lot of the time, people before you get impatient and leave so your patience, which is indeed a virtue, can help you get your tummy filled.

We've probably ordered everything on the menu and I wouldn't say their food is that great, but it'll do. The staff is nice enough, though clearly overwhelmed by the 2am rush (and that is literally the only time I've ever been here).
author: Vivian H.

description: Overcharged me. Its only 2$ but the fact they they put 15% tip on their own is unacceptable.
author: Aidana A.

description: This is my favorite Korean bbq spot in San Francisco. It gets very busy on the weekends (open late) but the staff is always super nice and you get a discount if you pay in cash. One of the things I miss most about SF is this place. Go you will not regret it! Also if you're a fan of Kpop go during the week as they play more Korean music and Korean music videos then and more America pop during the busy weekend nights.
author: Dave H.

description: The food came out quick. We got the half and half fried chicken (plain and saucy one). The plain fried chicken was lacking in flavor and the saucy one is cover with cheap Dollar Store sweet sauce. The bulgogi was not exceptional, it tasted weird, so we couldn't finish it. The chicken katsu was dried with some funky brown sauce. Overall, if you drunk and like "expensive" cheap meal come here.
author: Mike L.

description: Went here two late nights in a row.  Small spot, but great place for food after 2AM. We stayed at Sir Francis Drake Hotel and wanted a late night meal. This was only 5 minutes away from the hotel.  The menu is limited but the food is good for a late night spot.  If you like people watching. Great place to see this after 2. Ha!
author: Marylyn N.

description:
SF only has one late night Korean food option??

How is that possible?? I guess NYC has spoiled me. We arrived at Cocobang shortly after 2AM one Saturday night, and was greeted with a 30 minute wait: the price of luxurious, late-night noms. After much confusion, the servers finally seated us 45 minutes later. We quickly agreed on a budae jjigae, haemul pajeon, and fried chicken. If you were to ask sober Ben, I might've given it a so-so review, but Saturday night Ben was into the whole thing. I absolutely loved that the wings were boneless, which made them so much easier to chomp on. The jjigae was served in a soondubu bowl, which I thought was a little weird, but whatever, it was hot and hit the spot.

The final bill was totally reasonable, and we left stuffed and more than happy. However, I wouldn't trade the late-night food options in NYC for anything. The selection is just too perfect to pass up.
author: Ben W.

description: I ordered delivery, and the food that arrived was not what i ordered. The restaurant refused to help and did not take responsibility. There are so much better Korean restaurants around. Stay away from here!
author: Debbie I.

description:
Since I left you 4 days ago I can't stop talking about you to my friends and family, I can't wait for them to meet you and we can be together once again.   Oh Cocobang you are the one I've been searching for.  

The fried chicken is so bomb and can't even stand it, it even taste better the next day after sitting on the nightstand.  nom nom nom   Ask for salt and pepper on the side to sprinkle on it...to die for. 

Protip:  
*Don't mess with the guy taking your order, he will probably tell you.  NO CHICKEN FOR YOU!!  and you don't want that
*Great place for after drinking eats, open till 4am  Holler!
author: Yvonne C.

description: It was a fun place our 2nd visit and made sure we came back. Very good food. Very small place always a wait but worth it.
author: Vicki D.

description:
We ordered delivery from this place through Eat24 and ordered the following:

Tofu soup - half filled soup 
Kalbi - 6 pieces with onions 
Fried chicken - the best looking thing 
Seafood pancake - super greasy and no dipping sauce 
Kimchi fried rice - half ordered

Running theme - they only give you half but makes you paid full price. Lukewarm food and no banchans. Highly recommended not ordering from this place. Quality and a service severely dropped. Check out Zzan. So much better quality and value.
author: Vince L.

description:
Came here with my friend for a dinner and we came right at opening. The service was fast and the food was so tasty. The first few times I went I didn't enjoy the food that much. But this time it was very delicious! We ordered 3 dishes, duboki (rice cake) with ramen, seafood pancake and garlic onion chicken. We had the sides with fish cake and it was delicious! Loved the soft and chewiness. The service was great they kept checking in as well, as we started eating the crowds came and lines were forming to be seated. We first got the garlic chicken, looking at it, it looked dry and not saucy. But as you take the first bite in, WOAH, it was juicy. After this experience I came back two days later. And ordered the dubbokki again, the fried garlic with garlic sauce, soju. I am now obsessed with this place. The taste, freshness, omg it's amazing. I try to come here for lunch sometimes but they're usually open at 5:30 pm :( 

Definitely come here late night or even for a dinner!!
author: Amy Y.

description:
We came here at 2 in the morning after we got kicked out from a bar. Again, it was 2 in the morning but the line was ridiculously long! Lots of drunk people 

Food was mediocre.. we had Korean fried wings, kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, soon tofu, and japchae. Epic failure, I didn't like any of the dishes! I still ate it because I had too much to drink. I am sure it was the same for the rest of the costumers there...

Just don't go there when you are sober, food was terrible

I gave a two-star solely because they open late, I mean really late
author: Teresa N.

description:
Ok... I guess I frequent Cocobang too much not to update my review and give them the full stars. They deserve it for the fried chicken, and now more. 

Yes the fried chicken is still so yummy. Personally, I still prefer mine without the sauce but if you do, there is a garlicky alternative to the standard red hot sauce. A new discovery though - the green onion salad. Totally works as it's a bright salad that goes well with the crispy fried chicken and definitely more flavorful than the standard shredded cabbage slaw. 

But in my numerous return visits, I've samples SO much more and Cocobang does a good job at more than just the fried chicken. Let's explore some of my new favorites here: 

Corn cheese - It's exactly like it sounds. Sweet corn and melted cheese in a hot skillet. So addictively and gluttonously satisfying.  

Braised pork feet - Would not typically order the dish but saw a lady next to us enjoying a whole plate of it so I knew I had to get an order of these tender trotters. The meat is flavorful and pairs well with the kimchee.

Boiled pork with spicy daikon - if based on description alone, this dish does not seem appetitizing but it's deceptively good. The pork just works with the spicy pickled daikon, raw garlic, and kimchee. 

Pan fried clear noodles - I guess this is jap chae and I'm pre-disposed to like it. Cocobang does a decent one. 

Steamed Korean sausage - This took a while to get used to texturally. It's not as odd as coagulated blood but there is definitely some element of it. Not for everyone but worth trying if you're curious. 

Of course all the other usual favorites like bibimbap and spicy tofu stews are on the menu. I always come back for some Korean fried chicken and Hite beer but have now expanded to new, sometimes odd, parts of the menu. Through the many return visits I've come to know the folks here more and they really are lovely albeit frantic on busy nights. 

One of my favorite places for fried chicken and beer hands down. K-pop videos lucky strike bonus.
author: Jon L.

description: I paid for my order, then they made me wait outside in the rain while I was waiting for my food. They prioritized Korean people over me. I was drenched from the rain. The staff did not allow me to enter the restaurant until my food was ready.
author: Vikram M.

description:
Literally the best. Need I say more? 

Late night Korean food to fulfill all your drunk cravings or even just all you're just being hungry cravings. 

Bomb short rib BBQ. Bomb chicken wings. BOMB CORN CHEESE. LITERALLY TRY IT. ITS LIFE CHANGING. 

Small and cute. Wait is worth it. Chill outside with your homies and get ready for a meal that's worthwhile non
author: Alaia L.

description: My god chicken done right! Flavorful, piping hot, tickles the senses. Keeps patrons coming back for more. Great value, literally a small mountain of chicken for not much $$$. Low cost and good tastes makes a great combination! Four stars bra.
author: Keit K.

description:
We were staying in a hotel nearby and were looking for some Korean grub within  walking distance.

Cocobang is a little restaurant in the Union Square area. There was a short wait for a table, but they have us menus while we waited and we were seated after about 10 minutes. 

We decided on a few items to share family style: kalbi, stir fried glass noodles, spicy chicken and fried chicken in spicy and sweet sauce. We also got a couple of carafes of soju and beer for the table. My favorite was the lemon soju, with the yogurt version not far behind. The food was ok. Decent flavors, albeit a little on the overly sweet side. I wouldn't order the spicy chicken or kalbi, since they were my least favorites for the night. The fried chicken and glass noodles were pretty good, despite being on the overly sweet side.

Refills were plentiful and service was friendly and relatively attentive. That's all I ask for, for the most part.

I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Emily R.

description:
You're not going to like this if you're from SoCal or NYC, but otherwise its average-quality Korean food that comes at a decent price for San Francisco.

The fried chicken was decent, and the soondubu was just plain bad. The bibim-naengmyun was actually very good, but they definitely forgot my order, and lied to me about it when I asked.

I ended up going to the counter to ask about the status of my dish when everyone else at my table was pretty much done eating. They said it was still in the works, and it ended up coming 15 minutes later. Seriously? I've ordered it enough times to know how long it takes to make.

Oh and no banchan? 

Even if you ignore the missed order, it wasn't great despite the fact that each plate is only few dollars more expensive than you'd find in SoCal, understandable due to the higher cost of living here. I still can't wrap my head around the fact that some restaurants double or even triple in price for an inferior-quality product. San Francisco is almost as expensive as Korea for KBBQ, so take that into account if you're iffy about the prices here. Its a great value if they actually serve you correctly.

Banchan: missing/5
Fried Chicken: 2/5
Soondubu: 0/5
Cold spicy noodles: 3/5
Service:0/5
Diversity: 2/5
Price: $$/$$$$
Satisfaction:Price- 3/5 -1 for bad service
author: Stanley W.

description:
It's been years since I've been to Cocobang--but the horrific experience that I suffered is unfortunately emblazoned in my mind forever.

The food here is a sad excuse for Korean food. Maybe it was my fault for giving them too much credit and trying to order a legitimate Soondubu at 1am, when tables next to me where chugging 53.4oz of Hite and eating cheese whiz melting off corn cobs. But this place is one soggy seafood pancake from being just a literal hole in the wall where drunk people from Ruby Skye come to drink beer and swipe right on Tinder.

Cocobang receives two stars due to two reasons. 1) the rest of the Korean food in San Francisco is barely tolerable, and 2) this place opens late, when everything else (with the exception of Jack in the Box) is closed. So, there. Nice job.
author: Andy J.

description:
My favorite Korean spot in SF!
The chicken karage w/ slaw and the kimchi fried rice are so on point!
They have a lot of great dishes on the menu and they're open late which is a huge plus for a night owl like me. 

Try it out!
author: Erika S.

description: ordered food from cocobang and the tofu stew came with RAW EGG Inside it. The soup was not hot enough to cook the egg. Combined with the poor food safety score I find this highly concerning, as I ate a few bites before realizing there was a raw egg inside the soup.
author: Lori K.

description: Cocobang makes some damn good wings and is a fun hangout spot that's open late. 4 stars as it's a little grubby, but that's not really a problem.
author: Loren A.

description:
Cocobang oh cocobang
Did it meet expectations? Yes!

We came here for late night and got extremely lucky. We beat the rush by maybe 15 minutes and the wait ended up being 40+ min for those in line. So sad. 

The establishment is cozy, so I understand why there would be a line, especially with drunk kids like myself itching for some Korean food before bedtime. The service was speedy, delicious, and overall satisfying. 

Was it a 5 star satisfying experience? Not quite. But was it a 3 star type of restaurant? Not really. So I give it a 4/5 stars you Korean food eating drunks.
author: Daniel K.

description: This feels like the typical and average spot in NY Koreatown. Small, surly, limited banchan, busy, late night, order right and it's cheap. Spicy tofu soup was good. Pork pieces weren't awesome.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Ode to Korean Fried Chicken: I thought I loved fried chicken before until I met you. Juicy, succulent meat and super crunchy exterior. I love you above all.

Half Order of fried chicken with Hot and Tangy sauce
Beef short rib bbq
Kimchee fried rice

Oh baby....

10% off if you pay in cash...hellz yeah.
author: Viyada S.

description:
This was a horrendous experience. My friends and I ordered take out (Kimchi BokumBab, Bibimbap, and Korean Fried Chicken). All of the food were not seasoned and bland. We didn't even finish any of it, because it was just not worth eating. I'm not sure what it was. Maybe it was because it was around midnight that we ordered. Bad day? 

Worst $40 dollars of Korean food ever spent. This is exactly why I don't like eating Korean food out. It's never worth it, especially when you're Korean!
author: Leta K.

description: OMG the fried chicken is so good and very reasonably priced!  The food comes out pretty quick at this small Korean eatery, so it's great for a to go order, especially for a late night nosh. There are a lot of items on the menu, dive in and be adventurous, it's worth it!
author: Joshua W.

description:
It's really small and seats only a couple tables so getting a seat may be difficult. There's only one waiter and one employee that cleans up the tables so they are constantly running everywhere trying to make everyone happy. I wish they could hire more help. They forgot to bring our OB beer as well and tried to charge us for it. The entree came out before the appetizer before the complimentary appetizers. The order was backwards. 

Aside from the little things, the food is delicious after a long day and not having anything to eat for the last 9 hours. The yogurt soju was good. They fulfilled our request for adding extra soju. We couldn't taste it but we could feel it. The half order of sweet garlic fried chicken was definitely enough between two people to share. The salad with dressing beautifully complimented the chicken. The corn cheese is how all macaroni and cheese should be--a little less calories with more substance. It was gone within several scoops.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: We walked in and the smell grossed me out so bad I had to leave. I didn't see the sanitation score, so I just followed my instinct and left.  I was really looking forward to eating here because of the great online reviews and business associates who raved about the food.
author: Zanthia H.

description:
What's so Korean about this place? Obviously it was not the food. 
I don't want to hate but there was nothing authentic about the food except the beer and soju.

I was really excited about the Korean fried chicken but it was an epic fail, why? lacked flavor and the spicy wings were drenched with some tangy sauce. On the other hand the Korean spicy ribs was SPICY, one tiny bite and my mouth was on fire. The Kimchi fried rice, hmmm was A-ok. Would I come back? UMM NO!!! #FAIL
author: Kathy V.

description: I like the bibimbap and the rice cake soup!  The fried chicken is ok....
author: Cindy C.

description: This place is terrible. They have horrible service and play favorites when giving out tables to guests
author: Sam W.

description:
Decent Korean food, but take it I was starving....

We ordered gyoza, chap chae, chicken cutlet, ribs, chicken cheese wing w/ kimchee, and 2 bottles of peach and strawberry soju.

My favorite had to be chicken cutlet and chap chae.

Bill was about $100 for 4 people.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Another late nite meal. 
As we walked around we kept passing this place so we stepped in. 
Small!!!! We JUST got in ahead of a bunch of folks who waited about 30 mins to get seated - we lucked out. 
Tried soju for the first time. Wow, that's a new liquor to add to our drink list. Really good. 
Had bulgogi and kimchi fried rice. 
Both were good. Way better than my mom makes... 
But not the best ever. 
A fun small funky place. 
Wished they sold their t-shirts!
author: Only Hell Yes Y.

description:
I came here at around 7:30pm and the place was full. I had to wait for around 20 minutes before a table opened up for a group of 4. Make sure you head inside to put your name down on the waiting list because the servers aren't always there to greet you at the door, especially with many people waiting outside. The place is pretty small. I wouldn't bring a group bigger than 6 here since the tables were tiny. Service was okay. The servers don't really check up on you. Now for the food..

Fried chicken w/ green onions: WOW they were really good and crispy. The seasoning they used made the chicken taste sweet which was pleasantly unexpected. There were greens that came with the chicken and they were just ok (a lot of sauce and oil). Some of the chicken pieces were boneless FYI.

Ddeukbokki w/ ramen: Their rice cakes were really soft and not too chewy, and the ramen was cooked just right. The sauce was spicy and on point! I wish there were more fish cake pieces though.

Corn cheese: I usually like this dish but cocobang makes theirs realllly sweet. I don't think I would order this again.

Bibimbap: tastes like any other bibimbap from any korean food joint.

Strawberry soju: really good! the mix isn't overly sweet and even though they use 20% alcohol you can barely taste it. For 1 bottle, you can get 3-4 shots of soju when sharing w/ a group of 4.

Overall, I think this place serves pretty solid Korean food but it is a bit pricey (bill was $59 w/o tip).
author: Emily L.

description: Our group waited about 30 minutes for a table. When we walked in it smelled so good! We ordered 2 types of fried chicken and both were great. One was soy and the other was the gochujang. The food came really quick too which What is shocking due to the amount of business they had. All in all, it was a great meal.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Tasty Korean, great for take out or late night drunchies. 

Enjoyed the spicy soft tofu soup with vegetables (just excellent!), chicken bulgogi was sweet and tasty and the vegetarian bibimbop was spot on. I wish we had ordered two orders of the clear noodles with vegetables as they were among my favorite, along with the soup. (They are on the appetizer menu, but might as well be an excellent side dish to accompany the bbq, etc) Seafood pancake was perfect and pretty full of seafood, too, which I find to rarely be the case.

We ordered takeout and the meal was prepared fast and tasted very fresh--less than twenty minutes to ready. It's not the place to for an elegant leisurely dinner, but the flavors won't disappoint at lunch or latenight.
author: Joss K.

description:
I liked that this place closes at 4am.  We got there around 1am, I believe.  We didn't have to wait, but once we got seated and started eating, the line was out the door.

Dishes we ordered were:
Cheese corn
Kimchee fried rice
Sweet and spicy chicken wings
Peach Soju

Great spot.
author: Rachel L.

description: This is my go to spot in SF when I'm craving chicken after drinking. I love their flavored soju, mixed flavor chicken wings and corn cheese! It's so satisfying! And awesome service too. I usually get the friendly guy with the glasses as my server :) I love this place!
author: Leah A.

description:
I'm a  native no longer living in SF, who was in town for the Christmas holiday. Stayed at the Zeppelin around the corner, and while they were sorting out my reservation I went to put my name in. They told me it was a 40 minute wait for one person, so I'm glad I put my name in and could then finish checking in.

4 - food
3 - service
2 - price

Pros:
The food is great, impressive hit the spot Korean you're looking for. The food really is the draw here.

I had the corn cheese (nothing fancy here, exactly what it sounds like), and the spicy Korean chicken, which was the perfect amount of heavy spice (I would not advise getting the next level up, as the spice just becomes distracting).

Cons:
The wait. The place is tiny and on an empty SF holiday weekend, there was still a 40 minute wait for one person. They will call you if you leave your cell, so do that ahead and plan on grabbing drinks across the street.

The service isn't terribly attentive, and the small space with the door constantly opening creates a somewhat stressed eating environment.

The price. Don't bother buying booze, everything is overpriced and the booze isn't worth it. This is the kind of place that would be AMAZING if it was just $2-3 less. It's a hole-in-the-wall place deserving of hole-in-the-wall prices.
author: Eric B.

description:
The name is somehow incredibly accurate--Cocobang is beloved like something you'd imagine to be called Coco, and the night always ends with a bang.

The place is smaller than most Korean bars of this type, but that gives it even more of a hole-in-the-wall feeling, especially when it's located in the middle of a side street in Downtown SF.  The ambiance is down-to-earth, almost like those street food booths you always see in kdramas where people go to drink soju and eat BBQ by themselves when they are sad (they even have the same red and blue color scheme!)

Expect a wait, especially at night, but the server is very friendly and welcoming.  He made sure we were seated and gave us menus, so the wait didn't end up being so bad.  

The YOGURT SOJU  is good, as expected, and served in a curious flask that looks like a vase.  It makes yogurt soju ever more deceptive because at a point you feel like you aren't drinking anything but it's really just a trick of the curvy glass.

The CHICKEN CUTLET WITH SPECIAL SAUCE is amazing; it's two ginormous pieces of perfect panko cutlet with that yummy Korean cabbage salad.  Fyi the special sauce is that cutlet sauce that's like soy sauce but better.  

A lot of people get horribly drunk; I truly respect the servers for having the guts to put up with this and still be so nice and positive.  From a customer's perspective, it's almost sadistically entertaining to watch the wasted people stumbling around.  Lastly, warning that, as expected, the bathroom can be gross.  (I assume more so the later in the night it gets)

Conclusion: Late-night shenanigans galore
author: Edna C.

description:
The food is very average but it definitely satisfies your cravings. It closes late so it's the perfect place to grab a bite after a long night.

I love that the food didn't take long to arrive. We came right before the rush, but the place is a little small so not many people can fit. 

I had the corn cheese which was nice and fattening, fish cake soup which was a little on the bland side but they were very generous with their fish cake, and half of the garlic fried chicken which tasted more soy saucy than garlicky.

Would I come back here? No. It reminds me of Americanized Korean food as opposed to legitimate Korean food.
author: Cam C.

description: Food was okay, the chicken was best. Compared to the short rib which was extremely spicy. The overal place has people coming in n out which seemed ok. On the alc side not too bad either. The people are great but it's just for a late night meal ;)
author: Alan D.

description: Got home with the wrong order m! Seriously! I called in to order togo earlier, first I ordered Sprites and hot tangy chicken wings,  and the guys asked me if I want rice , and I said no I want drinks !!! S-P-r-I -t-e!!!! Not rice.. when I picked up my order I got fries and fried chickens instead. I called them and told the server they got my order wrong but he goes, no you told me the wrong answer when I was asking you...seriously...what a great customer manners you got there. So disappointed!!!! If you are not sure about the order next time, ask twice before you assume!
author: Lyn Z.

description: Came here after a night out celebrating a friend's birthday. Ordered the crystal noodles, sizzling hot spicy pork, and the fried chicken (regular and with the hot sauce). Everything was really good and worked well with each other. Just had to take one star away as service was a bit slow and you had to kind of "hunt down" your server (which is surprising because the place isn't that big). But overall, it was good!
author: Daniel M.

description:
One of the best late night eats in SF! 

- Open till 2AM. The place to end up after clubbing/drinking in downtown 
- After 12 this place gets very busy, there is a long waiting line, especially on Fri/Sat . 
- Small place, so not a good place for large group.
- Fried chicken goodness with lots of difference flavors/spice levels to choose from.

MUST HAVE -
- Yogurt soju 
- Kimchee fried rice (served with fried egg) : not oily, perfect flavor $11
- Corn and cheese appetizer : Cheesy goodness!!  $8
- Fried chicken hot&tangy $9
- Seafood pancake $14
author: Payal B.

description:
Holy sh*t this place is the bomb.com. Came here with a friend on a Monday night and still had to wait for seats (granted this place is small). Walk inside and tell the guy your name and number of party so he can write you down on the list.

I was skeptical about ordering the Hot and Tangy wings but a friend recommended and said it wasn't spicy at all so I tried. And OMG it really wasn't spicy at all! It was so delicious. The chicken was a little bit overcooked but the sauce was amazeballs. It was sweet and sooooooo goooood. I was in heaven. I got a half order. Gets you about 6 pieces (sad I got 1 wing and 5 random pieces). Comes with some salad on the side which was a nice balance of flavors. Good dressing. Also tried their tofu soup. It's pretty good. About standard taste compared to other Korean restaurants. Nothing to rave about.

Definitely will be coming back for more chicken wings. OMG my mouth is watering just thinking about it... BTW if you pay with cash, you get 10% off your bill.
author: Benita M.

description:
This review is written purely from a chilehead perspective. I have only had their "Burning Hot Chicken" (several times!) and it is simply sublime.

Don't get me wrong, I love some extremely hot foods, but I always also want flavor too, and that is what CocoBang delivers. The chicken was melt-in-your-mouth tender and flavorful, but with a heat that gave me a nice runny nose and forehead sweat.

Tiny little place, so order to-go or delivery or be ready to wait.

Huge fan of CocoBang.
author: Paul D.

description:
GREAT LATE NIGHT SNACKIN'! 

This place is a Korean snackin treasure trove and it's open till 4a.m.! If you get out of a concert, club, or finals studying, this place is always nice to come through to afterwards! Try their different varieties of fried chicken. Generally comes with one or two chickens with bones and a couple of HUUUGE crunchy boneless fried chickens. MmmmM. So it evens out for those friends that love to suck on bones and for those friends that just want to eat without the hassle of bones. The budae jiggae is pretty good here. I would probably order extra noodles next time! They are extremely generous on the sausages in the soup, but after running out of the noodles, I had nothing to eat with the sausages!!! Their bean sprout side dish is on point, and so are their fish cakes! 

The atmosphere is cute! They've got a projector with kpop mvs playing at the top, and the whole store is made out of bricks! Small place, but they made it hip and poppin'! Definitely a go-to spot when driving around SF late night. Also, service is hecka sweet! Although there's always a wait and they're understaffed, they're still super friendly and considerate!
author: Kim N.

description:
When hungry after a bike ride across the Golden Gate Bridge to Salusilito and back, searching for sushi restaurants that were about to close at 10pm on a Saturday night, Cocobang came to the rescue!! We did not have to be told that the wait would be 1.5 hours. Instead, it was 10 minutes! Yay! 

Since dinner was super late for me, shared the BBQ Combo - spicy pork BBQ and chicken bulgogli. Bold spicy flavors!! Overall a good late night snack/dinner. 

Nothing fancy about this place. Just good eats! :)
author: Tzarina W.

description: Well, what should I start, first there is long way and I waitting for 5 mins , the points is I am first people on the line. But they just ask Korea guy in Korean . So I ask them are they first? Then, they give me seat first. Also they didn't served water, so what can I say?
author: Mindy Y.

description: I've never given a one star rating after 4+ years in Yelp, until now. The wait staff was exceedingly disrespectful and unprofessional. It was a cold weekend and they guys in our group were fine waiting outside, but they insisted the girls wait outside as well. Meanwhile they sat two groups of Koreans ahead of us. When we protested the proprieter sarcastically asked if we could read the sign he posted. I failed to see why we had to wait outside while other groups had everyone waiting inside. In addition I could hear him and his staff muttering to each other in Korean while glaring at us. I have been here at least four times in the past and each time they've exhibited hints of rude behavior, such as speaking to us in sneering tones, or audibly sighing if we had a question or request, but this experience was over the top and blatantly disrespectful. The food was ok and I've overlooked their abysmal customer service and food safety score in the past as a result, but the treatment I received this past weekend compels me to state unequivocally that I will never eat here again and will actively be telling my friends to avoid this "establishment".
author: John F.

description: The portions were a bit skimpy and our meals were lukewarm in temperature. Most bibimpaps I've had at Korean restaurants are in a hot stone dish, so you get that nice crunchy rice on the edges. Not here. Not worth your time.
author: Amy M.

description: Unfair host. We were next in line and they called for party of 3 ahead of us... then proceeded to seat 8-10 people. Left and not coming back
author: Andrew T.

description:
How this place doesn't have a solid five star average is beyond me. Yes it's small but the tables turn over quickly. We were visiting San Fran for a night and this is the place we chose. We've been missing Korean food so much since leaving Northern Va. 

The fried chicken here...man I'm in love. So crispy and sweet with a little heat--we ordered the half chicken in the sweet sauce. It was six, good size pieces, mostly boneless. Soooo yummy! We also ordered the clear noodles from the appetizer and my hubs still can't stop talking about them. Side dishes had a bean sprout salad that we're going to copy when we get home. Pot stickers were good. Kloud beer and a bottle of Soju, we were set.

The prices were much less than I expected in SF, but I imagine they may have some competition so they keep the prices low.

That five hour drive for that fried chicken, damn. I'd do it again.
author: Mandi B.

description:
Loveeeeeeeeeee this place. Not many places are open past 2AM so that's already awesome.

Conveniently located close to Union Square, makes for a great post-clubbing spot.

We actually went here for dinner on a weeknight and really enjoyed it- filling food and super sweet soju! The prices are fair - like any other Korean late-night spot. $16 for most meats & other main dishes.

Def awesome! The space isn't large, so plan ahead for a wait or go early. Great for parties of 2-4.
author: Veronica S.

description: One of the best Korean food restaurant in SF. One thing that bothers the place is that they always have full table.
author: HJ C.

description: We were looking for a Korean place nearby and this spot was just a 10 minute walk. The restaurant is small so seating is limited, but it was well worth our 30 minute wait. We got the kimchi fried rice and bibimbap and it was great. Will probably come back to this spot if we're ever in the area!
author: Puneet H.

description: Not at all what I was expecting. My Kimchi, pork & tofu was way overly sweet. I only ate a couple of bites and had to stop. Ended up eating what my hubby left of the bimbibap and was a bit bland but decent enough to eat.  I'll give it another chance and try other plates but based on this experience, I'm only giving it two stars.
author: Alana L.

description: Waitress straight up ignored me when I kindly asked for an estimated wait time. Do not recommend during busy hours.
author: Andy Y.

description:
Sorry San Francisco. When it comes to Korean style fried chicken, LA has it much better. But, I will give some props to Cocobang for representing downtown Union Square. When, you're trying to feed the late night hunger, beggars can't be choosers, and I think Cocobang passes the test.

OPEN LATE
Till 2AM daily and 4AM on Friday and Saturday. The selection is what impresses me the most. Greasy fried chicken, often smothered in sauce. Korean comfort food that satisfies your late night munchies, while calmly subduing the inner drunkard in you. The only objection to the late night hours is the wait. Come at the wrong time and you're looking for at your watch for 30 minutes plus.

Let's focus the attention back to their selection of food, which appearing on their website, gives you some relief from the hunger pains generated from downing soju shots to the face. Small dishes, soups, BBQ, and dinner plates are all accounted for. Take a breather and check it out. (http://www.cocobangsf.com/mm1.php).

I think the prices are a little bit over the top, but I do understand the cost of living around here. To say that I was surprised with the total bill is an understatement. 11 bucks for a headache in a green bottle? I'll stick to a pitcher of OB for next time. One more thing, be careful when you use the restroom. Going down a flight of stairs when intoxicated is not my idea of fun. Don't trip and let your life flash before your eyes.

CHRIS EATS HERE
who you calling chicken? series
author: Chris C.

description:
Coco Bang is the DTSF/Theater District's equivalent to El Faralito in the Mission, and Pizza Orgasmica in the Fillmore Triangle...good Drunk food. 

It is a bit more upscale than those, being that you can sit down and have table service. And like a cheaper Foreign Cinema or your favorite Korean or Vietnamese Place, you can eat while watching videos on the big TV above the kitchen, if you like K-Pop boy and girl bands. Many Occidentals would say that Asians all look alike, but K-Pop groups take this to another level, making the members all look alike through the thriving cosmetic surgery biz there, perhaps the best in the world. K Culture (K-Pop, K-Drama, subsidized by the K-Govt)  is big business worldwide, and K-CosSurg is a huge supporting player. 

I digress. This is more like a Korean Chicken place meets a Po Chow, or Korean drinking bar. It is like the new international version of the old All-American Soda Shop of the '50s, with their Milkshakes and French Fries and little Sock Hops to the Juke Box. That is all replaced with K-Pop Vids and Kimchi, and flavored Soju and Pitchers of Beer, OB or Hite. 

It is a small place, about 8 tables, 4 on the left, 4 on the right, bright red, that mimics the fun whimsy that is often in K-Pop videos. Oh, how I miss you Wonder Girls, "Nobody But You". 

You can get many of your fave foods, including Soon Dubu, Fried Chicken, Kimchi Korean Pancakes, Noodles, etc. Add beer or Soju, and a couple of drunk friends after a night at Ruby Skye, and you are in Hog Heaven (well, or Pork Dreamland).

In classic Korean resto fashion, you can just point at the pictures on the menu if you don't know the names of what you like, or too drunk to say them.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Cocobang has some tasty Korean food!

Food:
I have been here a few times and have tasted several dishes. The last time I visited, I indulged in the pork cutlet with special sauce, kimchi fried rice, and fire spicy chicken.

The pork cutlet was perfectly fried, and the sweet special sauce was the perfect complement.

The kimchi was flavorful and moderately spicy, and came with a sunny-side up egg.

The fire spicy chicken is no joke. It is spicy! If you can handle the fire spicy chicken, you can step it up a notch, and order the burning fire spicy chicken.

Side Notes

Ambiance:
The restaurant is small, so I believe accommodating large groups for this restaurant would be tough. The place is modernly decorated, and always has Korean music videos playing. If you are planning on visiting for a late-night snack, expect a long wait.

Service:
Every time I have visited, I have always had good service. The employees are very friendly.

Overall:
If you have not been, give this place a try! The food is tasty and the service is friendly.
author: Garrett F.

description: Awesome food even when taken away! The tofu stew tasted comforting, tofu was smooth and pork isn't the fatty type! The spicy pork bbq was slightly oily but still great flavour. Takeaways came with side dishes still, pleasant surprise! The fishcake side dish was awesome :)
author: Cheryl S.

description:
The food is way better than 707. I was always particularly dissatisfied with the soups at 707 and I think I've now found a good alternative for whenever I'm near Powell. In the past, I always found myself at 707 because they have a lot more space which makes it better for groups. But considering that both restaurants are in the same area, and the wait for Cocobang was alright, I'll be choosing Cocobang next time I'm craving Korean food. 

Not only was the food significantly better than 707, but the service was also exceptional here. Our waiter brought over an extra chair for our bags without us even asking! He also switched out our plates extremely quickly to make more room on the table for us. Throughout our meal we never had to ask for anything or wave him down because he was always one step ahead of us.

This also reminds me of a random time I was craving cheese ddukboki which is not on their menu. I ended up asking one of the staff here if they would be able to add cheese to this dish anyways and they kindly put in the request for me, no judgment. Within a few minutes, I had a huge togo box of cheese ddukboki at no extra charge. I think it's safe to say that the service at Cocobang exceeds expectations.

Lastly, it's kinda sketch, but pay in cash to get 10% off!
author: Junes S.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars based on the two times I've been here.

First time (incredibly drunk and blacking out as I was eating):
The only thing I remembered from this night was that the kimchi fried rice was bomb. I was told the next day I also ordered tofu soup and bulgogi. I finished all 3.

Second time (sober):
Food was pretty good for a Korean restaurant & bar. I've been to a lot of Korean bars , and I can honestly say Cocobangs is one of the better kbars for food. It's not fine dining, but for a Korean restaurant open until 3 am, you really can't complain.

It's tiny and it's super busy at night. The vibe is very "eat fast and leave" lol I saw servers rush people that are eating/drinking slowly to finish up so they can seat their next customers.

Overall, food is pretty good and the price is reasonable. I'd recommend this spot to anyone that's looking for late night food and down for Korean.
author: Steven O.

description:
I can't say that I've been to any Korean restaurants late at night without the intention of getting drunk off of soju, but this past Saturday night, I just wanted some food. SO and I found ourselves here at around 11pm after seeing our friend's work on display at Joy Gallery. After waiting for awhile with no one acknowledging our existence, we had to flag down a waitress to let her know we were waiting to be seated. We ended up ordering the Kimchi Fried Rice and a half order of Hot and Tangy Fried Chicken. The Kimchi fried rice tasted off, like something in there went bad. The Fried chicken was tasty though. 

10% off your bill if you pay cash!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
3.5 STARS

Nothing good happens after 2AM. Nothing.

Pick your poison:

1) Bang a KFC. Regret it in the morning. 
2) Bang a drunktard. Regret it in the morning. The day after. And, the day you're spread eagle at the Dr.'s office. 

Sorry, I don't know about you but I vote for the first. 

Other than your 24 hour greasy spoon diners, Cocobang is one of the few restaurants that closes at 4 AM on weekends in SF. They are known for two things: Korean Fried Chicken and drunktard eats. If you're sober, hungry and/or it's after 12:30 AM, GO elsewhere. Cocobang can only seat 24 people so there will be a wait of at least 20-45 minutes around a bunch of obnoxious, peace-sign whoring aZn drunktards slurring all the wrong words to the Kpop videos blaring in the background. Me being one of them. 

Since the Fire Chicken hurts more coming out then going in, I normally stick with the KFC (Half Order - $8.95) with gochujang chili sauce on the side. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=1ANUyIoTu4x8qgSuJYo6Mg#SyVefsuVXf8gztNBjHsAIA Deliciously crunchy on the outside and succulently moist in the center, the KFC is very flavorful and quite satisfying after a night of drinking. That along with the salad doused with a bukkake of thousand island dressing makes it one gluttonous dish. 

The Soondubu Jjigae (Soft Tofu Soup - $10.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=1ANUyIoTu4x8qgSuJYo6Mg#j0u67waZPmphX6UCc2er7A is also a safe choice as is the Kalbi ($14.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=1ANUyIoTu4x8qgSuJYo6Mg#JtEmeSt_LABB_SSpHlwXzg. I've had better at other places but at 2-3 AM, I can't complain especially when it's a tad cheaper than other Korean joints. 

Stay away from the flavored soju though. It tastes like spiked Pedialyte. Something you'll need a lot of IF you eat the Fire Chicken. Just saying...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We ordered kimchi fried rice, rice cake dumpling soup, spicy fried chicken, and the padak (chicken with side seasoned green onions?)
Personally i wished that fried rice was less oily but it was still good. 
Rice cake dumpling, we actually ordered by accident but it was a great choice. I recommend this if you are craving something soothing.
Spicy fried chicken was a little too sweet for me, wished that it would be more spicy and have more kick to it. 
I liked padak more for my choice of chicken. I liked the seasoning but once again, the sauce for green onions was too sweet for me.
author: Irene L.

description:
I came here late a night with a group of friends to sober up after drinking. I like how they're opened late but the wait sucks since the restaurant is pretty small. 
Food was was pretty good.
I would definitely come back again if I was in the area!
author: Stephanie N.

description:
Open until 4am!!! Im down!
This was a suggestion from my friend.  I just arrived in the bay and headed to my brother's birthday party dinner @ his friends house in Marin county.  So driving from OC all the way to Marin county, I was exhausted! and i wanted to eat something after the party.  My friend suggested this place.
I yelped for directions.  Awesome part was finding close street parking to the resto!
As my friend and I entered the place, we were greeted rt away and seated within in 5mins.  We lucked out, since the place was full.  It was abt 1am!
We ordered the short ribs and the fried chicken and a bottle of rasberry soju.
Yummm rasberry soju! 
The server was very friendly.  Food came out fast.  The short ribs was good but had better.  I'd just come here if nothing else is open and for the soju!
author: Remie M.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting from SoCal and we felt like we wanted a Korean night out. We went to coco bang for some drinks and when we got there they made us order food along with our drinks. They said it was policy. 

We obliged and ordered more drinks as the night went on. 

After awhile one of the owners came to our table and said we had to leave due to the fact that we had been there for almost 2 hours (we had been ordering drinks all night). 

Basically it just seemed like they were making up rules to make as much money as possible. Anyone coming from New York or LA would be sorely disappointed. The food was mediocre and the service was awful.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
This place is so chill! Really good for late nights or if you want to relax without doing anything too crazy in the city. The food is good (wings and kimchee fried rice are a must) and the service is pretty good. Even though they open late, they will stop alcohol service, but you can still stay and hang out. 

It is ALWAYS packed, so try to beat the crowd, usually before the clubs get out.. people linger so it will take a while if you end up waiting.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Terrible!!! After club, we were drunk, then we sat in the restaurant, when we were about to The start ordering, the owner kicked us off, because we were too drunk, i guss. But thats not the case.
As a customer we do not deserve this. Hope this place goes bankrupt soon. Terrible!!
author: Omega A.

description:
2 am in the morning.  After returning from an unsatisfying trip to the Castro/Folsom area, I Ubered it back to our hotel in the Grand Hyatt.  Then a text from my Yelp wife.  Hey we just decided to go get some fried chicken.  As soon as I got out of the car in front of the hotel, I realized where the place was - CocoBang.

Of course, she had me at fried chicken.  However since this is a well-know after bars closed eatery, this small place in theTenderloin area (maybe edge) was crowded as heck with lines of Asian men and women.  Of course it was a line to wait but one of our crowd's hotel was close by so we ordered to go.

I didn't taste anything but the chicken but we had kimchee fried rice (its a Korean fried chicken), fries and pot sticker.  After a not so drunken but imbibed several beers this evening, the fried chicken tasted great with just salt and pepper to add.

The best part - the chicken tasted great several hours later when we woke up.

CoCoBang you can bang bang my fried chicken anytime.

Oh yeah some had bones, some had not but it tasted Great!
author: Melanio F.

description: Place is great. The food is so good and very tasty. They are open till late as well , so it's perfect for people who gets late snack. I will definitely come back. The only think i don't like is i can smell the people who smokes outside, otherwise, i'll give them 5 star.
author: Mitos E.

description: This is such a popular place for drunk late night eating. I came with a group of 9 and they accommodated us after a 20 minutes wait. I ordered the spicy tofu soup ($12). It's pricey, but they give you a lot of tofu. The spicy is exactly how I liked it as well. But when you're drunk and hungry, this place is perfect.
author: Cindy Z.

description: It's not the best Korean food place since its not an upscale restaurant. But the staff are sincere and courteous and I really appreciate this type of attitude.
author: Hyun B.

description:
One of the best korean style chicken I've visited in SF. If you like chicken & beer like I do, this place is must! :D
Their food was delicious, very good service, place was casual and cozy.
author: Maki J.

description:
I walked into this place and it was crowded, so this was a good sign. Simply put -  tasty chicken bulgogi, the spicy short rib was my favorite along with the kimchi fried rice. Tasty potstickers too, overall a great late night option... plus you get a 10% discount if paying with cash, so naturally I made it rain. 

Took away one star because the booth we sat at was uncomfortable.. Not bearable uncomfortable but just plain uncomfortable. I will definitely come again and eat away the discomfort.
author: Francisco V.

description: Really Good variety of food!!! I personally like the Spicy and the Garlic Soy Sauce chicken and kimchi fried rice. When you are done eating,  no need to wash dishes or hire someone to wash dishes.
author: Gil H.
