description: Was quite surprised at this place. Got the Korean fried chicken with the spicy sauce on top. Usually I am not a fan of fried food, but the sauce was very thick and tangy, flavorful! And yet not oily!! Also got the dobbuki and it was sooo good. Bibimbap was good too, and you could control the amount of spicy sauce to go on top. I would recommend their fried chicken, I dont know compared to other korean restaurants this place beats the ones I've went to.
author: Jasmina D.

description: Very delicious food! They are amazingly fast and take care of their customers. Wish I live in San Fran to go there regularly!
author: Arne H.

description:
A great Korean bar/grill in the city. 

It's a small location so be sure to wait around dinner time, but it's worth the wait for their chicken wings and soju.

I'm not quite sure what the fuss is about cheesy corn, but there aren't any huge complaints.

I will say their ramen with spam and sausage is quite delectable. It isn't too spicy which is great for me. I enjoyed the Chinese sausage the most because I've never seen it added to a kimchi soup base.

A great outing to start or end the night!
author: Jonathan T.

description: Very friendly staff and relatively good food, except the fried chicken sizes were too big and seasonings difficult to differentiate. There are other Korean fried chicken places within blocks that have crispier, better seasoned fried chicken. The prices are very fair and a repeat visit is most likely, but not for the fried chicken.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Good Korean food open late at night... what more can you ask for?
The tofu soup was only okay... but the homemade korean noodle soup with clams was amazing! Perfect for dinner on a cold day.
author: Michelle L.

description:
POST CLUBBING KOREAN EATS OPEN TIL 4AM?? HELL YES.

Omelette: HUGE egg omelette with ketchup, so simple yet perfect when you don't feel like putting work into eating your food

Chicken Wings + Green Onion Salad
- super greasy with good sweet flavor, very generous with green onions (i'm a fan), make sure to separate you're salad immediately from the pool of oil under neath the chicken!

Spicy Tofu Soup
- very standard, almost exactly like the one at Arang, there were some seafood shell shards in the soup so be careful!

Clear Clam Soup
- Strong seafood broth flavor!  I was impressed at the richness of the soup, it tasted like the shells of a hundred shrimp, clams, and mussels were boiled for an hour!  certainly good recovery food
- **definitely recommend this one**

Kimchi Fried Rice
- super average, there is nothing bad/good I can really say about this, except they could step the flavor up by using butter!

I'll be honest. the food is pretty standard compared any other Korean place, but it is SO good when you are starving after a night of hard partying.  4 stars for OUTSTANDING SERVICE at an ungodly hour, late night availability, and decent food!
author: Tina A.

description:
First and foremost the service was really good.  The staff there were very attentive of their tables.  They were pleasant and really helpful.  The food was pretty good.  We enjoyed the cheese corn and the spicy octopus to share; then I had a combo dinner of chicken bulgogi and short ribs while my husband feasted on the cheesy spicy chicken.  We also really enjoyed their yogurt soju.  

This was a great spot for our date night tonight!  Thank you Cocobang for an awesome dinner!
author: Raisa M.

description:
One star bonus for being one of those rare late night spots with solid food in SF. Our waiter was very nice - we 4 girls were going to order 4 dishes (the three below + corn & cheese) and asked if it was too much food, and he actually said yes! I've never been told that by a server before. He was just kind of hard to understand though, with a really heavy Korean accent.

Also - cheap! $9 for all of this w/ tax & tip (split b/t the 4 of us).

* Free cold starters - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=qP6yaFZ5v4SJ1MN7HvQJhg#_I-CWZUVe9UydGNhSOXVxg
Not the largest selection I've seen, but good fresh daikon, and the potato salad had apple in it which I liked.

* Sweet & Spicy Chicken - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=qP6yaFZ5v4SJ1MN7HvQJhg#bP3O8xGmSGX9jPN-VoMpRQ
Pretty spicy! And tangy/sweet. Meat good, not super moist, but still enjoyable for late night. The skin was baked pretty thick and hard. The sauce over the shredded lettuce was actually really good too. Half order gave us about 7 wings.

* Kimchi fried rice - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=qP6yaFZ5v4SJ1MN7HvQJhg#gU8oH7vbjrzHQs0foNMyjw
A simple dish but actually quite good. Intense in the kimchi flavor, with a sunny side up egg with soft (but not runny - though that would've been good) yolk on top. The sausages, though not as plentiful as I would've liked, were rich and savory and great.

* Garlic fries - 2.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jBdCBZc7-ab7c2tpoIEWJw?select=qP6yaFZ5v4SJ1MN7HvQJhg#qP6yaFZ5v4SJ1MN7HvQJhg
These are thick and oily. Probably about as good as generic frozen fries you might buy at a Safeway and bake (though with lots of oil). Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed this as fries really never can be bad to me, but the garlic flavor really was not apparent and they weren't special in any way.
author: Ziyan C.

description: I don't understand the three-star rating for this place. Have people in SF never been to LA and eaten real Korean food? Yes, this place has some American influence, but the only thing you can fault them on are the portion sizes for the price. Otherwise, a Korean establishment, THAT'S OPEN UNTIL 4AM, which serves bossam, army soup, and pork neck stew, should be venerated in a city with a giant black hole where Korean food should be. This isn't the Sunset or Richmond, where you've got Han il Kwan or Toyose. You're on freaking Taylor Street, and you've found an oasis of actual Korean food. Bow down. Service is quick once you get seated, but be prepared to be rushed. These guys only have two servers, and they're hauling ass to get to all the tables. They're also probably pissed because of all the drunkards coming in and giving them crap or not being able to order properly. So, sit, order two bottles of chamisul fresh, a couple pitchers of hite, their original fried chicken (deliciously double-fried), some bossam (excellent portion size), and kimchi fried rice. Things here are spicy and hot, and they come out quickly. Eat, drink, be merry. Don't be an asshole.
author: Danny C.

description: Spicy tofu hot pot is great. The egg and tofu  in the pot are so soft. And I ordered extra spicy one, wow~
author: Shadow L.

description:
Atmosphere: Small restaurant with limited seating. They have Korean music playing in the background and a projector screen showing Korean music videos. There is usually a line of people waiting to get seated, so try to get there earlier (before dinner rush) if possible. 

Drinks:
Peach soju and mango soju - Both my friend and I ordered our separate sojus, because we thought they would come in small glasses. However, they came in a mid-size soju decanter pitcher. The sweet and fruity soju is mixed with chucks of ice, which made it taste like a super sweet slushy. The mango soju was sweeter than the peach soju, but they were both too sweet for me likely. Try to finish the soju before the ice melts, BECAUSE after the ice melts, the soju becomes thick and syrupy. 

Food:
Pan fried rice cake with spicy: I thought the portion was small given the price, especially since there were more vegetables than rice cakes. The spicy-sweet sauce was balanced and not too spicy.
author: Angel G.

description: We were in San Francisco and had the brilliant idea of getting Korean fried chicken, because two out of the three of us had never had it before. The food came out fast and it was delicious. The simple salad it came with was great, too. The banchan was delicious, as well. It's a tiny restaurant, but pretty authentic. I definitely want to come back to try more!
author: Ally M.

description:
I think it says it says a lot when the standout memory of coming here was "what is that nasty pink sauce on my cabbage?" Y'see, I live in a city that's bereft of many outstanding Asian eats. Thus, when I come to SF, I'm drawn to get to my fill of Korean, Filipino, Chinese, Vietnamese, Japanese, Burmese, etc. food. Given Cocobang's proximity to my hotel, I fell into its orbit. I anticipated Korean fare reminiscent of my beloved Crisp in Chicago. This was no Crisp.

It's not my fault to make such a comparison. Cocobang was all, 'my chicken is too good, chile'. You betta eat it!' So, I did. It was ok. It was no Seoul Sassy.* The banchan was ok. The rice was ok. The cabbage with pink sauce was the work of the devil. My overall experience was ok. In a city packed with tremendous depth of quality Asian eats, Cocobang can be missed. If you're coming to SF from a city with little in the way of quality Asian eats, Cocobang is an ok choice... if near your hotel... and you're hungry... and you're not that familiar with Korean food.

*If you don't know, book a ticket. Fly to Chicago. Go straight to Crisp. Order the Seoul Sassy. Get turned out.
author: Johnny T.

description:
The kimchi fried rice was really good! The army soup and the fried chicken were decent. The fried chicken could have been a bit crispier and spicier - I've had better in Korea. But Korea has an extremely saturated fried chicken industry, so that's not a fair comparison.

I haven't tried their drink selection, but I hear it's pretty good. Will be coming back!
author: Jiwon K.

description:
TL;DR?? BOMB Kimchi Fried Rice that you MUST try!! Friendly, quick service. Good hangover munchies. Small location, street parking, has a screen projector with Kpop MVs playing sweettt

Food Quality, Service: B+
Prices: B
Location/Ambiance: B-

It's 3AM. My friends and I just left The Grand and we are hungry for some munchies!!! We got there and the server informed us that their kitchen closes at 3:30PM and there were two parties ahead of us. If we were seated before 3:30PM, then he could take our orders but we'd be taking a risk in case we waited 1/2 hour for nothing. Luckily by the power of Late Night Munchies divinity, we got seated at 3:25PM hallelujah!

Ordered the Kimchi Fried Rice, BBQ Kalbi, and Pan Fried Rice Cake w/Ramen Noodle (topokki). Our meal came with only 3 banchans (fish cake, kimchi, and bean sprouts). Yes they were busy and it was closing time but they never refilled our banchans :( They were excellent with refilling our waters though. 

.....Kimchi Fried Rice:: One of the best EVER! I've had this dish at almost every Korean restaurant I visit. I even MAKE kimchi fried rice and I can tell you that their sunny-side up egg, sausages, kimchi, and spicy paste all marinate into this plate of heaven. Definitely. Get. This.

.....BBQ Kalbi:: Was decent. It was definitely sweetly marinated (usual guzzling Korean marinade sauce) but there was like only about 8 pieces for $14+...Not worth it! Came out on your standard sizzling plate with onions and we had to ask for white rice. Odd that it does not automatically come with rice??

.....Pan Fried Rice Cake w/Ramen:: This is my friend's fave dish since there are not many Korean restaurants that make this but oh boy... It looks completely spicy and appetizing but when we bit into it, it tasted like the cook accidentally dropped a CUP of sugar into it! I've never had such sweet tasting noodles yikes! The rice cakes were delicious and soft though, and the the hard-boiled egg was mediocre. I would've preferred a soft-boiled egg haha. Verdict: Way too sweet, that it's simply criminal. 

Overall service was okay as they were nice enough to accommodate us. The place itself is tiny with like ~10 tables and chairs around. But it is SF after all and space is a luxury. I will definitely try this place again if I get the munchies after a night in town!
author: Donna T.

description:
The place could not be more solid. Had the bossam and haemul soondooboo. The bossam was perfectly tender and all of the accouterments added depth to each bite. The soondooboo was flavorful, full of seafood and tofu, and extremely satisfying. The two servers were efficient and friendly (and cute!). Prices are also very reasonable for this part of town. Just off a week long vacation/ragefest/bender in New York, it was strange just eating Korean without soju and Hite, but the food was so great I didn't miss it much. 

"Thank you James." -my liver

Protip: this place gets buuuusy (but for good reason), so be prepared to wait a little.
author: James H.

description:
You're reading this either because it's late night and you're drunk, or you just want some Korean food and you're too lazy to go to the Sunset, or both. Let's break it down. Cocobang has a few things going for it. 

1) It's open extra extra late. Way past when any of the bars close. Why not have breakfast before you sleep? 

2) Your orders come out extremely fast.  ~10 minutes for four dishes seriously impressed me. 

3) It's darn tasty. The fried chicken was super tender and flavorful. The spicy BBQ pork came out piping hot, spicy, and greasy enough for me and my friends to gobble it down, but not greasy enough for me to rethink my diet. Also try the pig's feet and at least a bottle of soju. 

However there are also a few things within and out of its control that hurt its competitiveness. 

1) It's a small place, and the wait time can be painfully long. A party of eight is seriously pushing it. 

2) Relative to nearby Korean establishments, the portions are less than impressive for the price you pay. 

3) The side dishes are sadly lacking in variety and quantity. If you're a fan of side dishes, this may not be the place for you.
author: Jason T.

description: This is my third time here. I'm glad I bought my friends here because they love the food. We ordered half fried chicken and half fried chicken with hot & tangy sauce, glass noodles, kimchee rice and bbq combo. Everything is good. The place is so tiny so we have to wait about 15mins but its all worth it.
author: mel m.

description:
5 stars!!! Are you people drunk when you are reviewing this place?! 


I came here once at 3:30am, it was mouth watering. I am here before peak hours and my mouth is still watering. My friend and I shared the bbq salad and fried chicken in tangy sauce. We ordered more, anticipating  taking left overs home, however it is so hard to resist eating it all. My taste glands do not know what to do right now. 

The wait is long and the place is small, but it is worth it. It is Korean bbq bar style, way different than traditional Kbbq!!! 

The service is fast and everyone here is friendly. 

This place is open late, it is great bar food, and has a great atmosphere. My friend lives next door, so I will be coming back. 

All you haters, need to check your taste buds!!!!

*** and they accommodate for unethnic cultures with garlic fries! :)
author: Rochelle E.

description: This place is legit Korean food. It is the best Korean food we had so far, ever! The pork was amazing and the stir fry glass noodles were superb. Totally recommend this place.
author: Piyush S.

description:
For SF, this is probably one of the best Korean spots. Everything I tried on the menu was very tasty (fried chicken, combo of spicy pork/spicy beef short rib, kimchi fried rice, yogurt soju). I would definitely return. 

On a busy night, be prepared for a wait. It's a smallish restaurant so not a lot of space.
author: Judi B.

description:
It's hard to write this review because some things were so good and some things were really not good at all. I am visiting San Fran and arrived late, was starving and found this place near my hotel. It's a tiny place that has only about ten tables or so. I had to wait about 15 minutes for a table which was fine.

One thing I must say is that the servers were so attentive. The service was great. As for the food, I wanted bulgogi and I also wanted ddukbokki. However, unlike most Korean places they don't have a ddukbokki appetizer, it's an entrée. So I said what the hell and ordered it anyway. The server did warn me it was too much food but I figured as much. 

I wanted bokbunja as it was on their menu but they said they didn't have any. I ordered the strawberry soju which was strawberries blended in soju, almost like a daiquiri but not as icy. It was pretty sweet and towards the end, I couldn't drink it anymore because there was too much sugar. 

The bulgogi was really good and I ate it all, very good marinade. Probably one of the best I've had. However, the rice accompanying it was not good, it tasted kind of old. The banchan were not varied and not very good. No kimchi!!!!! What the hell? How can you be a Korean place and not serve kimchi? I almost cried, seriously. 

The ddukbokki was okay. I mostly ate the dduk and left the other stuff. It came in a kimchi type sauce, not gochujang like I'm used to. So it was kind of watery and the veggies in it were not really cooked. There were some slices of fish cake and a hardboiled egg in the dish as well, which I didn't eat really.
author: Megan K.

description:
Such a great hole in the wall Korean spot! I came here with my friends for some Korean one night because they're actually VIP members with Cocobang.  I let them do all the ordering and was so surprised at home HUGE all the portions were! The chicken wings were amazing, I even ate the shredded cabbage that came on the side to off set all the delicious flavor that was radiating from the chicken. 

The platter with the Korean BBQ fixings with pork belly was absolutely necessary. We also washed everything down with a pitcher of Mango Soju which had just the right amount of juice and the right amount of alcohol.  

I left feeling very satisfied, slightly buzzing and delighted that I got my Korean food fix! Although this location is a little out of the way for me, I would come here with my friends again to get my life. Korean food is my weakness!!
author: Kai S.

description:
This place is wonderful and super delicious! I was really hungry when I ordered food that night, which was good because I was able to sample multiple tasty options. I ordered the spicy rice cakes with ramen, cheese corn, and the fried chicken wings. Everything was so tasty, and my mouth is watering as I think about it right now. The spicy rice cake dish was nicely flavored, and definitely had that kick from the spices but was not overpowering. The rice cakes were cooked perfectly: nice and soft, but still with a chewy bite. The wings were nicely fried and filled with great flavor! Cheese corn was good as always!

I was also very pleasantly surprised by how awesome the service was here! They really did their best to accommodate us, and this left me with a smile on my face! Someone was always there to attend to our needs, which was wonderful! They even pulled up an extra chair for my friends to put their bags and items because they say that our area was getting a bit crowded! Definitely going that extra mile to help their customers made a huge impression on my friends and me. Great service with fantastic food will definitely keep my coming back here for more! I am so looking forward to my next visit, and I encourage everyone to stop by here!
author: Daniel H.

description: Been to almost every korean place in sf and this one by far has the best kimchi tofu soup and kimchi fried rice!
author: Paul C.

description:
This place is the best! The BEST! Be prepared to wait because it's small, but it's the BEST!

Fried chicken thing, Kalbi, cheese corn, kimchee fried rice, mango soju, for 3 of us . The BEST!
author: Nelson M.

description: The food here is amazing, recommend the fried chicken and the army stew.  Think it's on par or even better than most of places in Korea.
author: James K.

description:
A solid choice if you're in the area and don't mind waiting for a table or if other places are closed. The first time I went here was when it was new, before the soju girl posters and LED sign. The last time I went here was after a recent big group karaoke a few blocks down.

It's more of a young people, fried chicken, corn cheese vibe than grandma restaurants, but there are still some old-timey dishes if that's what you're looking for. Or if you're looking for cigarettes, ask the people who smoke right outside the door.

Fact: The eyeglasses and usually hatted waiter did some fashion modeling in years past. Book him for your clothing line.
author: Dan B.

description:
Two words: consistent drunchies.

Good go-to spot if you want a solid post-shenanigans meal that doesn't involve standard diner food! Kimchee fried rice, Fried chicken, Pan Fried Clear Noodle...fantastic options that are always there for me in times of late-night drunchie need. And the preparation? Presentation, flavor, and serving size are all very consistent.
author: Emmeline A.

description:
I came up to the city for a weekend getaway and my friends suggested we go here. So on my last night we headed to this little hole in the wall.

The first thing I notice was the size of the restaurant. It is pretty small; however, the food trumps its size.

Their chicken wings and bossam are everything! I enjoyed the fact that the wings were boneless, but still flavorful. As for the bossam, it is perfect medley of flavors and the pork hit the spot.

Also, shout out the David for the awesome service! He was very accommodating and helpful the whole time we were there.
author: Arianna C.

description:
My relationship with fried chicken is pretty strong. Even when I'm away, I have to get me some. I was staying at a nearby hotel and lo and behold - Cocobang! They're a friendly establishment that seems to be mom and pop ish. I can't confirm this but the place is tiny and the owners were working the restaurant.

I got the kim-chi fried rice along with the half order of the hot and tangy fried chicken. The kim-chi fried rice was decent and had bits of pre-packaged hot dog in it - strange twist but I enjoyed it.  Fried chicken were a mix of boneless meat, wings and a drumstick. I assumed they would all be wings but this kept me on my toes the whole time I was eating. It wasn't as spicy as I would've wanted but I can see how the amount of heat would affect others so I won't knock them for it.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Small spot but worth it for that fried chicken and kimchi pancakes. I have done pickup and dine-in but the chicken is better when it is fresh out so it is much more enjoyable to take a small group and sit down at the restaurant.

Great, friendly staff as well.
author: Kevin M.

description:
A friend brought me here as a "bribe" (she calls it a "thank you") for helping her unpack and move into her new apartment nearby.    We strolled in on a early Saturday evening and half the tables were filled.

Food:  Pretty solid Korean food, as we tried the Jap Chae, hot & tangy fried chicken and kal bi.  Portions are decent and the food arrived hot.  The chicken is quite good, but note that they are saucier than the ones served at SO or San Tung.  The beef and noodles were good too, but nothing that stood out to me.  The fried chicken is the star.

Service:  Our server was very friendly and helpful.  Our food arrived after a minimal wait and he made sure that our water glasses were filled.  

Location:   Situated in lower Nob Hill/Tenderloin, this place is easy to find.  Parking might be an issue depending on the date/time of arrival but there are parking garages/lots nearby as well as metered parking

Ambiance:  The restaurant space is somewhat small and dark.  Tables, which are packed together, are for small parties so I would not recommend this for large groups.  This is a great spot for pre or post bar-hopping, or a late night meal or snack.  Patrons were mostly on the young side and I would guess the majority of them were students. 

Great spot for Korean food if you are in the area.
author: Melissa L.

description:
#1 - I appreciate any food this good that's open as late as they are. Keep up the good work. 
#2 - The food is freaking good. 

I picked up a bibimbap that made my night after a long day and I'd do it again any other time of day.
author: Matthew B.

description: Where to begin. This has been my go to spot after work for a few years now. I stumbled upon this place in downtown SF in the Summer of 2012. Parking in this area is a bit of a challenge, but then again, I have been driving in the City since  high school And I used to live in the Tenderloin for a few years, so I know the parking game as it is. I go here because they are open late, so I don't need to rush over since I work late also. All the favorite Korean cuisine is here, along with all the beer and soju you can possibly have. ;) The staff here is awesome as well. You know you've been coming here too often when they know you by name and have given you a VIP status card. Their Kalbi , bulgogi, soon tofu, fried chicken, chap chae, etc. are all awesome. It is a crowded place almost every night of the week. They are that good, so bring your appetite and patience with you. It is worth it.
author: Andrew D.

description: I've been here twice and this visit was better than the last time. I always opt to go here because what place is open late. Yelp said 2am, but yesterday we arrived at 2:30am and stayed opened until 4am. We had a 20 minute wait so we were seated close to 3am. Beware, I went to the bathroom downstairs and it had the strongest chlorine smell. However, the food was so good, especially the Korean fried chicken. We order 1 full order, 1 half order, and Korean fried rice for $50 that fully fed 4. Last time we ordered their speciality plates and it was not good. Therefore, the safe bet is the KFC. The order also comes with cabbage with a special mayo type sauce. Sooo good! Would definitely recommend for a cheap late night meal.
author: Van N.

description: Awful service. mediocre food. There's no actual wait list. Preferred customers are seated first. Better Korean BBQ choices In the area like Zzan.
author: Allyn M.

description:
Good spot when you're drunk at night when everything else is closed...don't think I've been here sober.

Complaint is whenever I order my soodoobooooojiggae online they never give me rice. Even when I call and ask and put it in the directions. Who eats soondubu without rice??
author: Blake Z.

description: I had their Korean Army Stew. Honestly, my Korean friend made it better than them. It was $15 for a bowl that is about the size of a typical pho bowl, or smaller. Not worth it in my opinion, but it was worth a shot. My friend got a seafood tofu stew and it was even smaller than mine! But the short ribs rice plate was good! I believe there was a 10% discount for cash as well.
author: Christine C.

description: Was having happy hour drinks around the corner, I went here to eat dinner. Had a long wait even though we were told 20 mins. Didn't take in our reservation; however, another group was seated before us because they said that they had reservation. WTF. We asked them to reserve for us. This place is tiny, but they price of food is affordable. Upon this review I read it has a poor inspection score and maybe why their business and service was bad.  Their food is okay; there was nothing special about it. I got the bibimbap and kimchi soup. It wasn't that spicy. We also didn't get the collection of kimchi dishes serve table side that I'm used to whenever I go to a Korean restaurant. I don't think I will return or recommend anyone to eat at this place.
author: Roma C.

description: The food was really bad. We ordered the original fried chicken, the skin was not crispy and the meat had no taste, probably the worse Korean fried chicken I had and nothing compared to the ones I tried in Seoul. The fried calamari with noodle had too much sauce and taste was so so. The only thing is good is the peach soju
author: Ying C.

description: I think they have pretty decent fried chicken, but aside from that, their other food is average (bulgogi beef, kimchi fried rice, corn cheese, korean sausage). Good service though, but place is a little small.
author: Sui N.

description:
Korean fried chicken is always good. Why? Because they're usually double fried, creating an extra crispy layer of fried skin.. And helloooo, who doesn't love crispy chicken skin? You won't be seeing me raising my hand anytime soon.

So what's the verdict with Cocobang's fried chicken? Well, it's pretty darn good. In my opinion, their fried chicken with the hot and tangy sauce is more tasty than their original fried chicken recipe. The original recipe is just too plain jane for me. If I want regular fried chicken, I'll just go to Popeyes and buy myself a bucket. (Not that I have done that yet or anything...) Other notable dishes were: assorted seafood pancake and pan fried rice cakes with ramen.

Overall, it's not a bad place to go to get your Korean food fix on. But man, they are seriously lacking on their variety of ban chan. I adore Korean restaurants BECAUSE of the ban chan. This place only serves 3-4 different kinds of ban chan, which is simply not good enough for me.
author: Annie S.

description:
Korean late night eats FTW!

Food is yummy.  So  It's not the best but it gets the job done.  We had the BBQ wings (4/5), Mushroom tofu soup (3.5/5), and Kimchi fried rice (3.5/5).  The BBQ wings were awesome.  Everything else was pretty good.

TIPS:
-Open till 4 AM.  Alcohol stops serving at 2AM and you have to consume or dump it by that time.  They don't warn you about this either.  As such, we ordered alcohol at 1:50 and had a worker come by to inform us we have to finish our drinks before 2AM (this is after they served us mind you).  Not cool man.
-Huge line.  We left around 2:30 and there was a crazy line.
-Small inside.  Not ideal for large groups.  4-5 people and you should be ok.
author: Mike T.

description: It is located near Union Square. A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. We ordered fried chicken w/ hot & tangy sauce( half size), Kimchi fried rice and pan fried spicy calamari w/ somen. In addition, they offered us some pickles for free. Really delicious and authentic Korean food.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I tend to go a little overboard with the food here; I can't help myself, it's just too tasty. I mean, they may have even had to move my party of 2 to a four-top table to fit all the food and drinks we ordered....so, yeah, I think I might be in love with this place.

It's some of the best Korean late night food I've had in the city and I like it way better than Toyose (all the way in the Sunset) or 707 Sutter (right around the corner). 

Their hot and tangy fried chicken is so good that it has become difficult to try other items on their menu because we always have the chicken cravings once we enter the door. I've also tried the Kimchi Fried Rice (pretty good), Corn Cheese (so good), and the Spicy Tofu Stew (excellent). Top it off with Korean beer or soju cocktails, and it's a great late night dinner.

I just knocked off the one star because they do get really busy and service will be pretty slow because of it and they don't have a ton of variety in the menu or banchan. But, the staff is really nice even if they are a tad bit slow and understaffed.
author: Christina R.

description: This place is awesome! We had their sweet chicken I believe and it was delicious! What I do remember pretty well was the spicy rice cake with ramen! It was so soft and chewy! Definitely a place to come to! Will be stopping by next time with other friends.
author: Liseth M.

description:
I wanted to try "real" Korean food, made by Koreans and ran by then. Had 3* was veer iffy shit going but read the reviews. Dumb people complaining about portion and how small the place was.Sat down ordered right away.... bbq combo.. chicken and beef, spicy tofu, they threw two raw shrimps in and you could taste it. It was fishy. Food came quick. The side dishes were 3 good ones, two different cucumber and my favorite  fish cake. Yes the portion was okay :/ for the price. But overall food was good. 
Atmosphere was really chill and relaxed.
Korean music video played through a projection displayed right on to of the register wall.
Service was 10/10
I would recommend this place hands down the best  so far
author: Christina M.

description:
One of the few places that have solid Korean food in SF! Having lived right next to Ktown in NY, I missed the many 24 hour Korean restaurant options and their good food. But Cocobang has come closest in this city. It's a bit hidden as its nested near the edge of Nob Hill and when you go inside it has a bit of a dingy bar pub kind of feel. It's a tiny space so you may have to wait a bit at times. Usually it's popular during the late night hours after a night out. 

We ordered one of the combos. We had the spicy chicken, seafood tofu soup and the soju combo. The food was generous in proportion and was pretty good. It's a good place to grab late night food and of course if you're craving Korean food.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Omgomgomg don't even get me started on how amazing this place is. The food here is SENSATIONAL! My boyfriend and I were celebrating our eighth year anniversary and a couple of our friends wanted to have dinner with us. They were all feeling Korean BBQ so I found this spot and walked all the from Westfield mall. Let me tell you, it was worth the walk  My boyfriend and I shared the kimchi fried rice, the combo deal of chicken bulgogi and spicy ribs, and the clear noodles. Ooh baby! Best restaurant we ate at the whole four days we spent in the city! Thanks Cocobang! We'll definitely be coming back to visit!
author: Briana Nicole G.

description:
Ok I come here way too often and leave happy to just leave them hanging with 4 stars. Seriously, the visit has been weekly if not more. 

Serious default go-to for dinner, drinks, or late night grubs. 

The owner is always nice (can't believe I still haven't learned his name ) and tries his best to accommodate our always large group. Sometimes the wait is long, but they always find a way to make up for it - and even if they didn't, I'd forget all about the wait once the food comes out anyway.

One time we came late and the wait was going to be an hour. 
My friends: *complain about the wait*
Stranger outside: "oh it's so worth it. You have to try them."
Friend: "we know!!! We've been coming here before you ever did!!" *drunk rage*
Stranger: ".." 

Anyway, we have so much love for coco
author: Alexis P.

description: Visiting town. Ate here and now up till 4 am as my poor boyfriend is violently ill after getting food poisoning. Stay far, far, far away
author: Heather C.

description:
Super yummy, spicy Kim chee flavors in my mouth. Yummy plates that left a nice warm and full feeling in my stomach. The three of us shared 1) short rib and spicy pork combo, 2) Kim chee fried rice and 3) spicy tofu soup. Yum! 

Soup was spicy and meat combo savory and delicious. The service was perfect and a side of rice came with the combo plate. 

I'm down to eat here again. Super down.
author: Sean T.

description:
Officially my favorite restaurant in San Francisco for these reasons:

1. Great food. The best kimchi, Korean fried chicken, galbi (ribs), and chicken salad in the city. It's a good sign when even the staff take their friends to eat there.

2. Efficient, pleasant service. It's a tiny, popular place and the small staff work well as a team to minimize wait time. The food's ready in 15 minutes usually.

3. Open late.
author: Inigo M.

description: Coco bang very hipster  place right next to a massage parlor right next clubs.. I went there around 1 am the line was still out the door. I end up ordering to go and just eating outside the Korean BBQ was delicious maybe because I was high lol
author: Patterson N.

description: The last day of vacation and I have food poisoning stay away from this restaurant what a awful way to spend your vacation!!! I wish I could give this place  an -0 rating and the prices are too high
author: Mick W.

description:
KFC stands for Korean Fried Chicken. If you don't know what to order, definitely get the fried chicken. That is one of the things I would go for everytime. I definitely recommend the Hot and Tangy Chicken. Don't be intimidated by the name, it was not spicy. It was almost like a sweet and sour kind of taste, but with enough punch of flavor to make you have a conversation with your friend for 10 minutes about how delicious it was. I recommend getting the whole order of fried chicken if you aren't planning to get anything else. That is about a good 10-11 big pieces of fried chicken. What's the best part? 8/11 times, your chicken pieces will not have bones. THAT'S JUST FABULOUS! 

I usually try not to eat fried chicken, but if I do, it would be from either San Tung or Cocobang. Bigger question, which was better, San Tung or Cocobang? Honestly, I LOVE COCOBANG way more. Flavor profile for both are great, but Cocobang just does it a lot better. 

If you are into the chicken and beer culture, definitely give this place a try. I have seen this place fill up to its ears with people waiting in line. Try to get a reservation or just go early enough so that if you have to be on the list, you'd be near the top. I was at the bottom of the list and I think I have waited an hour only because some groups just gave up and left. What I love about their system is that, you don't write down your name on the list, you write down your phone number so that if there is a table for you, they will call you and wait for you to come back to the restaurant to seat you. That is a great system. So if you know you will be waiting in the hour, instead of waiting in the cold for an hour, you can just walk around Union Square or just that Lower Nob Hill area. They have cute little shops, like this coffee place Joy's Place if you want to warm up. If you want to doll up a bit, you can head down to the nail salon to get your nails done before you go back to the restaurant. 

I think the only sad part is that they only open for dinner and not lunch I believe, which is fine, but their chicken should be served during the day because it's that good.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
I LOVE COCOBANG!!! ...but this place is always packed!

It's tiny, but I really love the food and how they are SO NICE! Every time I've been here, there's been a long wait...so that kind of bums me out. Still, its a nice place for yo-ju and chickennnnn!

What to eat:
1. Fried Chicken
2. Army Stew - budae jigae!! - Mish mash of random stuff thrown into a pot and made into a stew. Its SO NOMS. Get rice. love me some rice! 
3. Ddokbokki - can't go wrong with rice cakes in spiciness.

What to drink:
1. Soju (if this is your thing...it is not mine)
2. YOJU! I love yogurt soju..but this place makes it noms-icle because it doesn't taste like soju at all.

Apparently they have karoke here too?!?! I did not karoke..but definitely heard SNSD here for the very first time..like 5 years ago. WEIRD, RIGHT?!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Strong contenders for the best fried chicken wings I've had in 3 years of living in SF.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Seafood ramen is the best after a
Night of drinking. Enjoyed the food And the atmosphere. Plus you an order a nice bottle
Of sojo to top off the night!
author: Aysia H.

description:
My friend and I had diner here on a Tuesday night. The estimated wait time was 20 minutes, however we were seated pretty quickly since the people ahead of us did not show up. Score! 

This is a very small restaurant. Really small! So big groups of soju-bombing isn't ideal. Staff were very sweet and attentive for a busy place. Looks like they had a lot of calls for take-out as well but they were able to manage. 

On the delicious foods. Our food came out pretty fast... maybe we were lost in our conversation but it was quick! We got the kimchi fried rice - this my dear is a must. It is just so good. The rice is moist, the egg was running, the kimchi was flavorful. My goodness... I love the texture. Second item: dubokki with veggies, I've become weak where I cannot handle a lot of spicy foods anymore. This was on the spicy end for me, but from what I hear from my friend this was a made a little sweeter since in Korea it would be much spicy with no hint of savory sweetness (I am bad with descriptions! Sorry!) The third and the final item was the Bulgogi hot pot. This soup stood out to us because it did not have any spice and surprisingly It was delicious. The meat was tender, there were bits of clear noodles. 

We were in and out within an hour and half.  Total was about ~45 with tip. Not bad at all. I would definitely come back if I am in the area.
author: Phuong V.

description:
A great time for 4 friends. Get a few pitchers of OB beer, and a few pitchers of Soju. Mango is our favorite. I recommend putting your name & number on the list and going across the street to Owl Tree to get a drink.

The good:

* Pitchers of OB & soju.
* Sliced pork foot.
* Corn & cheese.
* Regular fried chicken.
* Kimchi fried rice (add 2 extra eggs).
* Kpop playing on a projector.

The not so good:

* The tangy fried chicken is a bit too sweet.
* The corn & cheese is good but a bit too sweet.
author: Grayson K.

description: Stumbled upon this place after a long day out while we visited San Fran. The restaurant is pretty small but the food had big flavors! We didn't get the chicken, but we got the bulgogi and kalbi. With endless kimchi (my favorite) and some pickled veggies I really enjoyed. All very reasonably priced. If I lived any where near this place I would definitely be a regular.
author: Ariana F.

description:
Came here with a friend after a late night of bar hopping on a Saturday night (well, by the time I got here it was past like 1:15ish AM on a Sunday). Let's start with that. This place has crazy hours. And by crazy, I mean crazy amazing if you've been drinking. Open until 2AM and 4AM? That's ridic. Espesh for SF where everything basically closes when the sun goes down it seems.

This place is pretty small. If I had to guess, maybe like a total of 10 tables. Be prepared to wait a bit if you come here with a party larger than say 2. Me and my buddy had to wait a solid 30 minutes coming here super late.

They had a pretty expansive menu with all the Korean staples. We just got some ramen, short ribs (obvi), and then my buddy got the dried cuttlefish (yes, the one that smells like a fish market at the end of the day). Ramen was legit. Short ribs were legit (not overdone). And the dried fish by the look on my friend's face was good.

Hard to gauge how great something is when at the moment in your night you could and would eat anything, but I'd say I'd def. come back here. Some may say it's hard to screw up short ribs, but believe you me, I've had some POS short ribs, and these were good. Between the two of us we spent like maybe $45ish - not bad. Service was pretty quick on everything.
author: Shawn B.

description:
Maybe I'll give Cocobang one more chance but I was very unimpressed last time we visited. Here are the strikes against this Korean spot from our last visit:

- our favorite server Sean is no longer there. He always was so welcoming and friendly. It's so sad that he's gone!
- Cocobang is a fairly small spot and there was a table of about 15 that was finished eating for over 20 minutes but not  budging even though there were a ton of people waiting. I asked the waiter if he could ask them to free up the table and he said he wouldn't - they could sit as long as they wanted to.
- usually the kimchee and other free appetizers are delicious and refilled generously. On this trip, we had to keep asking for more and they didn't taste quite right.
- our order was not 100% correct even though it wasn't a huge order
- the waiter was not particularly friendly

At 2 AM, you don't want your meal to take forever and this time it did. Between a long wait and then an unsatisfactory eating experience, I'm not inclined to rush back. Cocobang, bring back Sean and your former amazingness please!
author: Meghan P.

description:
A+ for drunchies. - 1 star because WHAT KIND OF KOREAN PLACE DOESN'T GIVE YOU FREE SIDE DISHES???

We got a ton of food. Spicy BBQ Ribs, Spicy Chicken, Army Soup (L), Seafood Ramen , Kimchi Fried Rice. It was all really delicious. The Army Soup was my favorite. Everything had solid Korean flavors and while nothing was super mind-blowing and different from other Korean food that I've had, I still enjoyed our meal here.

Sadly they don't serve soju after 2AM so we couldn't try the Yogurt Soju.

We had a group of 10 and paid $14 each for a massive feast. We waited about 30 min for a table at 2AM.
author: Mel C.

description:
Saw this might be a fun place for late night munchies so headed here after drinking. Small, only 4-5 tables, and a huge tv screen in the back playing what looked like Korean "American idol." No one noticed we even walked in, had to go find someone in the back who promised we were "next"- which apparently meant another 20-30 minute wait, we found out. Everyone who walked in seemed to know each other...and tables just became filled with people who seemed intent on staying forever. 

When we were finally seated we tried the hot and tangy fried chicken. Complimentary Kim chee was good. Also got a beer- WAY too much beer in the large for two people, forewarning. Fried chicken was neither hot nor tangy...more sweet. And seemed almost tempura fried which we didn't expect. Other stuff on the menu seemed overpriced for what his place is so didn't order anything else. 

All in all wil definitely never return, and unless you are already a regular or know the folks who work here, I don't recommend. if you absolutely have a hankering for late night Korean, carry it out...and skip the fried chicken.
author: Farheen Q.

description: This is a cute neighborhood place. We came here for dinner and we ordered the chicken bulgogi and BBQ short rib combo along with the fire spicy chicken for dinner. You know the food will be spicy because the waiter brings you a pitcher of water rather than just a glass. :-) Also, you will need to tell the waiter the degree of spiciness of your dish otherwise it may be a little too spicy as we found out with the fire spicy chicken....Yes, I know...the name says it all but nevertheless :-). Would come back again
author: A K.

description: I love Korean food, but this is probably the worst Korean food experience I have ever had. The bibimbap was so cold that I don't think even the rice as put into the bowl warm. The service was non-attentive. The waiter did not come once to check in after the food was delivered. A pitcher of water was included so they didn't have to check in for more water. I would not recommend if you want a true Korean experience.
author: Jaclyn F.

description:
Good for late-night Korean eats. 

Definitely one of the hallmark Korean fried chicken and beer joints in the city.

 Their sweet and spicy yangnyum fried chicken was actually pretty good. Their side radish was not be best I've had, but alright. Their banchan side dishes were hit or miss: some good and some a little bit off. I also tried their rice cake and dumpling soup, and it was fine. 

Service was attentive and friendly. The restaurant is small, so I am assuming it can get full at peak hours.

Recommended!
author: Augusto T.

description:
2 visits in 2 weeks. 

This place is great! Really good late night food that's fairly priced. Expect a wait (anywhere from 5-25mins in my case), but it's worth it.

CocoBang doesn't pretend to be your Korean grandma's house, so adjust your expectations if that's what you're looking for. It does however have great food and excellent speed of service. The staff there are super friendly, and good with K-food novices like my friends. The atmosphere is trendy, young and energetic. The food is on point and is a great way to end (or start??) a night out. Very yummy.  I recommend the fire spicy chicken and a bottle of Soju for the group!
author: Nina N.

description:
Korean Fried Chicken!  It's the second place I've tried, and it's better than Aria because their chicken actually has skin on it and isn't just dried up lumps of batter.  I got the sweet sauce chicken, it's really more savory with garlic :)

The salad on the side has way too much dressing!  But otherwise, it's a good pairing.  Some of the banchan, shredded radish tasted a little funny/weak.

The oden wasn't very good and had a weird taste the next day because they put jalapenos in the broth and it bittered the oden.

10% if you pay Cash!
author: Alice S.

description:
Called in a take out order for the spicy chicken with ddukbokki (rice cake) and cheese corn.  Based on the reviews, I had assumed that the order would take an hour and was surprised when the restaurant informed me it would be ready in 15 minutes (which it was!).  

Loved the ddukbokki with spicy chicken.  The ddukbokki was my favortie part of the meal.  It had the perfect texture and was covered in a sweet, spicy sauce.  The spicy chicken was also good.  I was NOT a fan of the cheese corn however.  Loaded with mozarella, you would think that they couldn't go wrong but the corn was too sweet .  It tasted like canned corn mixed with a lot of sugar with mozarella on top.

Loved the late night hours.  I can't think of a better place to eat at 3 am in the morning after a night out.  Tried it a few times while staying in the area would definitely recommend if you are looking for a late night after-party spot.
author: Linda H.

description: love this place open late!
author: Alonda P.

description: Was out with friends late nearby and got so hungry for a bite at 2am. Thankfully Cocobang was open. I got the half order spicy tangy fried chicken and another friend got the fire spicy chicken on the iron plate. I wish the fried chicken was more spicy but it was exactly what I needed! Crispy chicken with a nice light coat of sauce right off the stove. Wish there were knives though because hard to take a clean bite of the meat and after 3-4 piece the sauce and the cabbage salad dressing gets too sweet. Overall, amazing and will be back!!
author: Christina H.

description: They refused to serve us while they gonna close in 40 mins later. I mean it's ok but it's really not professional. I guess it's ok if they think they have too much to earn. So yeah be prepared for bad service because they don't even care.
author: Crystal N.

description: If you're looking for some good Korean street food definitely give Cocobang a try. Its a hole in the wall restaurant conveniently located around downtown, that serves some bomb Korean style fried chicken. They're open late so great for late night hang outs.
author: Charity H.

description:
To be honest this place isn't even the best tasting Korean place out there, but it does do one thing that surpasses them all. NIGHT GRUBBIN.

If you are looking for a place that taste like gold when you are drunk, but still want it to be exotic this is the place to go. Their food is actually pretty good, but people usually come here when they are done with going out to the bars or finished clubbing.

Here are some things to try:
1. Chicken wings. They have really good chicken wings here.
2. Kimchi fried rice is one of the best i've ever tasted. They make a mean kimchi fried rice.
3. Soups are always a safe bet although watch out, it can get pretty spicy.

Cons:
1. They will take away your SOJU AT 2AM! DRINK IT ALL BEFORE THEN.
2. Ask for all your stuff prior because getting their attention again is pretty hard.
3. The line sucks. Sometimes you wait for over an hour if you are not lucky. Sometimes you wait for 5 minutes or you don't even wait at all. It all depends on your luck.
author: Nathan L.

description:
I had a great time with my friends from various countries.
I liked the food and one of the staff looked like a korean actress Kimsarang. I think she's the reason why the restaurant always has a lot of people.
author: Minseon G.

description:
This was a great late night find in SF walking distance from our hotel! We had eaten an early happy hour meal and we're having a hard time finding something to eat late.  We got there and there was a line out the door! We decided to wait it out, and it was a great idea!
Had the bulgogi salad and the fried chicken and shared both.  We were really happy with both of our choices, and in fact, could go back and eat it again now!
It's really tight in there, so you'll be sitting close the the table next to you! 
Korean music videos play on the wall for entertainment as you dine. 

Would recommend.
author: Danielle D.

description:
Went there on a saturday late afternoon with a friend. Environment is casual and slightly trendy with a black  shade theme. There is kpop music being played in the background and a huge screen showcasing MVs and korean shows. I guess a great location if you want to be immersed in Korean entertainment and while eating your favorite korean dish.

Ordered the Tofu Soup and Seafood pancake and split it with my friend .Portions was a bit slim but what korean restaurant in SF is not. Taste was also just like any other SF korean restaurant; average. 

Though what sets Cocobang apart from other Korean restaurants in the city is the atmosphere and very courteous staff. They came to our table and asked us how the food was and even dropped in for some small chit chat until things got really busy during dinner time. 

To sum it up, food is good enough, priced mediocre, but staff is cool.
author: Jude N.

description: Your servers are a bunch of con artists working for it. You really don't have change for a $20? I'm gonna keep talking shit about your business till you come correct . Loser ass con-artists.
author: PJ L.

description: This place is great for the 1am dinner, which I've had many times here. Most of the food I've tried isn't great, but there is one holdout which is amazing. Get the fried chicken, it's off the hook. Pretty much everything else isn't that great, but I have dreams about the chicken. I have tried bimbim bop, bolgogi and neither is that good. The kimchee soup is decent too.
author: Jonah K.

description: The best dish here is the soft tofu soup. It's really tasty and it never fails me. The fire burning chicken is like the most spiciest dish they have here but it's not spicy for me. The spicy taste is really delicious. And I asked it to come without veggies since the other time the whole dish was just 75% veggies and 25% chicken. (Note: I have a really high tolerance for spicy food but most of my friends could not eat more than one piece). Also, don't bother getting soju here. We ordered three peach soju and the first one was pretty good and not as watered down. The second one was extremely watered down and the third one was just plain peach juice. But I really love this place and I will come back.
author: Pana P.

description:
A decent korean restaurant open till 2am on weekdays and 4am on fri/sat/sun? I'm sold! The restaurant itself is quite small and cramped, but it's really not so bad since the guys working there are really friendly and make you feel right at home.

Some of the dishes I really enjoyed here are:
- Kimchee fried rice
- Cheese corn
- Spicy fried chicken
- thick chewy noodle soup (good substitution for pho)

There are not very many good korean places to eat in this general area, so I'm glad I stumbled upon this small restaurant. Perfect for those late night cravings, you won't be disappointed!
author: Angela K.

description: high vermin problem so everything you're eating is gonna get you sick. stop eating here it's NASTY.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I have been eyeing Cocobang ever since I moved to the city 8 months ago. I instantly knew I had to eat there as soon as I saw rabokki (spicy rice cakes with ramyun noodles) on the menu. I can't believe I waited so long to finally discover the cure to my Korean bar food craving! This is not your typical Korean barbecue restaurant. This is the place you go to if you want delicious drinking food to accompany your beer or soju.

I was very excited to try the rabokki. It was a little saucier than I'm used to, but the flavor and spiciness was exactly what I was looking for! It was a generous portion of soft and chewy tteok, ramyun noodles, fishcake, veggies, and a hard-boiled egg. Kalbi is another must order dish whenever I eat Korean food. Their spicy kalbi was very delicious.  A little sweet, a little spicy, and very tender short rib meat. We also ordered the cheese corn. Cheese and sweet corn...mmm. So simple, yet so delicious! 

The place is pretty tiny, so be prepared for a wait during peak times. Service was quick and friendly. I will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu!
author: Kris T.

description: The chicken is amazing! Love the sweet sauce and the chicken was the right amount of crispy. Reasonably priced and large portions.
author: Danielle W.

description: The food was utterly amazing, the service not so good but its a must if you're into different food.
author: Gus A.

description: I loved this place! Open late, really good food, easy quick bite after drinks with friends in the area!
author: Hannah P.

description:
Waited a while to be seated on a Wednesday night, and finally got a table after a mix up with the servers promising two parties the next table. 

We ordered the: 
-cheese corn: OK, kinda what you expect 
-baby clam miso hot pot: this was really strange, not what we expected at all in flavor and content, very few clams... would not recommend
-friend chicken: half spicy half not... these are boneless wings that are fried and sauced. Honestly not the best I've had but they're not bad. 
-pan fried rice cakes in spicy sauce: super chewy rice rolls, I think this was everyone's favorite.
-rice cake soup with potsticker: nice light soup dish, this was my favorite. 

Banchan was paltry, service was okay.
author: Linda L.

description:
Koreans have a rich and storied tradition of getting drunk and eating food. This is the ideal place to do the latter.

We had the Burning Fire Spicy Chicken BBQ, a turbocharged version of what is normally sold as spicy chicken bulgogi. It was as spicy as advertised, with a level of heat that cannot come from the normal chili pepper. No, this was spiced either with a capsaicin extract or with a more muscular pepper like habanero.

We also ordered Rice Cake Soup with Pot Sticker, and it was a bit different from the traditional style, sweeter and darker, but still delicious.

They get really busy at night, and service can be spotty, so you may have to remind your server to get you that second bottle of beer. It's worth it.
author: Cory K.

description: Awesome fried chicken! Would recommend getting an assortment of different types if it's your first time. Goes great with beer/soju. Tofu soup is actually tasty too. Parking can be tough in the area and may need to wait awhile to get seated, but definitely worth checking out!
author: Cindy W.

description:
So I guess if you are drunk or stoned at 1AM, this would get 4+ stars but as a Korean Restaurant, not so much.  The website  and the actual place have not much in common.  They have great marketing.

Staff is friendly and they humped it.  Place is super small and I waited for a table of 1 for a while.  Will come back to super small at the end.

Menu has a good variety.  But their prep capabilities are fairly small.  The thing about Korean communal eating is the Ban Chan.  This was not that very good or creative.  If you are only going to have 3 items, make the distinctive.  This was mostly soy sauce, sesame seed oil and gochujang.  I actually had to ask for Kimchi and to be honest, it was the very best part of the meal.  If they make their own, that rocked.

Bibimbop - they do not do dolsot.  The veggies were really cold over rice that was overcooked and a tiny bit of meat.  The cold veggies and the sunny side up egg, not sure that was exactly a good idea but I did.  The vegetables were a bit nondescript.  Anyhow, it was ok, but really just OK.

Back to the small place, be prepared for everyone to hear your conversation.  I was 2 feet from a table of 3 that were discussing the merits of THC in Marijuana varietals and the positive effects of mushrooms on individuals with personality disorders.  I am not here to judge, gotta love San Francisco.  I wonder why they had some much food on their table?

I have had better.  I will a diner at 1AM over this one.
author: Tom K.

description: I love this place. It started off as just an after the bar, drunchies stop, but has made it's way into my regular dinner rotations ( I crave their hot and tangy fried chicken at least once a week).  There is usually a wait to be seated but they are cool about taking your number down and calling when your table is ready (I usually head across the street for a drink at owl tree).  I like the casual atmosphere and the music videos playing.   The servers are always nice even when they are slammed and they keep my banchan flowing.  My favorite dishes are obviously the hot and tangy fried chicken, but I also love the army soup and pan fried rice cakes with spicy sauce.  My husband really likes the corn cheese as well.  Whenever we have a visitor from out of town we always make sure to bring them by for some great late night eats!
author: Nicole C.

description: This place is awesome! Their fried chicken is off tha hook .... I have been to this place many times and I keep coming back. The atmosphere, reasonable prices, quick service certainly deserve 5 stars ... Sean and Ray are great and funny dudes . This place is open until 2 am and trust me , you wont be disappointed with your final bill.
author: George B.

description: all the reviews about their fried chicken are inflated. Or written under the prolonged influence of booze.  I still prefer KFC's fried chicken
author: Alice Z.

description:
Right around the corner from Ruby Skye and open until 4am, Cocobang is the place to be for drunken munchies!

I have tried a few of the dishes here and they are all amazing!

I love starting off with the cheese corn.  Im pretty sure it's just canned corn and melted cheese on top but when you're drunk, its amazing.  The Clear Noodles with Vegetables and the Seafood Pancakes are a MUST when you visit this restaurant.  The noodles are so good, it even gets non veggie eaters to devour the whole thing!  The seafood pancake is perfect.  I've gone to multiple places that either had too little batter or too much, but the portions of each here is perfect.

I've also tried the wings which were a little too spicy for me but I love the sweetness it comes with.  The short rib bbq comes out in a sizzling plate, its delicious but careful it's HOT.

The pricing is GREAT with the portions of each entree.  The only bad thing is this restaurant is pretty small and I have waited about 40 minutes on a few occasions for a  table.
author: Jessica n.

description:
This is a great late night grub spot!

Love the korean fried chicken and that scallion salad is soooo good!

Sometimes there is a wait but its worth it! The fried chicken, kimchi fried rice and yogurt soju are all super delish. Don't forget the corn and cheese!
author: Christine W.

description:
Definitely a nice, cheap, reliable, and relatively simple place to go out if you don't feel like being too fancy - great for a little drinking too!

This place is a hole in the wall for its atmosphere and vibe! Very comfortable and home-y, yet loud and classy - almost divey with a splash of intimate. 4 stars for this.

Fire spicy chicken, Korean short rib BBQ, and bimbibob was delicious! 3 stars for that.

The food tasted well - leaning more towards fast food but don't get me wrong, this place is definitely tasty! By no means is this place top quality food, but it's a joint you must try for what it is.
author: J J.

description: One of my favorite places to go on a Friday night. Perfect late night place for some spicy food, yogurt soju and beer. Almost everything is good on the menu. However I tend to order green onion chicken, spicy pork, army soup or kimchi fried rice.
author: Ivy J.

description: Came here in 2015 and left wanting more. Came back to San Francisco the next year and again this please is delicious. If you looking for a nice intimate place with great food and great prices, this is the place to come.
author: Oscar H.

description:
My boyfriend and I recently discovered Cocobang and after our first visit, we were sold! The service has consistently been awesome. The staff is efficient, incredibly friendly, and they definitely put in the effort to make sure your dining experience is enjoyable. 

Everything about Cocobang is pretty much great. The food is delicious, the environment/ambience is casual, youthful, hip. I recently traveled to Seoul, South Korea and Cocobang brought me back to the lively and happening late night restaurants of Seoul. There's music playing (K-pop), constant chatter, and people drinking soju and makgeolli over delicious Korean food. 

We started with the complimentary side dishes: kimchi, bean sprouts, and fish cake and then had the Chicken Bulgogi and Spicy Soft Tofu Soup. The chicken dish was served on a sizzling stone plate and it consisted of chicken and vegetables covered in a sweet and savory sauce. The tofu soup was served boiling hot in a stone bowl and was delicious. The soup had a satisfying savory taste and the tofu and meat portion was generous.

If you're looking for yummy Korean food in the downtown area, look no further! : D

Another plus is that they're open late!
author: Monica T.

description:
Love, love, loooove their fried chicken!! Of all the Korean chicken places I've been to, Cocobang is the best place to satisfy my fried chicken craving and have it washed down with a nice glass of OB. I like my chicken saucy and Cocobang makes it juuuuust right. I always get half hot & tangy chicken and the other half sweet sauce marinated chicken. Kalbi, tofu, and everything else is average bar food, nothing extraordinary. Pajeon was good. The Army Soup was way too spicy for my taste (I'm not a spicy person).

There could be a line if you arrive during peak hours. After writing this I feel like walking there after work now...
author: Cheri S.

description:
My friends and I stumbled on cocobang when the (now closed) kare-ken couldn't serve us since they ran out of food. One of our friends likes Korean food so we said "why not?"

It's since been a place we come back to once very few months to a lot of enjoyment. Cocobang sells itself as a late night eats sort of place but it has great food and great drinks. It's a place you're meant to go as a group you share dishes with rather than order your own thing.

Their soju cocktails have good flavor without being too syrupy. Their fried chicken is my favorite in the city (beating out Little Skillet and other establishments by a wide margin). I strongly recommend doing a half-half whole fried chicken of spicy and sweet. Their kimchi fried rice is good and you really can't go wrong with most of their other entrees.

I've brought a friend who's lived in Seoul for a year and it's his favorite Korean place in SF (over Yakini-Q, Toyose, and 707).

It's a small place so it's good to get their around opening or you'll be waiting a while.
author: Rajiv P.

description: Very good. We got the cheese corn (interesting and good), kimchi fried rice (good but could have used more kimchi), sweet and spicy fried chicken (delicious), and green onion fried chicken (very nice). The place is small so it gets crowded and cozy. The service is ok and you need to flag down people for service. Good location. Parking garage next door is very expensive. One problem is that they take away your alcohol even if you order before last call and they don't tell you before hand that they will take your drinks away 10 minutes after ordering.
author: J. W.

description: Great food. Small location so you will have to wait during busy meal periods. They do have food to go so that is an option. Went here on a rainy day for the army soup and bibimbap. Delicious
author: Steven B.

description:
I love, LOVE, L.O.V.E soup. Any kind of soup. Soup is literally soul food. The more flavors and spices, the better. It's why I love Cocobang. I love their spicy, steamy big portion soups. A bit on the salty side but that's expected. I've been there a few times and one time, they were so busy, the girl waitress had to take my number down. Although they forgot to call me back, they are super nice every time... so I forgive them for now;). It's a cute, cozy place perfect for a casual dinner and they are open late. They play Korean pop music projected on the wall all day and night. It's entertaining to watch so grab a seat that allows you to see, but warning - it can be very loud. 

Prices are decent, food comes out quick, and you never feel rushed despite the busy surrounding. Very good place to check out.
author: Deborah V.

description:
My wife and I love trying random places in the city. We felt like Korean food out of nowhere and wanted something warm or hot because of the cold weather lately. Hopped on yelp and found this place, so why not try it out!

Walked in and was able to be seated right away. They gave us a giant carafe of water and menus. The carafe was a good touch because we are water drinker extraordinaires. We sat and browsed the menu, but of course referred back to yelp. We ended up ordering the Spicy Tofu with beef, the sweet and spicy fried chicken, and seafood ramen. 

There's a big screen above the cash register area playing K pop videos and the music blaring. We sat closer to the front of the restaurant so the music wasn't too loud. The seating is a little crammed so we were very close to some guys sitting by the window talking business and throwing gigantic numbers out about the new worth of social media companies... that's how close we were. We asked for forks when the waiter brought out our food.

First the chicken came out. It was pretty good. For a half order they gave us about 6 big pieces with cabbage and dressing on the side of the plate. The chicken itself was flavored pretty well. The sweet sauce on top was a little too sweet but it was still good. We ate all of it. A MAJOR plus was that only one of the 6 or 7 chickens had bones the rest was boneless. Awesome! After about 10min more our main entrees came out. The spicy beef tofu had a really good flavor and came out in a small hot pot. Loved it. Good flavor and enough to make anyone full. The seafood ramen was just as good. Served in a real pot brought me back to my days of living cheap and eating ramen out of the pot I boiled it in... nostalgic. The seafood ramen had clams and muscles. They tasted good enough that I had to eat each one. There was also shrimp in there as well. The size of the pot was slightly bigger than the pot the tofu came in. 

In the end we LOVED it. A bit noisy with the music blaring and the close proximity of the tables on the right side of the restaurant made it feel cozier than the booth seating on the left side of the restaurant. 

We definitely would come back and recommend to people as a go to spot!
author: Jay V.

description:
I don't understand why people complain that this place isn't "legit" Korean food. It's supposed to be Korean bar-type food which is typically more Western. If you're looking for authentic Korean cuisine, I suggest going somewhere else. 

Cocobang has a nice vibe, serves good food (food comes out nice and quick), and has great service. Their portions are pretty generous and there's a large variety of dishes to choose from. I like that this place is convenient for non-Koreans - they make sure all their customers feel comfortable with ordering!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This place is hopping! The kimchi hot pot and the fried chicken were delicious! Great place to go at the wee hours of the night!
open till 4 am on the weekends
author: Sara S.

description: Such amazing dinner! We went in a group so i got to try a couple of items. The rice is amazing, some said it was a bit spicy but i like my food on the spicer end. I tried Fish Cakes for first time and boy were they great! If i lived here, i would come often.
author: Nicolette R.

description:
I was drunk and everything was amazing!!!

I was in a party of 4 and we were lucky to not have to wait for a table. I don't remember much, but I do remember that we ordered the fried chicken with the scallion coleslaw and it was awesome. Just be sure to bring some mints or gum.
author: Alfonzo J.

description: Went to union square for ice skating the week before Xmas with my little family but our schedule skate time was 10pm. Arrived to our hotel at 8pm and decided to go out for dinner. OMG, wait times were crazy right around where we were staying. Decided to walk about 2-3 blocks out and found Cocobang. Wait time was 15-20mins so we said yes. Got seated les than 10mins. Ordered and got our food...SooooOooo good!! My two girls ate their plates clean! Best Korean food we've ever had! Must try if your close by! We had a few dishes and I can't remember them but 4/5 dishes were delish!!
author: Maisie W.

description:
Not a bad place for late night comfort food.  

Pros: bimibap was alright. The spicy tofu soup was delicious. The galbi was my favorite. 

Cons: fried chicken was overly fried with too much oil. I tasted more oil than I did chicken and overly sauced. 

Overall: save this place for a late night eats option only.
author: Anita A.

description:
Great place to go when you have been out and about drinking and are ready to end the night. 

Very small kickback restaurant..

Grub food.  The kimchi rice with egg is absolutely a must! The meat was delicious!
author: N A.

description:
Here's a review from someone who wasn't there late-night after drinking; in fact, we ate there at 6pm.

Ok, so it's not Manna, but it's pretty close.  The chicken (according to my sweetie) was excellent, and comes with Korean cole slaw.  I had soondubu with seafood, which made for a full meal and was spicy with a nice mix of shrimp and clams.  The clear noodles were good as well.

If you're not drinking, it's pretty affordable; was about $17 each for us.  I'd eat here again.  Warning, though: there's a wait for the place even at 6pm.
author: Josh B.

description:
We are here the other night. It is a busy little place, so I recommend making reservations. The staff were very friendly and our food came out fast. 
Overall I give it four stars, because their menu is limited and somewhat confusing. Great food, great staff, great little hide-away restaurant :)
author: Julia E.

description: Their korean style YangNyum Chicken was similar to the original korean style.. I liked it.. the salad came with the chicken was very good.. side dishes were good, too.. I wanted to try CholMyun, RaPokKi, etc... they all looked good..
author: Sua Y.

description:
Delicious spot for great Korean food! 
Nothing fancy, just the usual Korean fare, cooked up fresh and quick. Affordable-most entrees $10-15, and it has a a casual, local, friendly vibe. 
Would definitely go back!!!
author: Kelsey K.

description:
I really enjoy coming to Cocobang!  Sometimes, you'll need to wait about 15-20 minutes for your seating, but they are always pretty honest about how long it will take to get you seated.  Also, the waiter takes down your phone number and conveniently calls you 5 minutes before your table is ready.  This gives you plenty of time to waddle over to Owltree (bar next door) to have a few beverages before dinner.

I really like sitting in the booths.  It feels like you have your own table service as you order Chum Churum and OB.  The waiters are all very accommodating.  Plus, this place is open super late in case you are super hungry after a fun night out.  "It never fails" as my friend and I say!

There are 3 main things I like to order here:

1. ARMY SOUP

My friend introduced this to me.  It's literally like kimchee chigae but with plenty more ingredients like spam, hot dogs, ramen noodles, and assorted veggies!  It's great on a cold night in SF.  Also, don't order much more if you're ordering the Army Soup.  It's huge, especially with the banchan on the side.

2. SPICY PORK

Yep, their Spicy Pork is really good.  It tastes pretty standard, but the environment at Cocobang is very fun, which makes eating the food fun.  I've traveled to Korea and this definitely lives up to the Korean BBQ you'd find there.

3. SEAFOOD PANCAKE

Woohoo!  I really enjoy the pancake here.  I like it when they don't put TOO much seafood, or too much dough.  That's why Cocobang does this really well.  The sauce is also very tasty.

Overall, don't expect the food to be the best Korean food you've ever had in the universe, but expect good service, a fun time, and a great environment to hang out.
author: Andrew H.

description: I Love CocoBang! This place is so Korean what with the K-pop music videos being played all the time and the crowd of Koreans that are always there. Their GARLIC FRIED CHICKEN is the BOMB but not on the menu so you have to be sure to ask for it specifically. They forgot my side of rice on a to go order once but I blame myself for not checking. Still my favorite restaurant at Union Square area.
author: Everette R.

description:
Love this place!!! I live a block away and have walked by before but never went in thinking it was a teeny tiny place. But it's really not that tiny. I liked the vibe of the place. The server was super cute and friendly. Most of the diners were Korean.. or Asian.. I'm not gonna say I can tell which Asian is which yet haha. So that was cool, it's always a good sign. Gives the place an authentic feel.

Ordered the spicy wings for appetizer.. yuuumo! Perfectly cooked, crunchy like I like. Good taste also. Then we shared kimchi fried rice and order of beef bulgogi. The fried rice was spicy heaven goodness. Bulgogi was good. They also serve soju so next time we'll try that. And there will def be a next time!
author: Vol T.

description:
OH I WILL BE BACK!!E

I went here with my husband last night and it was his first time having korean food. I have had korean food one other time at 707 Sutter, and Cocobang was even better!

We got a combo plate that came with burning fire chicken, spicy calamari, assorted kimchi soup and a bottle of soju which we upgraded to Yogurt soju.

IT WAS SO MUCH FOOD!!! the bill ended up being $55 which is pretty reasonable for the amount of food we got! 

We were also warned twice how spicy the food would be and boy was it! IT WAS INCREDIBLE! I honestly think Korean food is now my favorite food! It had such bold spicy flavor and the yogurt soju was AMAZING! Everything here was great! I cannot wait to eat here again!
author: Brittini S.

description:
I live right across the street from this place and have eaten here at least 10 times almost always takeout. 

Its a small place and always busy which gives you hope. If nothing else for me it's at least convenient.

Tonight when I went here I placed my order for take out and was told -- not asked -- to go wait out side. 

This is the first time anywhere a sit down restaurant small or otherwise took my money and said go out into the cold.
