I can understand its a small place and I wouldn't have been bothered if it was at least a request with an apologetic attitude but it was not. 

I went out without complaint but when my food was delivered I raised how this was handled rudely and was told that despite my past experiences this is what they do.

The realty is the food here is at best OK and the service has never been great.

I would say if your craving Korean and this is the only place going I would still consider it but not otherwise.
author: Ryan H.

description: Chicken pot, fried chicken, noodle with clams (bajirak kalgooksoo) are the best menus. Japchae isn't that good. Way too greasy. Always super packed with people. Slow service, not really satisfied with the service attitude, but a good place to go for late night food.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Beer + Chicken! That's all you need to know!
This is a great place for people who just want to drink and eat!
Is a fun place to be at with friends. Is a bit small but that is usually the space around downtown SF. Workers there are very polite and service is always good. They are alway there as if i needed anything  from time to time. Get their fire cheese chicken! You won't regret!
author: Timmy G.

description:
I did it again...I told myself I would eat clean this week...but....

The thought of hot sizzling korean food is so appealing at 3am!

I had the kimchee pancake this time and the half fried chicken with sweet spicy sauce. SO good!!  

I love how they ask you what you want to eat while you're waiting and the minute you are seated the food comes out steaming and ready to be devoured :P

I really do love this place! devil in disguise for my waistline :P
author: Selina W.

description:
It's just as loud and dark and crazy as Zzan across the street, but at least their takeout is faster. They tend to be a bit pricier though, but I think their quality is better. 
I wish I could sit down to eat one of those days, but the college pub atmosphere with the loud music and dark lights just makes me run away.
author: Sera L.

description: Late night hunger. I never eaten Korean food and my friends just decided randomly to come here. I think their portions are filling. I love their soup dumplings and I think it was BBQ pork or beef. I would go again if I have midnight hunger again.
author: Kaida C.

description:
2.75 stars
Just a chill late-night Korean eatery. My friends and I usually come here to drink, but we get food here and there whenever we get our usual drunchies. 

The place is kinda small and kinda on the ghetto-er side, but for late night grabs and cravings for Korean food, i'd say they got the best location. You get off of the 38 bus on to Van ness and it's right around the corner. Parking is a BITCH btw. You'll never find parking on a friday or saturday night.

Food is typical and mediocre, but it's not bad. I think most late-night Korean places serve the same typa food like dduk boki, yang yum chicken, etc. Can't ever go wrong. Everything's super saucey, which is perfect for drunchies. I'd say go for the soup when you're super drunk tho!
author: Joyce L.

description:
This place is open till late night which is good for some people who wants to go out.
Whenever i get off of work late, i come here grab a beer with late night snack. The food is amazing and good price. Service is fast. Every servers are very nice.
author: Iris C.

description:
Went to Ruby Skye on Friday night and after a night of heavy drinking we were famished. We ended up yelping and finding this particular Korean restaurant which was open until 4am. Wonderful. We ended up over estimating how hungry we were and we got an order of the spicy chicken wings, kimchee fried rice, bulgogi, and also the short ribs. the food was all decent. Pretty good for late night in the Union Square area. I would probably come here again if I happen to be hungry in the area after like 12am. 

The service was really friendly and prompt, and the atmosphere had a good vibe to it.
author: Allan H.

description: "Want to go bang Cocos?" is how a friend of mine starts the conversation whenever we think about late night munchies especially after having a few adult beverages. That probably caught some attention so let me focus back on this review. I have mixed feelings about Cocobang. I do feel it has the best KFC (Korean friend chicken) in the main city area for sure even in comparison to 707. I also think the Budaejjigae (army stew) is pretty delicious here so props to them on both dishes. I think my struggle is that everything else is just OK. There is nothing wrong with that for a Korean Pub as people tend to go to these spots when they are slightly happy off alcohol. I think the biggest part that is challenging for these guys is that they have very limited seating so there has never been a time that I have waited less than 45 to an hour unless you come extremely early. The prices are reasonable I suppose but again just the wait alone for just a few notable dishes has to round this3.5 review to a 3.
author: Dan M.

description: This is a fun place to go with friends and order family style. Also great after a night of drinking :) We always order soju and beer (combined it is called somac) and it is really good. I love the seafood pancake and the kimchi fried rice, both are delicious.
author: Samantha J.

description: A hole in the wall place..limited seating but we didnt wait that long. We ordered the fried chicken and it was ok..nothing special other than how it looks like, it had sweet breading, not spicy, it was lacking some salt. Kimchi rice was good, the heat was fine...again nothing special. We loved the spicy calamari with somen.. it was stir fried with fresh jalapenos and i guess some korean sauce they made. Staff was nice and attentive to needs. I would come back here but it would not be my first choice for korean food.
author: April B.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in The City.

Their food and atmosphere isn't posh by any means, but it is delicious and inviting. When you walk in, you'll see a smallish dining area with loud Korean music and dance videos playing on screens on the wall. It's a trendy feeling that somehow doesn't feel alienating. I am not a fan of k-pop by any means, but it's a fun atmosphere for a night out with friends.

The food is what I would call ethnic fast food--akin to Indian chaat, Chinese dim sum, and Turkish gyros. My go-to items are the bulgogi hotpot, the kimchi fried rice, the Korean sausage with silver noodle, and of course, the fried chicken two ways. That paired with some rice wine and soju makes for a wonderful evening event for me and my friends.

The service is great and super friendly. Although waiting times can be long, the servers/hosts always come out to acknowledge you and even bring out menus so that you have something to do. Shout out to Chae for being an awesome dude!

This is my go-to Korean spot in the city. I love the food, the atmosphere, and the service. They know my name and treat me warmly. I will keep coming back and recommend that you do too.
author: M T.

description:
All i gotta say is, this is the spot to drink and eat some good food.

The place was jammed pack on a Saturday night with a seating capacity of no more than 30 people.  Place was a loud with a couple of Korean people playing drinking games along with the music playing on their projector.   

Waiting for about 10mins then one of the workers said if you don't mind, let me get your number and ill call you when the table is ready. I thought this was a nice jester especially coming from a small restaurant but hey, that's a big plus for customer service right there. So we to hang out at the hotel, "Clift" down the street which is a trendy swanky spot.

About 45mins later, the restaurant called back and our table was ready. 4 of us was super hungry so we order the cheese corn, Fire spicy chicken with rice noodle, sweet and spicy whole fried chicken, Homemade noodle soup and the kimchi fried rice.

Cheese Corn: was ok, buttery with melted American cheese on a skillet.

Fire spicy chicken with rice noodle: this bad boy has a pretty good kick and I'm so glad i didn't get the "Fire Burning" chicken w/rice noodle.  My mouth can usually handle heat but this one was just right, anything hotter, I'd be crying a river. 

Homemade Noodle soup: Literally the noodles tasted homemade which came in a broth with small clams, carrots and zucchini.  The bowl was a very fair size and provided tons of noodles.  I added some of the fire spicy chicken in the noodles to give it a little be more of a flavor.

Sweet and Spicy Chicken: The portions were huge and came with shredded raw cabbage with a orange dressing.  This dish was delicious. I couldn't taste the spiciness especially after eating the spicy chicken before.  The chicken was actually all boneless which was to my surprise as i was expecting a actually whole chicken being cut up.  i wanna say it was a mix of chicken thighs/dark meat and 2 chicken wings. I'm more of a boneless guy so it was heaven to me.

Kimchi fried rice: this was spicy also but less than the spicy chicken yet more than the fried chicken.  A sunny side up egg was presented on top of the rice with a bed of Kimchi on the bottom.  Dish was good but just a little to greasy as you'll see the orange oil left on the plate and you can taste it.

Overall, I'd have to say this is one of the Best Korean spots I've been too.  Portions are big, definitely get your moneys worth and they serve flavored Soju (which i will be drinking next time i go).
author: Cliff L.

description:
Cocobang is one of those gems when you go with friends and you want a super casual place. It's affordable and good food. There can be a wait depending on when you go but, just give them your name and phone number. Then head to the bar to wait for your table. 

Comfort food at its best.
author: Lara C.

description:
I came here twice. First time service was great but I don't think we ordered the right things. We came back again because we had a better idea what to order, and we were right.
The fried chicken is realllllllllly good, with the side salad too.
Clear noodles and potstickers were also really good. 

Really good service, nice and attentive.
author: Roni M.

description: nice that they open for the late nighters.  but i wasn't totally wowed by the food.  the fried chicken was ok, but a little gristly and not very spicy.  ger-ger was really disappointed with the bibimbap.  the kimchi fried rice was good, but that's a dish that's really hard to mess up.
author: Brian K.

description: Glad that they were open late! The spicy fried chicken, kimche pancake, and house made thick noodle soup were delicious. The rice cake was very very spicy but still good! The tea went perfectly with the dishes.
author: Jennifer C.

description: After getting out of Playland on Polk at 2am and starving with no food other than pizza in site, I stumbled on Cocobang on yelp. We decided to take the half mile treck over, and it was well worth it. Thank you for being open at 2:30am!!! The place was of course packed with starving post-bar hoppers. But we were seated pretty quickly. I got the kimchi pancake and the kimchi fried rice, and both went down really well with my intoxicated self. So this place is a go! I am not so sure how it would've compared sober, but if you plan to come here at 2am like I did, it really doesn't matter. Enjoy.
author: Nikita K.

description:
My friends and I decided to come here on a Friday night. It was packed but the wait wasn't too long. We were second in line with 4 people. After we sat, we decided we wanted to get the whole fried chicken and the whole saucy korean fried chicken.We also got the cheesy corn and the bulgogi soup. I ate both chickens and enjoyed the saucy chicken a lot more than the regular fried chicken.  The soup and cheese corn B were delicious and I definitely recommend the cheese corn.  When we received the bon chon in the beginning, I was surprised that this place didn't have kim chi with their bon chon. 

They also play korean music with videos on the back wall of the restaurant which was interesting.

The service was lacking. However, it was a Friday night and it was fully packed. 

I'll probably come again to try out their soju because almost all the other tables had it too.
author: Jason L.

description: worst service ever！the attitude of the owner is so bad! Me and my friends would never come again! And me and my friends both lost something at there, so it is question about is someone stealing? But why such a bad attitude react to the customer who needed help? Just make me so mad to see this kind of restaurant still open!
author: Minglang J.

description:
Was greeted and served promptly. The waiter did a great job by taking ownership and letting my know that what I ordered perhaps wasn't gonna do it for me and recommended food that he thought would be a better choice as far as taste and portion wise (he wasn't up selling either) he also offered to bring out a free small serving of one of the dishes. 

 Overall great first time experience. I don't know much about Korean food but what I had was different and delicious. Ill be coming back here again for sure.
author: Alex V.

description:
I thought I had written a review about this place before - I guess I missed it because we've been here a few times!  The first couple times were ok, good bbq chicken and meat were a-ok, but this last time we were here, it was a dud.  

We ordered the fried chicken (actually pretty good), but the cabbage salad was ehh, the dressing wasn't very good, 1000 Island, not so hot.  We got the bbq beef, a-ok.  We had tea...sort of, the guy didn't bring it for a loooooong time, and at Korean restaurants, I'm used to getting the yummy vegetable side dishes, forgot what they're called, but you usually get 5-8 of them.  At Cocobang, we got 3...kind of disappointing and they weren't that good...disappointing...
author: Maile N.

description:
3.5 but I'm not feeling generous. 

Shitty day at work? Friends are all off at the same damn time? Don't have shit else to do? Filled our voids with Korean food. 

LMFAO tho.........this was such an odd experience. Luckily our server was super friendly and was able to deal with us. 

Pros:

Fast
Friendly 
Tasty food. Not amazing, but worth while
Huge portions


Cons:

Bathroom was gross
Space is tiny
They play youtube videos...-_-
Weren't very attentive
Over priced
author: Lydia L.

description:
Definitely our favorite Korean place in the neighborhood. The location is very small and I've only eaten in the restaurant a couple of times and it was a good experience as I was impressed by the selection of food they have. Owners were friendly but TV/music was loud. 

Food was delicious and even delivery was great! Obviously, if you are getting fried food delivered, don't expect it to be crunchy. They have all the homey Korean food that I generally crave for. Will definitely revisit often!
author: Susie L.

description: My mom and I found this place right around the corner from the Donatello and loved it! The food hit the spot for us. We ordered the kimchee fried rice and the  (spicy sticky noodle with vegetables) and the short ribs (kalbi) to go for my husband.  All three dishes were excellent. The portions were enough to share family style. Noodle dish was spicy and the noodle was perfect, the side dish is minimal and the bean sprout side dish was delicious. It's a small dining area with minimal seating but I say it is worth the wait. The service was excellent - staff very friendly and accommodating to customer needs! It's a small hole in the wall and that is what makes it so good! Highly recommend!
author: June R.

description: It's great. It's cheap, it's busy, and the food is great to suck up any alcohol you may have consumed that night. It is great to go after a few bars, get lots of things to share like the ribs or the cheese corn (corn cheese?), which is exactly what the name implies. I would go back any time I am in the neighborhood.
author: Michael J.

description:
Oh no no no. I did not like this place. I was craving tofu soup on a cold San Francisco night so my bf took me to the closest Korean restaurant to his place. What a disappointment. 

I love places that have hella side dishes but I understand that some restaurants only have 3. But why wasn't one of them Kim chi ? T_T I like to put Kim chi in my tofu soup so maybe that's why it just didn't taste like what I was craving. 3 stars for tofu soup 

Seafood pancake: huge portions as expected. I just wanted to note that they should cut it up and stack the pieces so they can put it in a smaller plate. The table we were at was super tiny and we barely had enough room for everything. Not bad dish but not memorable 3 stars 

Bimbimbop 2 stars. No stone bowl!? What the hell? The lack of a hot stone bowl made the rice seem soggy and was missing that crispy goodness at the bottom of the bowl. 

Don't think I'll be coming back. Sorry
author: Elaine L.

description: Great food, great service! They were prompt, attentive, and really friendly. We ordered the corn and cheese and a half order of the spicy/tangy chicken (came with a hefty salad too.) They also provided the standard nibbling snacks at Korean places (pickled radish, bean sprouts, fish cake.) Everything was delicious..will definitely be back!
author: Jasmine A.

description: Took a while to get a seat but they comp'd us a beer so that was a welcomed surprise. Thank you! In the end, good food and would definitely come back.
author: Lisa P.

description: I am so pissed because I lost my phone at there and I left only 5 mins and went back to find it! But the owner is telling me that they didn't find anything when they clean the table. I mean that's fine! So I ask other table's  people see if they see anything or anyone took it! But the owner starts telling me that I am disturbing other people eating! I mean I'm sorry if I disturbing others because I am so worry about finding my phone! But the other people are really nice and willing to help me to find! Why as a owner you have to act like this mean?! I been there so many times with my friends to eat and drink because I think it was such a good place to have late dinner and drinks in downtown! But what happened tonight, really make me disappointed！I would never go to cocobang again for sure! Not only because my phone was stealing， but also the services there is way to bad! As a owner, u should help customers! But u just acting like its not ur business! I felt terrible about u and cocobang after what happened and I suggest everyone does not go to there ever!
author: Lan L.

description:
The place is really small. Lucky us we got the last table around 8 PM on a saturday night.

We ordered Bulgogi Soup and Kimchee fried rice. The food and the price are decent. Great spot for Korean food if you are in the area (Union Square).
author: Angie V.

description:
Good foods, good service and great experience @ Cocobang will definitely go there again. Their cheese corn is a must order item on the menu. I had my mini vacation in San Francisco w/few of my girlfriends. We arrive on a Saturday night and unsure where to eat so we yelped and this is the place we decided on. Walk in at 7:25PM trying to get a table for five unfortunately the house is full plus there are two reservations ahead of us. Unsure how long the wait will be. We were told the only chance of us having a table is if one of the party cancel/no show however is not a guarantee; we won't find out until 8:15PM. We all were starving therefore no way we would wait. Before we left the boss suggest us to call in for reservation on that day between 4PM - 5PM. A gf really want to try their Korean chicken so we call in for reservation the very next day. We arrived 45 mins before our reservation frankly the they are able to work us in and they have us seated within 15 mins. The boss is very nice he apology to us about last night and took our orders before we even have our table therefore we can have our foods shortly after seated. He even gave us an appetizer on the house. 

That night the house was as full as the night before however it was an enjoyable night servers come to check on us every now and then to see if we needed and thing. When we finished paying the night slow down and the boss able to come to chat w/us. He ask us to come back more, we wish unfortunately we are tourists; we're glad that we selected here to eat.
author: Anney L.

description:
Was waiting forty-five minutes for a table really worth it? The only dish that was somewhat good we shared was the pigs feet. The flavor of my spicy BBQ pork felt more composed of added-on batter than the pork itself. I'm sure an OB can be ordered elsewhere.

Worst part is that the delay altered our plans for the rest of the night. Should've been better overall.
author: Garett T.

description: Great little spot off of Union Square.  We got the Bulgogi Salad, Kalbi and Kim Chee fried rice and glass noodles.  Definitely recommended if you are in the area!
author: Patrick R.

description: The Fire Spicy Chicken is quite glorious with a side of white rice. The water comes in a bottle suitable for 2 to share; have the water ready if you're getting the Fire Spicy Chicken. The environment is upbeat and the hours are absolutely splendid. Heartwarming service as well. Perfect for a post-bar chow down.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Friday night, after another too-many hours of drinking, the inevitable post-drinking late-night munchies struck. So along came I, with Anna D and Kazu O, after making the depressing discovery that we'd missed Katana-ya hours (no one among us seemed to remember that they'd closed an hour before).

After a long (20-30 minute) wait in the cold, we finally sit down and order a kimchi fried rice, kalbi & bulgogi combo, and fried chicken (that they soon forgot). Overall, just okay food. Yes, even after drinking. The kalbi and bulgogi were not particularly notable, and hardness of the kimchi fried rice seemed to suggest that it was either undercooked, or really old rice.

While there's a good chance that I may come back someday (or rather, be brought back someday) just because they're open late, it certainly won't be my first choice, as long as Katana-ya is still open.
author: Johnny W.

description: I'm eating the bulgogi salad right now. it is LEGIT. and the cheese corn. omg. you must come eat here.
author: Ryan D.

description: The service was excellent and the food delicious. K-pop background music at just the right level and very modest prices for the quality of fare. Loved it.
author: Simon K.

description: The food was utterly disappointing going in on a Saturday night. They were rushing us into ordering and extremely rude in their service. The entree was first placed and the rice was serviced after 15 minutes. When asked about it they didn't seem to bother and said we should have asked for it. Overall a very disappointing experience
author: Siddharth K.

description:
This is the spot to go to after bar hopping in this part of town. I mean, it closes at 4:00AM on the weekends and they're selling fried chicken and garlic fries. For my party of three, we got a whole chicken and garlic fries. This was enough for us. Since we were there after 2:00AM, they weren't serving alcohol anymore--just if you were wondering.

On this big projector screen, they play Korean music videos all day, even old school ones surprisingly.
The joint is sort of small so it might be a while to get a table if you're there at a prime time.
Bathrooms are downstairs.

Anyway, great find in the TL late at night.
author: Marlon T.

description: I went with a friend and it was super busy. It is a hole in the wall and so the wait took a while, but according to the friend it isn't usually like that. That is why I give it 4 stars. I like the vibe and I would have like it more if it wasn't as packed. The chicken is good and so are their other dishes. I like it a lot better than OB Town in Oakland, in terms of food! If you're in the area and want some chicken and beer this is a great place to go with a group of 3-4 friends!
author: John C.

description: First time here, visiting from out of town. I got the fried chicken with green onions togo and it was delicious even after walking all the way back to my hotel. The guy worker was super helpful, the girl worker seemed stressed/rushed. Super tiny place, less than 10 tables I'd estimate. I'd go back next time I'm in town.
author: Phyllis L.

description: The manager lost his temper - very unprofessional! I will add more details later..
author: Nam K.

description: Just finished the kimchi fried rice and the kimchi hot pot stew...SO thrilled to have this food a block away from my house! Rice had the best texture. It was moist, and flavorful, and had bits if hot dog/baloney type meat in it, and the hot pot was out of this friggen world. My new go to comfort soup For sure. Can't wait to go back and try the fried chicken.
author: Chaka K.

description: Can I tell you how much I love Korean food??? This place absolutely did NOT DISAPPOINT. Unfortunately, I was already on another level of drunk when walking into here so I didn't get to feast my eyes on the whole menu. But once I saw kimchee fried rice I was sold. There are only a few places, in my opinion, that can perfect kimchee fried rice and let me tell you... Cocobang satisfied 150%. Thank goodness the homies ordered korean chicken wings and other goodies that they let me try out cause I would've cried looking back at my pictures without being able to taste. Can't wait to come back to the city to try everything else!
author: Danya P.

description:
Mediocre meat. I just remember the spicy fried chicken being the best thing ever when I was drunk off my @$$, but the last time I went, they screwed up our order and didn't even bring it out. What the hell was the point of eating there, then?

Anyway... go when you're wasted and starving. It's okay for drunk food. I wouldn't touch this stuff with a 10-foot-pole while sober, though. I mean.. SF just doesn't have good Korean food, and this place is definitely not even considered one of the better places in the city!
author: Kazu O.

description:
FAVORITE KOREAN RESTAURANT in the city.

Garlic fried chicken - Everyone I brought to this place loved their chicken!

And I love their garlic fries! 

I love how they play kpop music videos, and my friends and I literally got free drinks for dancing Gangnam style.

Parking around the area kinda sucks, but that shouldn't stop anyone :)
author: V B.

description:
3.5 stars and this review is only for Sweet & Sour Chicken and Fried Chicken.  

Came to Cocobang after drinking with friends on a Saturday's night around 1:45am. Luckily that we went there before the rush.  Right after we got seated.  The place was packed and even there were couple parties waiting outside the restaurant.  

We ordered couple different dishes and I only tried the Fried Chicken and Sweet & Sour Chicken.  Both chicken were good.  The chicken was tender, juicy and flavorful.  Personally, I like the Sweet & Sour one more because I love the sweet & sour sauce.  The side salad was just ok.

I also love the K-Pop video wall.  Pretty fun watching the video while eating and drinking.  

I think Cocobang is a great place for food after a long night of party.  But if you go after 1:30am, be prepared to wait a bit because the restaurant is very small.
author: Liza T.

description: Great late night eats...nice staff, great prices.  They are open very late and are a prefect place to refuel after the bars.   We went w recommendations from the waiter and all three of us enjoyed each item.  Good quantities...meat quality good as well.
author: Scott E.

description: Like many others before me, this place is incredible. The chicken is tender, juicy, and a delicious crispy skin. The flavored soju was well done. The kimchi was very flavorful. Everything we had was better than expected. The staff was very friendly and patient (we kept ordering and ordering) would definitely recommend to anyone looking for excellent korean food. We will definitely be back.
author: Matthew C.

description: You get what you're here for . 2 am . Korean food. Good service. Food is awesome. Fair price. I've been there 3 nights in a row - they know how to deal with the young crowds pressure
author: Ben J.

description:
This place is the bomb dot com. Here's what just happened.

It's 8:00 pm and I want fried chicken because eating healthy is boring. Find this place. It's crowded. There are people standing outside. Good sign. I'm not going to be a jerk and usurp a table just for me so I order my meal to go.

I order a half (or as their menu says, "helf," oh god that's so cute) order of the fried chicken with hot & tangy sauce. "Do you want rice with that?" the she asks. "Yeah I want rice with that!" Suddenly flashbacks of my disappointing trip to Aria are coming back to me. But that was that and this is this so I worried not.

I wait outside while listening to the Kpop and watching the music videos on the wall. Hell yeah. Less than 10 minutes later the lady walks to the door and hands me a plastic bag with not one, but three plastic bins in it. Oh boy. I rush home like a giddy school girl leaving for holiday.

OMG there's so much food and it all looks friggin' delicious! Start eating. Suspicions of food being delicious are confirmed. Unexpected side dishes included: a generous helping of coleslaw, bean sprouts with peanuts, some green stuff and some white chunks (I'd tell you what they are but I'm far too white and far too new to SF to know such things... soon, I promise. I'm getting better at this). Hot & spicy chicken is not hot - it's sweet, but that's okay because it delicious.

All this for only $9.73 (before tip). I'm totally coming back here for take out! I'd also really like to come back with friends and eat in (note to self, make friends). And apparently they're open super late for those who like to stay out to the wee hours.
author: Vivian A.

description:
Walked here after a happy night at Tradition. It is a really small place with an even smaller waiting area. However, service is pretty efficient and food came out within 10 minutes!

Highlights: seafood pancake and tofu soup both were hot and delicious. 
Chicken: got one plate of each kind. I personally liked the sauced ones better than the straight plain fried chicken. Although the sauced ones are labeled spicy, they weren't and were flavored well. 

This is definitely a place to come by when you're starving after a night of partying/drinking. It is ideal for small groups so if you have a larger party - be prepared to wait.
author: Betty S.

description: This was SO GOOD.  My husband and I stopped here our last night in San Francisco, and I only regret not going sooner so we could go twice.  I had the Fire Spicy Chicken with Cheese and it was spicy, gooey, crunchy, and perfect.  Service is fast, polite, definitely not cloying or over attentive.  Hey, the place is packed and they're busy!  Get a nice cold soju (the strawberry is delicious) and some fire spicy chicken, watch the Kpop on the giant double screens, and enjoy.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
My friends and I went here in search of something filling in preparation for our race the following day. I ordered a chicken bulgogi which was very flavorful and my friends liked their orders as well. The mango shots we had while waiting in line were great too, tasted like fruit juice so you had to be careful with how many you had. They even allowed one of us to change their order after the other order had already been prepared, free of charge. The service was relatively fast given how busy they were. Best of all, they deducted $10 off our total order if we paid in cash, which we did. 

One star deducted because of the long wait and how crowded it is, which can be expected given the small size. It was nice being entertained by Korean music videos though while we waited, though. This a great late night and/or fast food option if you happen to be in the area. Walking distance to many hotels and Union Square.
author: a f.

description:
Great place! I used to come here quite often, but its been awhile....

I had a late girls night with some girlfriends. Table of 5. The wait was pretty long, even on a Wednesday. There was one guy running the whole show and a lady behind cooking. We waited awhile. 

We shared seafood pancake, korean rice cakes with ramen, fried chicken with spicy sauce, yogurt soju and mango soju 

Came out to $20 per person. If we didnt drink, it would be about $10 per person. Aside from the wait, this place is not bad. 

The giant tv screen thing is really entertaining. They rotate between kpop groups and american artists (beyonce, lady gaga, etc)
author: Connie M.

description:
I should have known the second I saw noodles in my kimchijigae what kind of place I was in -- the further I dug into my mediocre bowl of kimchi soup, the more I realized just how many sojus deep I needed to be before I could enjoy this bowl of spam, hot dogs, and $.10 ramen noodles. 

my friend told me that this is what's called "army stew" and is essentially korean comfort food -- which is fine and dandy, but i don't want to pay $12 for something i can make for less than a $1 and frankly wasn't that tasty. 

i have no desire to return to Cocobang.
author: Melissa N.

description: This place is just absurdly good. Sweet and spicy chicken was ridiculous. Kimchi rice was also amazing. Can't wait to come back
author: Edwin S.

description: I almost don't want to review it bc I want to keep it my little secret. Hit this spot up on my last trip to San Fran...so good. The beef hot pot, cheesy corn and spicy chicken!!! Best little "hole in the wall" late night spot ever!!
author: Inga B.

description:
My korean friend brought me here for dinner. It's a pretty casual place. Great for late night soju and fried chicken with friends! Sinful but yummy. They have K-pop music videos playing in the background. 

1. Fire chicken with cheese - Sounds weird initially. Cheese on hotplate chicken with hot sauce? But it turned out pretty ok. Less spicy than I feared. 

2. Soy garlic chicken - My favorite item. This dish is deep fried but worth every single calorie. The marinate drizzled over the chicken was awesome! 

3. Rice cake - I love korean rice cakes. They are so chewy!!! Love the tomato based sauce as well. 

4. Kiwi soju - Personally, soju has always been a little strong to me (like doing vodka shots), but mixed with kiwi... it's perfect! Sweet & fruity. 

The only downside about this place is 

1. Pretty horrible toilets. Try to hold it in. 

2. It isn't good for big groups (more than 6 people per table) as it is a small place.
author: Amanda L.

description: Best Korean restaurant in Union Square/Downtown SF area! I love Korean food and I've eaten here so often with my boyfriend that we are now VIP's. This place is always busy and crowded - I highly recommend calling ahead of time to put your name on the waitlist. Some of our favorite items we always order are: Fried Potstickers, Corn Cheese, Beef Short Ribs (Galbi), Army Soup (Budaejigae), and Fried Chicken in Sweet and Tangy Sauce. Definitely a must try!
author: Minnie S.

description:
EH. 

This place is kinda small and the food is only okay...

I like how they play music videos via youtube tho. The last time I came here- they kept putting on 90s songs so I enjoyed it. 

I've definitely had better Korean food...WAY better...

The wings were pretty decent but...that's all I can say right now regarding their food...

Will I dine here again? Hm...maybe when I'm drunk.
author: Eileen Z.

description: "2 middle-aged (but hip) white tourists walk into a bar" BA-DA-BING! Everyone in here was young & Asian, but we didn't feel at all out of place. The waiter offered forks in case we were chopstick naive & asked if we were ok with spicy. We went with what we knew: pot stickers, veggie noodles & beef short ribs(spicy). The food was the bomb!! The beef was tender & flavorful.  Could be my husbands new favorite in SF. 10% off when paying in cash. Only seats 20 or so. Go early or off hours or you'll be waiting!
author: Kathleen P.

description:
(See pics)

Still come here for the combo box as well as had tried other dishes. All were delicious but take note of the spicy ones as they are fire burning style.

The place looked like it had some good cleanup with a couple booths and new paint.
author: T L.

description:
Great Korean Food, especially their sweet chicken dish.  The service is awesome as well.

However, one of the reasons I have to dock one star is because the place is too small.  Gets super crowded real fast.  Also, it's deceivingly expensive.
author: Joshua P.

description: Service was good, friendly and quick. My group was looking for a place to eat and happen upon this place. We weren't disappointed. Jap chae was good, nothing out of the  ordinary. The BBQ Combo that I picked had quite of bit of sauce to it,  we should have ordered a side of rice with it but it was flavorful, spicy bbq pork and spicy bbq spare ribs. We also got the fried garlic  half chicken, tasted delicious, some pieces were boneless and some had bones, it was hard to tell until you bite into it though. My boyfriend got the bul go gi salad, it was mix greens with bul go gi topping it off, probably the most refresh dish we ordered that night. We were also intrigued with the $7.95 garlic fries, but did not get it. I was just wondering, are they that awesome for almost $8 or is it that large of a portion.
author: Kimberly S.

description: This was one of my favorite eating experiences. Before I get to the amazing food I just want to say that they were very helpful and easygoing when my fiance told them he wanted to propose to me. They turned the music down no questions asked. It was so romantic :) that being said the kimchi rice, chicken wings and bulgogi were no joke and let's not even mention how delicious the Soju was. The service was fantastic they refilled our water about ten times without being asked. The atmosphere is that of an actual Korean bbq and although it was crowded, it was fun and lively. Definitely you must come here. I will be back to cocobang
author: Liz W.

description:
ok...so the 1 star is only because there isnt 1/2 a star.  Dont get me wrong, the food is delicious (if you can get a table).  The spare ribs are tasty and finger licking good.  The tofu soup will warm your belly up on those cold sf nites.

Now on to why they only get 1 star.  keep in mind this is a small place with maybe 7 or 8 tables.  the short story is that They dont take reservations on weekends.  A friend and I arrive shortly after 10pm and of course there are no availbale tables.  We tell the guy we will wait and step outside.  2 other folks walk in and chat with the same guy.  a few minutes later he steps out and tells us, one table is almost done which he is giving to the party of 2 that just walked in and the other table that looked like they were finishing up just ordered more.

I kindly asked how it was possible that they were being seated before we were since they dont take reservations on weekends and we clearly arrived before they did.  He couldnt or wouldnt explain this to me and just smiled at me and repeated that they were being seated next and that we would have to wait for the next available table.

I smiled back and said, thanks but no thanks with a few more choice words I will not include in this write up.

this little girl will not be back no matter how much her tummy wants to!!
author: Chans G.

description:
I always ordered take-out from this place. Already out? Need some drunchie food? Want it as soon as possible? Call Cocobang, place your order, pick it up on your way home, and enjoy :)

FOOD
Kimchi fried rice: Slightly sweet, slightly spicy, slightly greasy. All topped with a nice runny egg.

Korean army stew (budae jjigae): I am surprised that a place like this offers this, but nonetheless, glad that they do! Spicy & hot, with a hodgepodge of foods thrown in (spam, sausage, green onion, kimchi, etc), paired with white rice. Perfect comfort food.

SERVICE
Really friendly service. There was this nice tall Korean guy that helped me every time I was there.  He was always smiling despite how busy and packed the place was.
author: Christine Z.

description:
Delicious strawberry soju! I came here after work and there was a 10 minute wait. I'm sure our wait time is nothing compared to peak hours. Cocobang itself is tiny! Be prepared to hear your neighboring table's conversations! Unlike other Korean street food spots in the City (ie Tonight Soju Bar) you get the mini Korean dishes like kimchi, sprouts, tofu, daikon fruit. We only ordered the kimchi pancake and fried chicken. Both hit the spot while downing it with soju. 

Service was speedy and friendly!

Will definitely be back.
author: Adlyn S.

description: Friendly waiter who loves Rihanna. A decent place to go for Korean if you're in downtown. However, the flavored soju was icy, which is hard to down.
author: Mandy D.

description: Soju, rice rolls, chicken... chicken... That was my night when I came here. We got drunk and ate some epic food. The rice noodle rolls started out surprisingly spicy, but as we numbed from the alcohol, I needed it to be spicier! I loved them so much. The fried chicken was incredible. The colonel ain't got nothing on these sweet and tangy bad boys. One more shot. Three more bites. Na, one more bottle! The atmosphere is edgy enough to encourage your continuous drinking and some good times! A great place for 4-5 peeps. Any more and this tiny spot will over crowd.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Came here after happy hour to get our Korean fix on.  This is a small hole in the wall dive so it gets packed pretty easily.  Red and Black decor - very 80ish.  

They play K-pop on the plasma TV  to pre-occupy the folks waiting to be seated.  At least it did for me anyway! PROPS TO WONDER GIRLS, "I WANT NOBODY, NOBODY BUT YOU!" (sing with me!) "I want nobody, nobody but you!"

Took us 20 minutes to finally get a table.

We ordered the fried chicken, korean dumpling soup with rice cake, and kalbi.  All in all, it was ok (3 stars) - but i wasn't blown away?  Especially their fried chicken. Bummer. I didn't  try their spicy chicken which is what they're known for but the regular battered chicken was not impressive.  Stone Korean Kitchen's chicken wings are still the best in my YELP book, hands down!  

BUT...what IS good...is the Korean dumpling with rice cake soup!  OMG!!! TO DIE FOR!!!  It's what I'll be craving during those rainy and/or sick days!  SOOOO GOOD and reasonably priced! AND FOR THAT....I give Cocobang 4 stars!!!!!  

I LOVE KOREA!!!!! KAMSAMNIDA!!!! WOOT WOOT!
author: Diana M.

description:
Awesome late-night Korean food! 

Went here with my cousin and friend and were seated within 10 minutes. The place is small and I agree that is isn't ideal for large groups but they will accommodate your group even so. A party of 10 came after us - good thing we got there before them. lol.

Ordered the Bibimbap and it was freakin' delicious. I'm used to seeing it in the hot stone bowl that fries up the rice and egg even more but it's all good - still really good. 

They gave us about 4 side dishes before our food came out (which came out REALLY fast) and we ate til our hearts content. 

I read a review that said "be premared to hear your neighboring table's conversation" LOL yes, this is completely true. We heard everything they were saying even if we were trying to have a conversation by ourselves! 

All in all, good place for late-night eats since they close at 4am. Will definitely come here again.
author: Kat O.

description:
Oh, Cocobang. Such a great place for late-night feasting on mediocre Korean cuisine. The food isn't fantastic--just putting it out there. My Korean taste buds aren't thrilled with most of the foods I've tried, but I will say that the experience makes up for it. They're open until 4am on weekends, so it's an obvious choice for those craving some Korean chow after a night out. Singing along to the K-pop videos projected onto the wall is one of my favorite activities. 

If you're coming for food over experience, try the Galbi (spicy galbi is also good!). I also recommend the Kimchi Hot Pot Stew. 

I love it here, and if you're looking for a centrally-located Korean place in the city, Cocobang is the chow spot for you.
author: Ayoung J.

description:
"LET'S BANG THE COCO!!" is what my friends and I always yell out at 2AM on a weekend night.

I absolutely love this place.  It's awesome not just because of the good food and drinks, but it's opened late every night (4am on the weekend!) so it's perfect after a night out too.  The ambiance is fun since they have a huge projector screen that plays Korean music videos and everyone is usually laughing loudly cuz their drunk.

I always order the budae jigae (spam soup pictured above).  Love love love this!  It's funny how the easiest ingredients together can taste soooo good.  Their korean bbq is ok but the Fried Garlic Chicken was as good as expected...crispy and juicy!  Yogurt soju is always a must when we order too.

The downsides are that it's small and popular, so if you go during a busy time (like after 2AM), you'll have to wait.  They do take reservations though so make sure you call right when they open.  Also, I wish they had more variety in the side dishes they give out.  But I still love this place nonetheless!
author: Jane N.

description: Best Korean restaurant in Lower Nob Hill! Their sweet chicken and BBQ Beef entrees are amazing. Definitely a great place to bring a date or just with friends. They also play a lot of Korean music videos, so it has a great atmosphere.
author: Eric M.

description: I love the food here very delicious better than sex believe me. The Chicken is great, the beef is awesome and the portion is big. The good thing too this place is open til 2 am.
author: Ron G.

description: I come here all the time after shows because its open late. Their chicken is the best korean style fried chicken you will find in the city, I love that you can order it half/half. Only reason I give it 4 stars is because its a little pricy for what it is, but all korean food in Sf seems to be that way. Great place, great atmosphere. I have been a happy customer for years!
author: Mandy M.

description: I just had it tonight and it's no Bon Chon!  It was actually terrible.  I ordered the regular and tangy/spicy chicken.  It had to much fat and I can't stand eating chicken when I can't distinguish the pieces.  It was fatty mystery meat!  Never again!  I'm from the east coast and Bon Chon is way BETTER!
author: Reginald S.

description: I feel like every time I go by here, it's packed, so we decided to stop by on an evening when it didn't look too crowded (maybe because it was somewhat early). The service was friendly but we had a little bit of a communication issue - nothing that turned out to be problematic, though. We wanted to try a range of the menu, so we ordered the fried chicken appetizer, spicy chicken, and bibimbop, which we were warned (rightly so) was too much food for 2 people. The appetizer ended up being our favorite item. The main chicken dish seemed bland and nondescript, and the bibimbop depressingly came in a cold dish, making it pretty unexciting. I'm worried that I just ordered the dish incorrectly and missed asking for a hot pot. Clearly I may have been missing something, and it IS open late, but despite its proximity we won't be back.
author: Lisa K.

description: Me and my family's favorite restaurant in downtown San Francisco. Especially corn cheese, bulgogi, and bbq ribs! Cocktail Soju is tasty too!
author: Melinnie A.

description:
Go-to spot for post-drinking late night grub. The labokki (I have no idea what it's called in English, it's half-ramen, half-ddukbokki) is awesome. Their soondubu is not bad. I'm not a huge fried chicken guy, but their sweet and tangy spicy chicken is pretty good.

Biggest knock is that they're small and if they're hosting big groups of 10+-- which they often are--the wait can get terrible.
author: David C.

description:
We all know Koreans are known for drinking lots, and serving delish drunchies (drunk munchies), so what place did we all have in mind when we were all drinking at 2 AM? Cocobang.

They serve your typical korean food, ranging from fried chicken (reg and that tangy sauce, yum yum), sundobu (tofu shop), cheese corn, ddukbokki (rice cake), and kimchi pancake. 

Their "spiciest" sundobu was not that spicy, their kimchi pancake was a bit undercooked in the middle and too oily, and their cheese corn was had too much mozzarella that became hard and chewy after only 10 minutes of eating into it. 

Their ddukbokki was the best -- the ramen that came along was nice and chewy, and the rice cake itself was chewy but also spicayyy. Had to stop eating because it was burning my mouth and the water was gone too fast! But soooo gooood, thinking about it just gives my stomach a bit of a turn just anticipating the spiciness.

Service was TERRIBLE though. I know the place is tiny and probably can fit only 30 people max, and with 2 korean servers, it was probably really hard to accommodate everyone. But it took us 40 minutes into service to get our kimchi pancake, and he kept forgetting to get us water....

Alsoooo, I know they won't serve you alcohol after 2 AM cus of the law, but not even at 1:45 when we promised we would finish our soju shots ASAP ):

TIP: 
1. Call in before you head out here to see the wait, and reserve your name so you don't have to wait too long!
2. CALL TO JUST TAKE OUT! Save yourself 1.5 hours here!
3. Please get a cab back home! The Tenderloin area is a bit sketch. Be safe!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Not the best korean food i've had. There are lot's of places in Oakland that are a lot better. All in all, i would say this place is only average.

The nice thing is that they have a projector that plays Kpop music videos, that part is very cool.
author: Howard K.

description:
I was craving for Korean food at 2 am and after the bars, we decided to go to Cocobang because they were still open.  This place was packed but the food was super good!! I loved it all. 

I especially loved the corn n cheese plate and bibimbap since I havent had it in awhile.  I definitely recommend this place if you're looking for good food at 2 am! hahha 

Enjoy! :)
author: Anna B.

description: Perfect hole in the wall Korean spot. Spicy, delicious food. Super sugary mango soju that tastes like candy. And a hilarious giant screen playing Asian music videos. I'll be back for sure.
author: Emily T.

description:
A taste of advanced Korean Hot & Tangy chicken frying techniques from the Motherland.
Have a lot more on the menu too!
author: Sejin H.

description: a good place for late night post bar hopping eating. We ordered some fried chicken, garlic fries, ddukbokki and galbi. I will probably pass on the garlic fries next time but everything was tasty. Four stars possibly because it was really late and I was hungry, but I enjoyed myself.
author: Alice H.

description: So good! Highly recommend the garlic chicken but wish it was more garlic-y. Also their version of jap chae is so good and flavorful. Highly recommend!
author: Miles O.

description:
When you first see the outside or walk into this place, you might get worried - especially dust-phobic people b/c you can't see anything in here!  The ceilings are high and the walls are red.  The bathroom is beyond a flight of stairs that might not pass any sort of city inspection, but at least it was clean.

The chicken and pork cutlet is really good here.  The service is pretty good too.  Just parking is a bit tricky, but would definitely come here again.
author: Chris L.

description: "Padak" was great!!!!! for this price! I definitely visit again if I travel san Francisco again!!
author: Hyedol L.

description: This the best place to eat in the city after a late night of drinking ! The videos the are on point...
author: Krs B.

description: Great hole in the wall Korean food. Their fried chicken is fantastic. Most of the pieces were de-boned. Great place to go when you're trying to sober up and need some food in the belly. Shout out to Sean! Thanks for the bottle of soju.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Out of towners listen up--if you're not scared by the prospect of a brief wait during peak times, and like the idea of casual Korean a stone's throw away from Union Square hotels, give this place a try.

My wife and I had their fried chicken, kalbi, some strawberry soju and a "pitcher" of (Obi) beer, with white rice and a bit of banchan and were totally satisfied for about $50-$60 including tip.  Think Friday's without the flair, owner operators who actually care, quick hot comfort food in a cozy setting and all the K-Pop your ears can eat.  What's not to like?
author: Stephen A.

description:
Coco BANG! A catchy name.

Patrons appear to be locals . mostly young . mostly Asian.

Atmosphere - neon glow amongst brick.

Menu is full of tempting, spicy Korean morsels. I wanted to try the spicy chicken wings, but refrained - my partner in crime that night can't handle fire...plus I was trying to be good and stay away from the fried goodness that I love.

We shared the corn cheese appetizer. I couldn't resist this unusual combination. It was as stated. Nothing more, nothing less.

Trying to toe the healthier line, I opted for the traditional bibimbap - veg., meat and egg over rice. It was served cold (I've had hot ones at other places) and bland for my palate. Fortunately sauce was near to add more oomph. On the other hand, the included meat was delicious, marinated and packed a nice punch.

I'd like to come back to try some of their other dishes. Something fried and with a Bang!
author: Cathy K.

description:
Garlic chicken and Galbi are my favorite dishes!

It is really tiny restaurant, so I was suspicious about their food quality and services. But their food is really great and has lots of variety. 

1.Bossam: It was expensive but great dish for sharing. 

2. Spicy Rice Cake: this is not spicy at all. But they have good amount rice cakes in it w/ veggies.

3. Galbi: This place has the best Galbi in SF! Short ribs are marinated really well. It is not too sweet or salty!! Come with ricr

4. Garlic Chicken: It is the best dish in Cocobang!

Also if you want to try korean drinks, try Kiwi soju:)
author: Sara I.

description: This restaurant was small and super busy. I had the bibinbop. It was ok. The bowl was not hot like traditional. My friend had the fried chickens said it was ok to good. All in all this seems like a place you come to after clubbing. The place is small so you have to be mindful that it will be busy when the clubs let out.
author: Tae S.

description:
The food is alright. The prices are alright also. The place is tiny so every time I show up, I have yet to see a table available. So I order to go.

Ordering over the phone is a nightmare. It's easier to shoot yourself in the foot. They don't speak good English, so it's common to hear:

"I don't know what does that mean..."
"I can't hear you, can you yell louder"
"What's that?" (when ordering something from their menu)

Sometimes they'll hang up on you, and when you immediately call back, they have no idea who you are.

The food is good enough, but they need a lot of practice speaking on the phone.
author: John D.

description: Tasty food, and the staff is very nice.  The dinner plates are HUGE, so unless you're starving, bring someone to share with.  Open really late too, and has free parking if you call ahead.
author: Christina S.

description: A fun korean restaurant in the city near union square. Food is authentic and is quite tasty.  The menu can be overwhelming if you're not familiar with korean cuisine, I suppose.  Korean fried chicken is great stuff that goes very well with a large bottle of beer and (of course) soju
author: Ross I.

description: It's not as good as the Korean fried chicken that you'll find in Los Angeles K-town..but a close second! I'm not a big fan of the grilled meat plates here but the garlic fried chicken will do.  And if you haven't tried the clam soup, it is a definite must!! Wish there was more variety with the banchan they give you here but for a late night Korean food spot near union sq, this restaurant is tasty and makes the cut.
author: Phan ..

description: The food wasn't very impressive. I had a lot better. The only reason I came here was because it was the only very few places still open late at night.
author: Shirley G.

description:
Its Korean food...lol...the best thing about it is that it is close to my work so its a great place to come by after a long day and you need a drink...food is good but the drinks are better....i like beer so it OB all night long...

Try their fried chicken...sooo yummy..any one cause there are several but i lean more towards galic...

it gets crowded fast and parking is an itch cause its down town..
author: Mary B.

description:
A few good points:
- SPICY BBQ PORK!!! You have to try it!
- Pot stickers are perfect.
- Bibimbap is delightful. 
- K-Pop always playing on the projector with Beyonce to spice things up. Its kind of mesmerizing. 

This place is always filled with cool hip Korean kids, so you know the food & drinks are good even before you try it. 

You might have to wait a little if you come during the rush, the place is on the smaller side, but it's worth it!
author: Lily R.

description:
usually a line during rush hours, its a small restaurant.

i guess the food is okay for this kinda price
- good service.
author: Miffy L.

description:
My wife and I happened to walk by this when we were visiting on a business trip. We enjoyed a great meal of Bul-Go-Gi and Spicy Chicken. We shared a big OB beer. The food was great. Simple and fresh with good portions. The Spicy Chicken was excellent. Very spicy, but still very flavorful. The Bulgogi was excellent. Ron Swanson would approve of the meat portions. Service was good. The staff was friendly and professional.
It is a very small space and people tend to camp out at the tables (my wife and I came in, ate, drank, and departed without another table changing out). 
Our total bill was $40 with tip included. 
Very satisfied with this place! I'd go back without and hesitation.
author: Chuck V.

description: The spicy pork with short rib combo was okay. The problem for me is that the short rib had a lot of fat on them. But the atmosphere and decor was nice. The place can fit about 60 people inside.
author: Keitha G.

description: Korean food at 1am?  Plus great, friendly service?  Sold.  No doubt this is a great choice.  I'm a Norwegian who lives in MN, but I dig Korean food and this scratched the itch.  Rice is cooked well and chicken is tasty.  Don't you dare come here as a closed minded person that only eats at TGI Fridays and then rate it 2 stars.  This place rocks for those seeking a satisfying Korean meal at a fair price....after bar close.
author: Chris B.

description:
2.13.2011
6:30 PM
$17

I pound it out here on the reg so I'm really not trying to fuel the fire but on a recent visit on a takeout order, I experienced something that was rather unique and Yelp worthy.

After completing my order and waiting around for more than 30 minutes in an empty restaurant, the owner approaches me, apologizes for the wait and discounts my bill.  Apparently, 5 phone orders came in before me.  

Anyways, I appreciated the proactive gesture and will definitely be back.
author: William R.

description: I wander around alone a lot at 3 in the morning.  I don't recommend that to most folks, since you are most likely more friendly than I am. What I do recommend is getting into Cocobang late night for the sweet and spicy chicken, cheese corn, kimchi fried rice and bulgogi.    But don't be out flaunting this food on the street if you take it to go unless you are trying to get robbed.   Those late night urchins will kill a mofo for that cheese corn.
author: Dru P.

description:
I know that the food would be a lot better past 11pm, but I was getting hungry around 6pm and was in the area.  I grabbed an order the daeji bulgogi and stared at the huge screen playing K-Pop MVs while waiting for my dish to come.  Service wasn't too bad and the prices are reasonable.  

But like I said, I know I would enjoy this place a lot more once late night hits.  But for now, it's pretty decent.
author: Ren L.

description:
The hot & tangy wings were not spicy at all, and not very tangy either, come to think of it. It mostly tasted sweet, with a hint of ketchup.  Seafood pancake is gigantic, but pretty well done.  Bibimbap was okay.

I know it feels like you're walking into a horror movie when you go to the bathroom, but it's not THAT bad inside. I've seen worse.
author: Lady V.

description: This is a story about my affair with Cocobang. Years ago, I would frequent Cocobang because it had the best Korean food in Union Square. But I moved away and I naively thought things would stay the same. Then all the cockroaches moved in. I met them last night. They were on my table and all over the wall. Big ones. Small ones. The whole variety. I must break up with this one.
author: Lily T.

description: Worst place to go if you're visiting San Francisco. This place is not only understaffed but also unsanitary. If you want to receive horrible customer service and inedible food because of the staff's hygiene then be my guest. The so called manager of this place is incompetent to meet his guests needs and extremely rude, when he took our order he missed a few plates and when we notified him and got our simple meal after waiting half an hour it had strands of hair. We were never attended to after that even after multiple tries of getting his attention, when we finally had the chance to speak with him he was aggressive and offensive. I'm not sure as to how this business is still up when they do not know how to run it. The health department should be notified of this critically unhygienic establishment.
author: Jeanette M.

description:
Awesome place! I always come here for Korean food as they have a huge menu and their price is cheap. Plus for your money they give you a lot of food, time to pig out with your oppas and ajummas! Service is very very good and accommodating to parties of 6, they'll bring those extra chairs out for you. 

The only thing though is its a tiny place, a rat would complain. Be there early, especially if you're coming out of a club at 2am.

I love coming here because I like watching Girls' Generation shaking their things on the big screen....B-Brings the boys out!
author: K C.

description: This place is great! I love cocobang so much . I always bring my friends here for their very first Korean BBQ dinner! And we always order lots of soju cocktails ! I brought 14 people in tonight and they made it work. We even got 2 free pitchers of soju from them. David and Sean who I'm assuming are the owners were great to my party. I've been to almost every Korean place in San Francisco and the atmosphere here is the best for the younger crowd. 5 stars for service , food, and overall. The only thing missing is long ribs. If they could get long ribs the place would have a line for the next block!
author: Kyle R.

description:
The restaurant is pretty tiny (8 tables?) so we took our 2am order to-go, but it really hit the spot when we got it home.  We got one order of regular fried chicken and one order of hot and tangy fried chicken.  I'm looking at Yelp photos and seeing how much mayo dressing comes on the "salad" is kind of grossing me out - I ate a TON of it in the dimly lit living room where we chowed down - but I'll just credit it with hangover prevention and go guilt-free.  I actually preferred the regular fried chicken to the hot and tangy texture wise, but if your group is big enough I'd get a mix for variety.  My crowd was pretty split on their favorites.

The KPop music videos projected super huge on the wall were fun to watch...however nearly getting caught up in a brawl while waiting in the doorway was not so fun.  The fact that no one in the restaurant blinked an eye or attempted to break it up makes me fear that it's a common occurrence, so I may just call in my order and be on my merry, tipsy way if I find myself craving late night Cocobang again.
author: Krystle S.

description: Best food and service in SF. We have been going here for a couple years now. Pretty much everything here is delicious, but I would highly recommend the fried chicken and boiled pork plate. The staff is awesome, and I always leave satisfied
author: Scott V.

description: Second time here, the kimchi related food here are all good. Kimchi fried rice and fried chicken are really good for soju.
author: Sunny J.

description: first time here, but I'll definitely be going back. really great experience. we had kimchi fried rice, seafood pancakes and a type of fried chicken that wasn't all greasy and had a really interesting batter. service was super friendly and accommodating. prices were fair. it's really small, maybe 10 or 12 tables (didn't count) so I've heard the wait can be bad, but it was only 10 minutes for us. very lively vibe which the waitstaff contributed to.
author: Bob U.

description:
Pretty freakin bomb.com!  Very decent portions for Korean food.  Get the spicy rice cake with ramen.  Get the cheesy corn.  Get the kimchee fried rice.  Get the fried chicken.

Been here twice.  Once for dine in and once for take out.  For take out, the guy we paid was nice enough to give us banchan to go (kimchee, fish cake, and potato salad).  The portions for the rice cake with ramen was one of the largest I've ever received.  The slaw that comes with the spicy fried chicken compliments it well, and while it's not the best Korean Fried Chicken I've had, I wouldn't mind getting it again.  The cheesy corn is something I don't tend to find very often, but I'm always down to get it if it is.  It's SO good!    And kimchee fried rice, why would you not order it...?

Come drunk, come sober, it really matters not, because I'm sure you'll enjoy it as much as I did!
author: Christopher L.

description: Are they suppose to specialize in fried chicken? If so, this place is a total failure. If you want Korean fried chicken, go somewhere else. As for the rest of the dishes, it's just ok.
author: Cindy T.

description:
got the Fried chicken in spicy tangy sauce.

I liked that the chicken was bonesless but didn;t like the lack of effort on the hot sauce and salad.  It did come with some nice pickeld daikon.

Otherwise this is just another boring late night spot.

I think if i were drunk this place would have gotten 5 stars.
author: Spanky M.

description:
This time, I had a good experience at Cocobang. 

I really liked tofu chigae. I think dishes at Cocobang is good if 

1. Drunk enough Shoju 
2. Super hungry 
3. Need Korean fix and to lazy to leave Union Square 

It's always cold inside. Bring sweater / jacket..
author: Chie J.

description:
We came here for some quick eats after some Tuesday night drinks - a good night since the drunks weren't out yet.  (Sidenote: As is necessary for all reviews of post-drinking establishments, the sobriety rating of this review is "buzzed" rather than "drunk.")

The bibimbap was just ok - sadly, it didn't come in a sizzling stone bowl so there were no crispy rice pieces.  The fried chicken was decent - crispy, sweet, and tangy, but not amazing like other places that specialize in Korean fried chicken..  There's big and bigger bottles of OB/Hite and soju to keep the party going long into the night.
author: Kevin W.

description: My favorite has got to be their military soup with the spicy kimchi! Just a really cool place to hit up on a late night while in SF. They usually have Korean music playing with videos projecting on the wall which is actually kinda cool;)
author: Paula A.

description:
Maybe this place was delicious because it was 3am and I was drunk.

Maybe. But I'll give it the benefit of the doubt. Came here last Saturday and ordered the soft tofu soup, chicken wings, dukbokki (rice cakes) and ramen in a spicy red sauce, and cheese corn. I was a little disappointed that they only had regular tofu soup and no beef tofu soup. However, the highlights were definitely the cheese corn and the dukbokki and ramen. The cheese corn comes with melted provolone cheese on top instead of your regular cheddar - yum. The sauce that accompanied the dukbokki and ramen was so, sooooo flavorful. I didn't get a chance to try the chicken wings.

Came out to $42 at the end. I left full and satisfied, and with no hangover the next morning thanks to my hearty 3am meal :) Definite recommend for a late-night drunken snack.
author: Anita C.

description:
Cocobang was my first experience with Korean BBQ and it was pretty delicious.  Pitchers which are really plastic 40s are pretty damn cool, so is the eminem music videos alternating with K-pop on the big projector.

The food is greasy, fried, and delicious.  Definitely left feeling tipsy, and satisfied.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Coco.... BANG I SHOT YOU WITH KOREAN FRIED CHICKEN GOODNESS.

Cocobang = drinking alcohol while ....... eating Korean food that pairs well with alcohol. Expect soju cocktails and crappy Korean beer. They offer lots of different foods but the star is their fried chicken.

First thing you notice is the projector TV set up near the ceiling playing kpop videos on a screen. While not providing the most stimulating of music, it certainly is entertaining to watch some of the borderline absurd plots these video run on.

DO TRY:
Garlic fried chicken.
Kimchi jun (uhhhh, green onion and kimchi pancake?)
yogurt soju

ONLY OK, TRY AT YOUR OWN VOLITION:
Fried chicken with hot & tangy sauce.

Four of us ordered all the above for dinner, were pretty full. It came down to $16 per person, which is CRAZY TALK usually for me when it comes to these kinds of Korean restaurants. And when I mean CRAZY TALK, I mean CHEAP. Usually I pay $20+.

Service was patient, nice, and competent. 

The bathroom is supposedly dirty? Didn't get to check it out myself.

Parking is impossible, obviously. SF seems to have an aversion to cars.

Booths are a little big, that could be good or bad depending on how close you want to sit together as a group and how many people you have.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Little korean restaurant that serves some legit korean bar food.  Surprisingly delicious and there were a bunch of cute korean chicks that seemed to frequent the place.  Just know that korean bar food can seem weird so make sure you know what you are getting into.  Everything best eaten with soju and beer.

Get: 
Chicken wings - standard korean take on wings, pretty dam great.  Spicy is very flavorful.  This is the MUST TRY of the menu.

Chicken gizzards - stir fried with good crunchy texture and flavor.

Pig knee/feet - delicious with some tasty sauces.
author: Steven F.

description: Been here several times. Worth every penny. Service was quick. Although the place is small, its warm and cheerful atmosphere quickly brightens your night. They have spectacular spicy dishes, and is perhaps one of the most authentic Korean restaurants in SF. Must order their rice cake in spicy sauce and kimchi fried rice. Overall cost for two people with alcohol $40+
author: Isabella D.

description:
Since this is the first time I've eaten Korean food, I won't be too harsh. The place itself was rather small, but that's not a bad thing. Had dinner with a friend here and ordered the bulgogi. I was expecting something new, different, something that I had never tasted before. i was a little disappointed. It tasted like a lot of stir frys that I have had other places. The food was not bad, but not the best either. 

The service was great though.
author: Lorth K.

description:
I never really realized that among Asians, individuals could either look more Korean or Chinese or Japanese or Vietnamese or etc, etc...

Maybe I am not very observant, but this simple fact just did not occur to me...until I started frequenting Korean restaurants.  From the 1st time I stepped foot into one, I have been bombarded by the hostess and waitstaff all speaking to me in endless Korean.  When I tell them I don't speak Korean...I have numerous times been scolded "Shame on you!" as they walk away shaking their heads. The first few times I was totally shocked and did not know what was up.  But when it happened to me with some of my Korean friends, they graciously explained to me that I look so Korean that the waitresses think I am an American-Born Korean that has grown up completely stripped of language and culture.  Pretty entertaining stuff huh?!

Because this has been somewhat of a neverending trend for me over the last decade, my love for Korean food has actually forced me to adapt to the situation.  After numerous failed attempts at trying to explain to waitresses that I am simply not Korean...I actually decided to make life easier and learn how to order in Korean.  From Bul-Go-Gi to Kal-Bi to Man-Du to Kim Chee Chi-gay to Kal-Gook-Su...I learned 'em all.

Since then, no more dirty looks from the waitstaff...and endless tastiness for me.  Double bonus.

One spot that I recently got to practice my ordering skills was Cocobang.  Kinda hole-in-the-wallish but conveniently located a few blocks off Union Square, this place hits the spot if you're craving some Korean fare.  My personal faves are the Duk-Buk-Ki, Chap-Chae, and Bi-Bim-Bop...sooooo good.

Check it out...Ahn-Young-Hee-Kay-Say-Yo.
author: Justin L.

description:
My friends told me it was called "Coq au Vin"..Hmm I thought, French? Sounds like a fantastic idea. Google Map it, nothing. We get there, and it's "Coco BANG", that's right BANG. Wow. 

Pictures of Chicken on windows, K-Pop SNSD music videos playing, stinky place, can't expect much, it's Cocobang, yo. It would be funny to see K-Rap to be honest. Ratio was 4 white people : 20 Koreans + 2 Mexican cooks. During our 30 minute wait some guy puked all over the floor. The place smelled like orange air fresher + chicken + puke. The waiters wanted to give us that table, really? We clearly saw that guy puke there and you cleaning it up right after. So we sat next to that table, but I felt really bad for the girls who sat on the puke table.  

We ordered bulgogi, kimchi, and Soju. The food was good, huge portions. After 6 shots of yogurt based peach Soju, oh man. Watch out with that soju, so powerful, it even gives you hiccups. My friend orders her food, and she asks "This is vegetarian right?", the waiter had no idea what she was freaking talking about and he replies "Yes, yes".  She says "no animals, right? ". He says "No no, ok I get for you, no egg, clams". He ends up bringing her plate full of clams and eggs, she almost fainted and had to send it back. Korean sneakiness: All the food brought out is billed regardless if the order was wrong.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
We stumbled in here after Katana-ya threatened to make us wait for a very long time for dinner. I was a little excited. They were playing Korean music videos on the back wall, and I was intrigued by all of the groups I've been missing since leaving Seoul. We ordered more food than two normal people should eat, and after getting the food, well, I was definitely unimpressed with the buldak. The fried chicken is pretty darn good, as I've confirmed with a follow up visit, but still not as good as anything at OB Chicken.

So sorry, Cocobang, but I'm just going to have to go with three stars. As in, if I want to go to an anju bar that is close by, sure, I'll come here. But I just don't think this place is as good as Toyose or OB Chicken, and really, if I'm going to put in effort to go to an anju bar, I might as well go to a very good one.
author: Angeline P.

description:
The bane of late-night eating is personified at Cocobang. 

TAKE AWAYS: 
- It's the place to eat ONLY if you're drunk. And only IF you got kicked out early...God have mercy if you left the bars at exactly 2am, because guess where everyone else is heading too? 
- The rice cake is very generous here. The kitchen is tiny, so try not to throw up (or...try to?) before the food comes. 
- The awesome K-Pop videos always give you an extra run for your money. 
- The prices reflect their late-night availability, so prepare to chalk up some money for okay Korean food. 

Bottom line, this place ain't going on the Food Network anytime soon, but that's how the locals and Asian Fobs like it.
author: Abel L.

description: OMG!  I love the Army Soup and Spicy rice cake with Ramen.  Better than LA and cheaper too.  Be prepared to wait as the place is not big.  Order a Hite and share it with the owner.  He is a great guy. Service Is good and food is good.  Will definitey be back next time we are in town!
author: al c.

description:
Fried chicken at a Korean Restaurant != Korean Fried Chicken.

This place was horrible:
1.  This is one of those places you only go to after a night of clubbing -- one of those places you would never consider having dinner at.  Think Mel's, Won Mi, Yuet Lee, New Sun Hong Kong.  Cocobang's is one of those places.
2.  Wait time at 2am was about 45 minutes
3.  Their fried chicken was horrible.  The day-old fried chicken at the Safeway is better.  The two-day old fried chicken at the Cala Foods is better.
4.  They have this spicy chicken dish which had zero flavor, yet was spicy as all hell.  I have no idea how they did that.  It's like they discovered the umami of spicyness.  This dish is simply not necessary.

Ok.  I've wasted enough time on Cocobang.
author: howie f.

description: I came here a couple times, the staff are always nice and wonderful. Ordered the kimchi fried rice and the tangy chicken. The chicken was great pretty juicy and flavorful. The kimchi fried rice on the other hand is not as great, it was pretty bland. Accompanied by the flavorful chicken, it is an okay combo.
author: Jay R.

description: I ordered kimchi hotpot and received top ramen noodles with cut up hotdogs and spam.  It was pretty gross.  But the chicken wings were pretty good and I liked the ambiance (cute K-pop music videos) playing on the screen.  Server was also pretty nice and the restaurant was full of actual Korean people so they must be doing something right. Maybe I just didn't order the right thing?
author: Meh C.

description: This is definitely my favorite korean restaurant that I've been to in SF so far, basically because of their sweet sauce marinated fried chicken.  We got the fire spicy chicken with cheese, potstickers, and 2 plates of fried chicken - one regular and one marinated in sweet sauce.  The fire spicy chicken was okay, but I'm not a huge fan of spicy food so I'm probably not the best person to review it.  However, I LOVED the sweet sauce marinated fried chicken.  I couldn't even stop eating it long enough to try the potstickers (so I also won't be reviewing that).  I'll definitely be back soon for more fried chicken!
author: Cici A.

description: Came here to sit down and eat! The last time I had Coco Bang I was not sober and it tasted amazing. This time I came sober and it tasted just as good so you know this place is good. It gets packed fast so get their first!
author: Clara H.
