description: Great food nice little spot, friendly service.  Spicy chicken, BBQ short rib, and clear noodles are a must.  Definitely a place that will be on my restaurant list when in town.
author: Steve A.

description: Came here because it was open late and my bf and I were starving after visiting twin peaks. Well, it's a hole in the wall place and I didn't really trust their cups and asked the guy for a straw and he tells me he doesn't have one but when my bf orders a soda he gets a can with a straw. (O.o) the food was okay, we ordered more than we could eat and ended up taking food home. There was Korean music blasting the whole time on the tv, it's nice but at 2-3am I'm trying to enjoy my food and go home, not trying to listen to all of that while trying to enjoy my meal.
author: Mim D.

description: Excellent Korean bbq, place is a small hole in the wall type. The food is a little bit overpriced. Every time I go I have to spend a good amount of money to leave satisfied. Nevertheless the food tastes very good and it is worth a try if you are in the area.
author: Walter Z.

description: It was late, my boyfriend and I were hungry and craving some good Korean food! We came up from Richmond after yelping a few spots. We waited outside because It was crowded, not much elbow space but The overall wait wasn't too bad. We ordered the potstickers, Korean bbq ribs & chicken wings. The food was super good!! We will deff be going back very soon. For those who haven't been there before, be sure to go inside and put your name on the waiting list!!
author: Rosie M.

description:
Maybe it's a white person thing, but I love going to ethnic restaurants where I'm the only table not of that ethnicity and not speaking that language.  I'm not a fan of wasting an evening in the avenues or the 'burbs for good Korean food, so Cocobang has a huge advantage on location while still getting the K-Pop blasting in the background.  The fruit juice soju cocktails come in carafe sizes, a real steal for $12.  The food is comforting and the hours are long, perfect for wrapping up a evening bender.

Corn & Cheese: Canned or frozen corn spread on a metal plate as if it were short ribs with a nondescript melted cheese on top.  Neither the corn nor the cheese was exceptional, but I enjoyed the Korean interpretation of corn sides which are actually treated like appetizers.

Kimchee Hot Pot: I suspect this is really budae jjigae due to the presence of hot dog and spam pieces.  Comes satisfactorily bubbling hot in a metal pot.  The spiciness cuts the fatty processed meats well.  There was even some noodles in there, though I felt they were a bit redundant given the rice bowl.

Fried Chicken w/ Spicy Sauce: Ever since BonChon in Manhattan, I have been drawn to KFC (Korean Fried Chicken).  The skin is not as crispy or complex or delicate here, but the generous dousing of thick red sauce easily helped me overcome that.  Less like wing sauce and more like the sauce in bi bim bap, the spicy and the fried are a perfect pair.  Most pieces are without bone except the wings and drumsticks, so you can eat without worrying about pulling a Mama Cass.
author: Adam B.

description: FOOD POISONING: I'll preface what I'm about to say with this: I've eaten at Cocobang probably 7-8 times or more over the past year and I've never had any problems. The food has been satisfying (especially as one of the few restaurants that open regularly until 2am or later) and the staff generally welcoming. All of that said, last night I ordered the BBQ combo with chicken and beef bulgogi... I'll spare you the details, but let's just say I had some pretty bad food poisoning within several hours. I hadn't eaten for 8 hours prior to this, so I'm 99% positive it was Cocobang - something about the beef just tasted off. My guess is that the meat that they use is simply not fresh at all, and perhaps it's been sitting out unrefrigerated the whole day. Whatever it was, I couldn't keep the food down. If you've been lucky enough to dine here and not feel like death just sucker-punched you in the gut, then this is just a friendly warning to you. I'm disappointed - I used to be a pretty big fan of Cocobang up until now.
author: Taylor C.

description:
While shopping in downtown, the bf & I were told to meet up at Cocobang with a group of friends..I was like wtf is Cocobang?  Yelped it on his Iphone..oo Korean food.  Big Bang..Cocobang..yeah..okay..?  At first I was hesitant because Korean food is usually kinda pricey (I'm soo used to cheap Chinese food).  

Friday night around 8, party of 5.  Split (food was already decided upon my arrival): 1 seafood pancake, 1 order of fried chicken wings with sweet & spicy sauce, 1 order of beef bibimbap, 1 combo order..some beef & beef kalbi ribs, individual bowls of rice, 1 HUGE (1.5L?) bottle of OB, & a bottle of soju = $99.

They also served complimentary appetizer stuff like kimchee and some tofu.  I enjoyed the chicken wings & the kalbi ribs.  The seafood pancake after my bf picked out the calamari for me was good.  Bibimbap was okay. Our waiter was friendly & attentive.  The place is pretty small & gets pretty busy.  Bored when you're waiting for your food?  The projector playing kpop music videos on the wall does give you something to look at.  The area as others have said the area's kind of sketchy too.  If I was in the mood for some Korean food and in downtown already I may come back here but wouldn't make a special trip out.
author: Cat C.

description: LOVE CocoBang!  My friend and I stumbled upon this place after two hours of searching for something to eat. The food was AWESOME, atmosphere was great and the Strawberry Soju drink was Yumo! We will definitely go back!
author: Katie L.

description: This place shoudl be called Coco-closed.  Not sure why the reviews are so high... maybe cuz the reviewers are drunk as the place is open late. If you are not drunk, you probably won;t enjoy this place.  go elsewhere.  the Sushi place around the corner is awesome, open til 11:15 or 12:15 weekends.  Sakana..
author: Michael C.

description: Very delicious!! Order the army soup and yang nyum chicken! Also order the corn cheese! Small restaurant but worth the wait! Open til 4 am so perfect for after bars!
author: Jenn W.

description: Yummy food  and fast service  Prices are also very good compare to amount of food
author: Dorota S.

description:
I came here last Friday around 8pm. I have never really took notice of this place even though I live only 2 blocks away. It is kind of a hole in the wall. It was less than half capacity. Very Korean looking interior even though I have only been to one other Korean place. 

My friend and I already ate dinner so we just ordered drinks. Two yogurt soju. It was definitely too much for two people. We played a drinking game while everyone else was still eating dinner. I thought that was funny.

The yogurt soju was pretty good. Would like to come back for the food one day.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Ugh this place sucks. They serve ok Korean food, it's only ok in SF. If they were in LA Koreatown, they would have gone out of business in a month.

If you are expecting good decent banchan(side dish), this is not the right place.
They give three small side dish and I never really even touch them. 

Their spicy rice cake dish has maybe 10 pieces of rice cakes, it's not worth for the price. Also too salty and too sweet, make sure you asked for less sugar. 
Spicy tofu soup was alright, if you have to eat here, I would recommend this.
Fried chicken with green onion was alright, sauce is again too sweet, but edible. I believe they use low quality chicken. It has weird smell from meat. I wouldn't get it again.

I have been here a few times and young people who work here are nice. The big problems is the guy who owns this place. He is rude and has no respect to the customers. We ordered four items and one of them is not coming out when everyone else is finishing up food. I called and asked him why one of our order is not coming out yet. Without giving any apologies, he claimed that he only heard three items(ah we are the first customers, so store was not busy at all, he has a plenty of time to check our order.). He was rather lecturing us that he did everything right. He was annoyed that we are correcting his mistake, wow! My friend was hungry, so we decided to wait. Super blend bulgogi bowl came out, again no apologies. My friend waited for over 40 minutes and also had to bare with his attitude problem. Of course, he charged for everything despite of his mistake. I can't believe we still paid him about 20% tips(he must feel grateful). But, he lost four of us and friends of our(potential customers) for good. I will never go back.
(Ah, I was not expecting a discout, BUT I expected the guy who took our order to give an apology that he made my friend waited for 40 minutes and admit that he made a mistake. He obviously ignored our table after we pointed out his mistake. When we asked for bill, he ignored first and when we asked for bill again he looked at our table with face and told us " "= literal translation is ok ok, but with attitude that he is clearly annoyed.)
author: Anna H.

description: First time at Coco Bang,  Ran into this place walking the neighborhood from the hotel on Union Square, This place is Authentically Delicious everything looks good from the menu to the plate on the table. I ordered the Fried Chicken hot and tangy sauce so good im going back tonight to try another plate.The staff was friendly and helpful. Great place to eat for Korean Food. Did I mention this place is open super late my kind of place especially if you have late night munchies.
author: Anthony Z.

description:
First thing, you KNOW I'm buzzed when I start laughing at the stupidest things. So they play these Korean videos on the wall and for some reason there was this boy band singing and dancing and I couldn't stop laughing because of their hair cuts. They had the PERFECT bowl haircuts ever. It looked like that one Jack and the Box commercial where everyone had a bowl cut. LMAO ok on to the review.

A good late night place if you're craving Korean food or if you're trying to soak up your alcohol from the bar or club. I think this place has potential but it's not really living up to it. I feel like the interior of the restaurant could use a lot of cleaning. The tables were all spread apart and the stairs leading to the bathroom was so sticky. Also, you can see all their stock of drinks and products against the wall which makes it look even more unclean.

I ordered the spicy and sweet chicken wings. It was pretty spicy and was drenched in sauce. I think if I ordered it plain, I would have enjoyed it a lot more. Don't get me wrong, it was good but I think for me it would have tasted better with all that sauce. My partner in crime ordered the bibimbap. The meat wasn't marinated that well and lacked flavor but the whole dish itself was not bad. 

Yogurt soju tasted so good. This was my first time having it and I've read and heard people say that you can drink a whole liter full like its juice and not realize your drunk til the end. I drank enough to get me buzzed. That's when random things started getting funny. We had the strawberry one and it tasted like juice so I knew I had to limit my drinking. Plus I was driving.

I'll come here if I'm craving Korean food at night or if Kitana-Ya has a long line and don't wanna wait.
author: Fran N.

description: I love korean food! Going in, I didn't have very high expectations since I heard the food is excellent when drunk but only mediocre when sober. We ordered a variety of Korean dishes: Galbi, bulgogi, bibimbap, soondubu, fried chicken, and pajun. nothing was super spectacular, but everything tasted just fine. 3 stars for A-OK.
author: Annie Z.

description: The spicy chicken is amazing. It's hot.. And full of flavor. It's a small space but they have a pretty fast turnover. Good service, great food.
author: Jordan E.

description:
Supposedly a great place to get late night drunken eats, but I've never done the post club hours Cocobang run and I dig it, so giving it a try sober is just as legit in my book.

Besides how else would you enjoy the huge liter bottles of Korean beer? Order their spicy chicken wings over the regular, and a couple of sides (sondubu and kimchi fried rice are my recs), bring a couple of friends and walk around in Union Square afterwards. A fun night in downtown SF will ensue.

Oh and their display of K-Pop videos on the big screen never disappoint. I dance so it's great to watch choreo and singers toting cutesie outfits while waiting for the food, which never takes too long to be prepared.
author: Geralyn Y.

description: After leaving Ryoko's hungry despite a ridiculous $45 tab for two (tiny, mediocre sushi rolls and sashimi), my boyfriend and I wanted to fill ourselves up and luckily found Cocobang across the street at 1am! We got ordered the large-size hot and spicy wings, which weren't that spicy, but still flavorful. We also ordered the yogurt soju which tasted just like the Yakult asian yogurt--sweet except now with creeper abilities. In retrospect, I would try a different wing flavor since I like sweeter wings. 4 stars for Cocobang. I'll be coming back.
author: M. M.

description: Great late night place to eat after a night drinking. The food is very mediocre but you wouldnt care too much at this time. I wouldnt come during any other time as there are so many better places. The staff is friendly and quick.
author: Dang L.

description:
*VEGETARIAN REVIEW*

Oh Cocobang,
I love you because I love Korean food and the fact that you're open late & play amazing Korean music videos which keep me happy & entertained,
But there is a couple of things that don't work for me -
Menu is not very vegetarian friendly at all, but they will omit meat (at least for Kimichi Fried Rice) if you ask. Also the quality of the Kimichi fried rice varies...sometimes they do serve it with the sesame seeds & seaweed garnish and sometimes they dont which makes me sad ;(.
But disregarding the garnish situation, the dish really is delicious. They make their Kimichi fried rice VERY spicy & flavorful & that's just the way I like my food!
Another hiccup happened with Cocobang is when I tried their Peach Soju...
I honestly can't believe that anyone likes this stuff!
It was so overly sweet & had such a overwhelming chemical taste that I had to dilute it with water to be able to stomach it & still couldn't finish the pot & I LOVE TO DRINK LOL!
maybe i'll try another flavour of their soju again but I am a little scared but still choose to believe that I just picked the wrong falvour bc I am a positive person :O)
Anyways I'ma keep coming back though until me and my bf find another convenient Korean restaurant to go to, but for now Cocobang HITS THE SPOT!
author: Zhenya S.

description: Came across this place after Ruby Skye (they're open late!). We tried the sweet & sour fried chicken...it's your average drunk food. Their portions are pretty generous, and the chicken was a little too sweet that we could barely finish it between the 3 of us. Fun place for soju and munchies!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I'm addicted. That is about all I can say. Their friend chicken is to die for. They also have a pretty gluten-free menu which is nice if you're trying to be healthy.
author: Jocelyn D.

description: The 4 stars is for staying open to 4am and for the very good kalbi and korean army stew with spam and hot dogs and ramen.
author: N A.

description:
I have always thought that, with a very few (to be exact, two) exceptions almost all of the Korean spots in SF are either overrated, overpriced or both.  This includes San Franciscans' pride and joy, Brothers Restaurant, which, unfortunately, IS overrated, overpriced and does not hold a candle to say, Choi's Kitchen in Sunnyvale or Myung Dong Tofu Cabin in the Peninsula. 

So I was less than thrilled, to say the least, when suggestion to go grab post-Rickhouse-cocktail late-night grub at this Korean bar in the ever-so-colorful 'Loin came up.  But it was late at night, everyone was famished and choices around the area were limited.  

The menu looks standard enough: BBQed meat, Korean fried chicken, Kim Chee soup and such.  But boy were they surprisingly tasty! We had fried chicken with sweet and spicy sticky sauce (half serving is plenty for 3), kim chee fried rice that had a lot of meat and not too much limp cabbage, and Budae Jigae that is almost as tasty as the version they serve at Toyose! 

Everything that we had hit the spot, absorbed the excess rum from the caipirinha, and prepped us for the next round of drinking at Mr. Smith's.
author: Ange L.

description: I love this place!  Their fried chicken is one to be remembered, crispy and not greasy.  Their kimchi anything is delish and the service is always on point and courtious.  It's our hidden gem, that's close enough to union square, but far enough to not be touristy.
author: Casie M.

description: Being from down in the Peninsula, I've always heard great things about Cocobang up in the city and finally got a chance to hit it up. Loved the atmosphere and was ready to dig into some delicious looking kimchi-jun and chicken when... my wife almost bit into a 1" piece of broken stone pot in the kimchi-jun. No kidding. It was so bad, I actually felt pity on the restaurant workers, but I had to ask for an explanation. Supposedly the batter for the jun is pre-made and last night they broke a stone pot in the kitchen... They made us a new one from fresh batter but nothing tasted very good after an incident like that. We're not going back here again.
author: Sokokyu K.

description:
No idea why I haven't found this place before!

If you've been reading my reviews, you'll know that I've been trekking out to Toyose for that authentic, burning-your-stomach-good Korean beer food -- pretty much in the middle of the Pacific Ocean as far as I'm concerned. (45th and Noriega, in case you were wondering.)

And Toyose is *great*, so when I stepped in here on a Saturday night after getting rebuffed at Katana-ya and their long line, I wasn't expecting a worthy substitute. But it was.

It was just the two of us, so we couldn't try everything, but here's what we got:

- japchae (a "small plate")
- bul dak (fire chicken) with cheese
- odeng tang (fish cake soup), spicy
- mango soju cocktail

Yeah.. it was way too much. It was all good, except for the bul dak could have been (heat) hotter. It ended up getting all goopy at the end and the cheese congealed way too fast. (try OB Chicken in Oakland Temescal for a better version of this.)

We ended up stuffed beyond all recognition and we still took some japchae home in a box.

But considering I don't have to waste 40 minutes of my life on the 71 just to get here - I like it a lot, and I'll be back to try the fried chicken and the budechigae!
author: Josh K.

description:
This is not too exciting a place. This is what I remember:
-Wings are pretty good.
-Rice cake with ramen was alright. The ramen was the same kind as the Shin packaged ramen but maybe it's supposed to be like that.
-Kimchee fried rice was a pass. Nothing special except the fried egg, but I can make that at home, thanks.
-Cheesy corn is a rip off. Canned corn with cheese for seven bucks?? My sister was suckered!
-Soju was good.
-Side dishes or what I think they were trying to pass off as banchan was kind of.. pathetic.
-Service was patchy. Politely rude, I'd have to say. I was totally ignored by more than one server on more than a couple occasions when I tried to tell them that a chair still had a huge chunk of food on it. They seemed more interested in breezing about the restaurant not making eye contact. I ended up flicking it off the chair myself because they kept pushing the chair in closer to me when I was trying to keep my clothes from getting dirty.
Overall, ok food, and the restaurant stays open pretty late. A little pricey.
Would I go back? If I'm seriously craving Korean food late at night, maybe.
author: Karen C.

description:
Notice this place while driving by looking for a space a couple months ago.  Debating what to eat last night, I knew this was the place when we drove by again.  After going around a couple times, we found parking less than 2 blocks away.  

The place is small and dark with music video playing - almost feel like a lounge but not quite, I actually wish it was.  Anyway, we sat at one of the smaller table for 2 (if you plan to order 3 dishes, be aware you will be space challenged) and started checking out the menu.  Many dishes sounded good and we didn't know what some items were.  After much debate, we decided on:

fried chicken wings w/ sweet & spicy sauce - $7.95 - really good fried chicken wings, would be good w/o any sauce.  not oil, very crispy and not a lot of batter.  I like the sauce too and it came with a heaping side of slaw (thinly slice cabbage w/ like a Thousand Island dressing).   

homemade thick noodle soup - $10.95 - this was ok, we didn't know what to expect but wanted the homemade noodle.  the noodle itself was good but the whole thing wasn't very tasty.  i had asked for it to be spicy and i think he forgot.  the broth was a little thick and cream color - some sliced squash, carrots and potato and about 10 small white clams.  I think the potato may have been the thickening agent for the broth?  

pan fried chicken gizzard - $10.95 - delicious!  it was served on a sizzling platter, all gizzards with slices of onion, green onion and many many whole cloves of garlic that were simply melts in the mouth.  I know because I had quite a few and the garlic breath this morning was no joke!  If you love gizzard, this is a must - a perfect dish to munch with ice cold beer while enjoying the music videos.

2 draft - $2.50each - domestic but not sure what it was.  $3 for imported.

Overall, I love the ambience and really enjoyed the music videos.  It is a good mix of American and many Korean with mostly dance like music that was played pretty loud, which I didn't mind a bit!  

When my crazy sister visits next time, I'll be sure to bring her here because I know she'll love the place!
author: Gloria H.

description: The wings were very good. I stuffed myself. When we arrived it was full but they offered to call me when a table was ready so we could walk around. The good came out very quickly and tasted hot and fresh.
author: Matt D.

description: late night drunk food... the kimchi fried rice is pretty good.
author: Mike L.

description:
Argh Dont come here ever after 12 am!! 
The customers are drunk, loud and rude....the waiters are also drunk and are incapable of speaking good english...they hardly know their food!! Plus the food arent good at all...like seriously i would never come here again past midnight, and i dont think ill ever be drunk enough to say that the food here is good....so not my taste:(
author: Cavin T.

description: Awesome Korean food! Totally filled my craving. The soon doo bu is delicious! Lots of soft tofu with a great broth. The egg is poached perfectly - half runny. Get the spicy fried chicken. Huge chucks of chicken with a spicy and tangy sauce. The pan fried calamari/octopus with somen is really awesome too. Great flavoring!
author: Sherry L.

description:
The best thing about this place is the location and hours.
I don't know about the food quality and the service. 
Cocobang is the only Korean place that opens late in SF downtown, so you have no choice. 

This place gets really packed on weekend nights. You will have to wait in line to get in. The place is also very small, crowded, and full of loud people.
author: Naomi L.

description:
A disappointing experience.  I honestly didn't mind sitting at a table surrounded by Korean beer girl ads, or the slow but friendly service, or having to endure Clay Aiken in concert on the big screen tv above.  No, none of that really bothered me.  I wouldn't be complaining if not for the food.

Two item bento box with spicy fire chicken and beef bulgogi.  The bulgogi was decent, but the chicken was not very spicy?  Intensely chewy strips of chicken (much of it burned), covered in an unappetizing red sauce.  With a small portion of kimchee and other panchan on the side.  

Bibimbap- the regular type, not in a stone bowl (dol sot, yes?).  Half a bowl of lukewarm rice with what looked like the same panchan mixed in.  A big ripoff, if you ask me.

Cocobang might be a nice choice for late night or for some snacks to go with your soju, but don't go in expecting a quality Korean meal.
author: Joanne G.

description:
The aromas wafting out to the street smell amazing and are what drew us in.

Initially, we were slightly put off by the waiter that opened the door for us then closed it back in our faces after asking how many were in our party. Was he preparing a table for us? Were we expected to wait outside in the cold? After a few minutes of confusion, he led us in and we reasoned that maybe the place was too small for us to have waited inside. Still, an explanation would've been nice.

Luckily the food was better than the service. We got the combination bbq (that comes with rice, kimchi, bean sprouts, and fish cake) and chose bulgolgi and spicy pork for the 2 meats. A little lacking in the side dish options, but the tables were so small we couldn't have fit more anyways. We also got the spicy kimchi stew to share. That came with spam, rice cakes, and ramen (judging from sight--my taste buds were on fire so I couldn't have told you the difference). Both the stew and bbq came in very generous portions and were more than enough for 2 guys and me--and I can eat as much as a guy! 

And the waiter that closed the door in our faces greatly redeemed himself by recommending us the kiwi soju, which isn't on the menu. So yummy, like fruity Starburst candy! Down a few carafes of that and you won't taste a drop of alcohol, but I'm sure you'll feel a buzz going! And the OB beer comes in a GIANT plastic bottle. 

We came here for food to prepare us for the night of drinking ahead, but the flavored sojus and giant beer bottles, coupled with the kpop-blasting, typical Korean bar atmosphere, led us to start the pre-partying here too.
author: Yang Q.

description: I'm always drunk when I come here, so it's hard for me to leave an objective review. I'm a diehard fan of their kimchi chicken wings. (Always get rice to go with it, or else your mouth will be on fire for the rest of the night.) Coupled with the fact that they're open 'til 4 in the morning, this place is my go-to after an overpriced night of drinking in Union Square.
author: L D.

description:
There's certainly no "bang" in their food. Once in awhile I love to eat spicy food and Korean food is generally spicy. One of our orders was a plate of "spicy chicken wings". Hardly spicy at all. And what they call soju seems like juice with a little bit of that "alcohol taste" to it. I'm far from being an alcoholic, but if I was able to almost finish the whole jug without slightly being tipsy, there's something wrong.

Oh. And I found it funny hearing some tagalog being spoken on the radio station they were playing at the restaurant.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
They got some good spicy chicken and rice cakes. It is just like the food they serve in Korea. Reminds me of the po-chang-ma-cha feeling. It's definitely a place worth trying if you are into chicken and korean bbq. The only downside is, the place is just too small and it barely seats about 20 people or so. 
It's very hard to get a seat on a Friday or Saturday night. We made a reservation, but still had to wait another 20-30 minutes longer after our reservation time to get a seat.
author: Dave K.

description:
are you drunk in the tenderloin? trying to look for a place to eat and found that the wait at Ryoko's is just too long? then walk on over to Cocobang!! nice spot for drunk snack foods.  had korean fried chicken with the sweet and spicy sauce on the side, french fries, and yogurt soju. i knocked it down a star just because the fries were mediocre and i happen to think i'm a fry connoisseur.  

total bill came out to $31.  not bad for the 'hood.
author: Tina L.

description:
Trust me I have been here so many times since it's pretty close to my door and we usually have a weird hunger for Korean food at late night. I bet the waiter knows us and expect him to treat his lovely loyal customers well BUT NO he doesn't. The waitress is hella rude and mean. He always throw the food at us. There was once when we ordered something and we changed on something else and he looked at us like "WTF is wrong with these people?" Seriously???

The food is okay. My favorite is Bibimbap. It's good - even though Bibimbap is good everywhere. Tofu Soup is okay and no beef? Kimchee Hot Pot Stew is a bit better than Tofu Soup. Bulgogi and Tteokbokki are okays for a restaurant style. I can make it like those.

If you eat there late night like us, you better expect to wait there for 1 hour for a table. Or like us later, just buy to-go - quick, easy, and you don't have to deal with the mean waiter.
author: Tran N.

description:
THIS PLACE IS THE SHET.

forrealskis. i LOVE this place and so do my friends.

discovered it because it was two blocks from my old abode and reminded me a slice of good old flushing, queens and the homies back home. 

it's a korean bar. with posters of hyori modelng soju and a gigantic projection screen running kpop videos and concert snippets on repeat. but tell me, what good korean bar DOESN'T have that? they've got soju (chameesul) and OB by the "pitcher" aka HUGE plastic bottle. they've got flavored soju (yogurt = best). they've got your ddukbokgee, kalbi, etcetc. but the CHICKEN is where it's at. the whole. spicy. comes with shredded cabbage topped with that ketchup/mayo combo mix dressing. mmmMmmmMmMMMm

so perfect to start off the night, or more likely than not.. END your night. get there a little before 2am so they can serve you some soj. order some foods too, since they're open til 4am on sat & sun, but of course the soj gotta go byebye at 2.. so drink fast. 

service is always always so awesome. they're great. really!!!!!!!
author: Yui K.

description:
Everything is just kind of meh meh meh.  Food, service, prices - I have found so much better all over the place.  I am not that impressed after three visits.  The service is anemic at best - there is no enthusiasm left in the place, really and that drab, lassaiz-faire energy travels like a virus; affecting staff, service, dining room maintenance, and of course it affects the level of food quality.

The banchan are of particularly lame quality - BIG NO-NO for a Korean restaurant!  The sides served at a Korean restaurant meal should reflect the care put into the operation as a whole.  These tasted like they were scooped out of a deli container, delivered from a central processing source.  Big turn off....sigh.

I don't think the chicken is really that amazing and the other things I've tried are just unremarkable.  Its like this place was once probably awesome but now its just kind of lazily maintained, just making money and never pushing the envelope to improve itself.  So I won't be going anymore.  I generously gave this restaurant three visits, I really wanted to like it - as it was a convenient location for a Korean meal in the area.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Meh. Food was decent but nothing out of this world. Like every other Korean place in the city I found it overpriced.
Service is mediocre at best and I kept getting nasty looks from the waitress for a reason that totally eludes me. And the number of seats is quite limited.
The only plus really is that they open late.
author: Vithiet L.

description:
I have passed by this place a couple of times and kind of brushed it off as pseudo Korean because their bi bim bap is not served in a dolsot (stone pot bowl.)

"Never knock it until you try it" mantra is applicable here. My girlfriend and I decided to give it a try. The portions are generous.

Fried chicken: worth a try (don't compare it to San Tung or So, it's totally different.)

Octopus noodle: very flavorful 

Spicy tofu soup: equally rich with flavors

I guess my low expectations were quell after our meal (and some left overs for brunch the next day) or we were soo hungry, a deep fried turd sandwich would have been suffice.
author: Tony N.

description: My friend and I came here on 6-1-14 1:40am'sh, after hanging out at Pandora.  Decent food, gave us complimentary corn with cheese.  Service was attentive.
author: Jer W.

description:
Love how they project Korean music videos on the wall.  I can munch, chat, and watch some cute Korean boys dance on screen.

This place is tiny and even at 6:30pm on a thursday night, it's packed.  They serve typical Korean bar food and soju.  You come here to drink and munch so don't be expecting eye pleasing food or surprising new flavors.  The fried chicken, kimchi pajeon, and duboki are not bad, not bad at all.  Skip the soondae stir-fry...the soondae had a weird spongy texture that grossed me out and had a weird aftertaste.  I can't remember what else we ordered, but overall the food was ok.

I'd be back because this is a type of place where it'd be fun to catch up with friends, chit chat, and munch away.
author: C A.

description: Best fried chicken in all of San Francisco- they are open late too!
author: Chris L.

description:
1) they didnt serve the food all at once.  first they served one plate.  15 minutes later another.  then the rice.  then 10 minutes later another.  
2) food wasnt really that great.  ordered some fried chicken, some squid, and some spicy chicken.  really truly, the quality and flavorings of the food makes me say the true price of the food should be half the price.  

the dude with the tight shirt that was taking orders and serving foods was a moron and looked like a kpop dude that would get his ass kicked in any real life situation.  what are you stupid?  why would i have to remind you to bring me my rice.  probably too busy fantasising about gackt.  ill never go here again.

there was also a puddle of some liquid spilled all over the floor and nobody mopped it up.  keep it classy, ya lazy bastards!
author: Peter N.

description:
Great late night spot for Korean fried chicken.  Been here twice, both times competing with the late night crowd trying to soak up the alcohol in their bellies while at the same time, supplementing with Hite and soju.  

We ordered the fire chicken, since after the first visit it was pretty awesome, unless we were just blasted drunk.  On this occasion, it wasn't as i remembered.  This chicken was caked with the fire seasoning.  Similar to women who attempt to hide their disfigured faces under layers of cover up and eyeliner, resulting in a disappointed male counterpart....this was the same thing but with chicken wings and a drunk group of guys, if that makes any sense.  Pasty and gritty, i couldn't tell if the texture i was experiencing was the crispness of the fried chicken or the gritty fire seasoning.  Although to a normal person, this chicken would be borderline unpalatable, but for us belligerent drunks trying to get our lives in line before the arduous journey home, this kinda hit the spot.  

Will we be back, probably, as it's one of our main late night spots at the moment.  Luckily on both visits, we had a Korean speaking friend who rubbed elbows with the servers, so we're on the inside!
author: Michael N.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed this location because it was only a block away from the JW Hotel. 

The spicy fried chicken ( yang nyum tongdak) is really good, so is the rice cakes ( tokbokki), the potstickers(), the kimchi fried rice.

I'd go back here when I have to stay at the hotel again.

It's really small, be prepared to wait for awhile. We ended up getting some of the food to go.

dang. now im definitely craving some of their food. :)
author: S Y.

description:
This is basically korean bar food, a bit more expensive than I'd like but with all the kpop on the screens, the soju, and fried chicken, we always end up having a good time.

It's pretty small but they've always been able to seat us in large groups, so +1 for that!
author: Yingjue C.

description: Not bad at all.  The wait to be seated was a bit too long, and the food was not really worth the wait.  Meh.
author: TheLaborLawGuy L.

description: Their yangyum chicken is yum yum and it has a good balance with cabbage salad. The ambience is nice for a simple night out with few friends and the service is pretty good. We had pretty easy going experience every time and would return again when we can.
author: Erik And Sarah Z.

description: Fried chicken with tamarine and Da Best!!  ther stuffs are ok.   If u want a late night dinner with soju here is a place to be.
author: Ben C.

description:
Best Korean place in the TL/downtown area.  If you want to splurge and get some deep fried goodness in your mouth, you have to get the Fried Chicken plate.

Also the spicy rice cakes are awesome, dupolki!  

As you dine, you can watch the amazing K-Pop videos playing on the wall.  It's amazingly Korean.
author: Wenter S.

description:
Cocobang is the closest I can get to good yang nyum chicken in SF.  And best of all, they're open until 4 am on Fri & Sat nights.  LOVE IT.  Finally found a place that understands my drunken need for a Korean fix at 3 in the morning.

It's definitely not the best Korean food in SF, but boozers can't be choosers.  My favorites are the yang nyum chicken and spicy rice cake w/ ramen.  The rest of the menu is dismissable, but I still stand firm in my ethnocentric view that Koreans make the best bar food.

Just beware of the projector that plays K-pop performances all night long.  Yes, it's as scary as it sounds.
author: Jen L.

description: Maybe we came here on an off night?  Other folks seem to love this place, but the entire meal had a sickeningly sweet taste that turned me off.  Maybe too much kimchi.  The tiny fruit flies also didn't inspire.
author: Kim K.

description:
Not sure that I would come here for future dinners, perhaps lunch or quick snack. I don't particular like Korean/Japanese bands whose music resemble adolescence with little training in singing (this place plays music variety shows of that calibre). 

As for the food, it was pretty good, although it only merits three stars. There's something about pork and it's oh so delicious fat combines with pretty any seasoning, with the Koreans - it's either barbeque, sweet, or spicey (the pork I had, had all of that, it was delcious). Pork is so universal, I liked it because it resembled a dish the Chinese make where pork (which can be fresh or pre cooked; which with pre cooked - the pork is roasted until the skin is crisp) is steamed with shrimp preserves (sort of like preserving tuna in sea salt) - heaven! 

We also ordered the beef (boulogi?), MMMMMM melted in my mouth.

The highlight of the night was the spicey tofu soup (fresh tofu, clams, and egg), it was pretty spicey, but was delicious.
author: Alex C.

description:
Thank goodness this place is open after the bars close. I was drunk and hungry -- and I'd eat Korean drunchies any day over some fast food joint.

It was crowded at 2am on a Friday. No surprise there. The place is pretty small, only holds about 10 tables. For a table for 2, we had to wait about 5-10 minutes. Had some Kalbi bento box type dish. Not the best, but again, at 2am, almost anything tastes good. The K-Pop videos playing on the large screen in the back of the restaurant kept us entertained while we devoured our food.

At one point, someone in the restaurant ordered a clam dish, and soon the entire restaurant smelled like clams. Not my favorite, but the smell wen away pretty quickly.

By no means is this a glamorous restaurant, but it will suffice for anyone hungry after 2am on a weekend.
author: Patricia Y.

description:
On a rainy day in SF, we found this place when the ramen place we wanted to go to was closed. This korean place was pretty small but was able to accommodate our party of about 8. The server was friendly and gave pretty good service considering they were busy. 

Several plates were ordered but I would like to comment on my spicy tofu soup. I appreciated that it was super hot and boiling - I've been to places where the soondubu was not that warm even in the clay pot. The taste was great and the spicyness was just how I like it.

There isn't anything super special to say about this place but it hit the spot when we were starving. It was also enjoyable to watch the K-Pop stars as we were eating - making the korean experience more complete.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Okay, the only positive things this place has going are that it is open late, and the soju is super amazingly tasty. The restaurant itself is slightly small, and the service was friendly enough. We came pretty late so parking was easily found right in front of the restaurant.

I got the bibimbap. It was just average. There is really nothing remarkable I can say. The meat in there was pretty bland/ lacking in flavor. I was kind of sad, really. They really lack selection of ban chan. There was only like, 3 or 4 types of stuff.. Kimchi, radishes, and I think fish cake. 

Their chicken wings weren't bad, but the sweet and spicy sauce was not working for me. Its not that it was spicy, but the flavor itself wasn't that great. The chicken wings were TOTALLY drenched in it too. Way too much sauce. 

I wouldnt recommend this place during the day, when so many better places are open. But if its late, and you're hungry, then give this a shot. Fast food can get old, fast. I can see this place being popular for someone just coming from the bar, so if you've been drinking and are in the area, give it a shot. Otherwise, I recommend trying Moms tofu house in South City.
author: Alison A.

description:
I came here on a Friday night with my coworker/her hubby/friends and I really can't stay anything bad about this place!

its open till late, serves korean food (can't complain about that!), is packed on a friday night, and... what better way to end your night than to watch kpop videos and sit by a table with a guy jammin and showing his dance moves! LOL!!

I will def come back here..:)
author: Christina D.

description:
Came by here with some friends after clubbing at Vessel.  The food was mediocre and not very memorable.

We ordered a bibimbap and a bugolgi.  The bibimbap came in a plastic bowl so there wasn't any crispy rice and one of my friends mentioned the egg tasted a little chewy.
author: Janice C.

description: Sad that there s no other good Korean place in this neighborhood. But this place makes some mean wings that can really beat the American style wings. I also got chapchae but the dish was a bit salty. My parent got sizzling spicy pork which they loved. Overall solid place. Wish that they would open for lunch
author: Heidi N.

description:
The food here is decent for late night dining. The spicy rice cakes were yummy and a bit on the hotter side. Other than that, their bibimbap is served in a regular rice bowl so it is missing a bit of the crispy rice taste to it. Otherwise, it's not bad at all. 

Downside to this place is that it is pretty popular for late dining so we had to wait a bit for a table. The place isn't big and seats about 50 people. I would recommend this place for late night Korean food cravings.
author: Eva Y.

description: Late night Korean food, just like I used to have back in LA.  It's solid food that's great to eat after a night of drinking.  The fried chicken dish was quite good.  Wasn't big on their soon dobu, though.  The service is fine.  Expect a wait any weekend night after 1:30am.
author: Thai D.

description:
The food was great and the service was phenomenal. I had the bibimbap and it was very tasty. Unfortunately, it wasn't served in a hot stone bowl so no crispy rice at the bottom. If it was, I would've given it 5 stars. 

Seating is very limited.
author: Richard M.

description:
i love munching on their chicken late at night-- i've had the spicy and tangy (not actually spicy) and the soy garlic (not on the menu but you can request it!). I prefer the soy garlic but I've had friends who liked both equally. The last time we went we also ordered the ddukbokki (which is actually spicy) which complemented the chicken well. 

good (not bland) food, decent pricing. tip: don't wear nice clothes because you will smell when you walk out of there!
author: Elysia A.

description:
Great vibe, one of the dudes who works there, Shawn, is awesome.  

Great fried chicken, love the one with the firebutt sauce.  You can ask for boneless!  That alone is worth 5 stars.  The korean pancake is okay, wish it was crispier.  Japchae is yummy, although cannot order vegetarian (since I don't eat seafood).  They have some awesome flavored soju.  Parking = pain in the poon.  

Accommodated our table of 10 with 30 minutes notice.  EXCELLENT.
author: Dong T.

description:
This place is good for late night eating if your in the city....I usually would pay a visit to this place when I'm visiting Sf because I crave the KFC...KFC= korean fried chicken...

The two main dishes I get are the spicy chicken wings and corn cheese... The spicy wings are by far my favorite dish at this place.Its actually not spicy at all, but the flavor is tasty....Corn cheese sounds like a very weird combination, but it compliment each other pretty well and is very popular at korean restaurants....
author: Dustin Brawler P.

description:
This place is clearly managed pretty poorly. Do NOT eat here if you have a food allergy.

Got in to this place for the first (and last) time on a wednesday night around 9pm, waited 30min for a table, but got to watch a projection of k/jpop music videos up on the wall while waiting, so it wasn't that bad.

When we were seated, we were each given a glass of water in small, cheap looking plastic glasses. Normally I wouldn't care, but the water tasted like soap which was pretty gross. 

Ordered a tea for me and a beer for my girlfriend, and from there everything went downhill. I have a gluten allergy, it's a serious deal, and I made sure to mention it to the server. I was greeted with a blank stare (untrained staff) so I explained what gluten is and common foods that it's found in (noodles, soy sauce, etc) and at the waiter's recommendation got a soup while the Girlfriend ordered  some BBQ'd beef.

Soup came... filled with Ramen noodles. Flagged down the waiter, explained that noodles are made of wheat (flour) and asked for a new soup without them. He said "ok" and 5-10 min later came back with a "new" soup. Poked around in the soup to check... there were still a few noodles in there, they just scooped out the ramen and gave it back to me. As I had explained previously, gluten allergy is kind of serious, anyone actually trained to work in a restaurant (which i was at 17, so I know it's not that difficult) has to know that this isn't a great idea. 

Flagged down waiter again, explained to him why this wouldn't work and saw some annoyance on his face, which was taxing as I'm was not doing it to be difficult, I really couldn't eat the damn soup. He promised a real new one which arrived 20 minutes later. With...did you guess it yet? Bits of Ramen in it. 

We paid and left, Girlfriend was pretty PO'ed so didn't even touch her food and took it to go. No idea if it was any good. 

So yeah, in sum, this place can kiss my ass. Don't waste your time here, I'd give it 0 stars if I could.
author: Erik H.

description:
After a hotel party sesh, we hit up this place since it was walking distance from the Hilton and the only spot open till late. Luckily, we got seated in no time considering there were like 10 of us! My cousin and I shared the combo with bulgogi and spicy beef short ribs. Bulgogi is my all-time fave and it was pretty darn good here!! Marinated just right! As for the spicy beef... seriously.. no lie.. SPICY as heck! I loooove spicy though and this was one of the fewest places I've ever been to that actually deliver "spicy." We killed most of it but by the end, my tongue was red and on fire! 

So if there's one thing I'll always remember from that night, it'll be the SPICY BEEF SHORT RIBS ftw!!!
author: Valerie M.

description:
I'd go back to Cocobang for the fire chicken alone!  (And in fact, I have gone back about a half a dozen times since I started this review 6 months ago.)  Perfect post-party place to eat.  Though I'd say get there at 2:00am, versus 2:30am so you don't have to wait.  It's a small venue that can accommodate parties of 5 or more, but pretty tight.  Venue is dark with candles and the blaring Korean pop idol shows (fun!) projected against the back wall providing the only real light.

The real star dish of the restaurant is the fire chicken!  They are perfectly crispy, tender, and spicy pieces of heaven...I mean, chicken.  It might be the best Asian spicy chicken I've ever had.  Nice that there are wings and boneless pieces, as well.  Oh, and can't forget to mention you can order a half (roughly 8 pieces) or a full order.  The cabbage with the thousand island like dressing is a good accompaniment as it off sets the heat of the chicken.

Other dishes that are done right (as far as the ones I've tried): bi bim bap (though I wished they served the version in a clay pot, too), kalbi, kimchi fried rice, mandu-guk, kimchi pancake, and teokbokki (spicy rice cakes served with some veggies).

Cocktial sojus are decent, but very limited in flavors.  Since I almost see them as flourishing at late night eatery, you can get away with never trying their sojus...but that's just my opinion.  

To wrap up, since this review is literally 6 months in the making...Go for good late night Korean food with relatively quick turnaround, friendly and accomodating staff, and vibrant vibe (patrons included).  Recenly has become my favorite post-party eatery, but loses the final star for the shady stairs that descend to the restrooms.  Ladies in heels, be careful (or maybe I'm just clumsy).  Bathroom isn't the cleanest either.
author: Marie B.

description:
service was really good, BUT...

the tofu soup I had was super blend, had really no clams in it except just tofu, squash and green onions.

I feel it was a rip off.
author: Sabrina W.

description:
I met up with my friends that failed at seeing the Chinese New Years parade a few blocks away.  Parking was a pain, but that was to be expected.

I ate a little of their food and someone ordered fries (?) which were good.  Mostly though, we drank 2 carafes of soju.  each.

Only, none of us got drunk, just really sugared up and FULL.

The server was totally awesome and really sweet.  He even bought us a carafe of soju.  Awesome!  We tried all 6 flavors (some of them 4 times...)

I liked:
Mango and Peach the best

Yogurt was interesting, worth a try but confusing. 

Lime, Lemon were good

and apple was good.

oh

i guess I liked them all.


Anyways, the server guy was adorable and they were nice.  We played obnoxious drinking games for a while (until we were so full we had to roll out.  I felt like Violet from willy wonka.  Violet, you're VIOLET!! I needed to be taken to the juicer)

next time I think we should do soju bombs...
author: Van W.

description:
I love coming to this place.  While some may love clubbing or bar hopping, I love just chilling and drinking.  Maybe it is just the alcoholic Asian in me, but nothing beats just hanging out with friends, snacking on a few delicious snacks, and drinking the night away.  

The Fire Chicken is pretty good and comes with a side of cabbage salad.  I usually just opt for the first bottle of soju on the menu.  I forgot what its called.  The yogurt soju is pretty good too, but pretty girly.  We usually just mix in like half a bottle of normal soju to give it some kick.  The place doesn't close until 4:00 a.m. on the weekends, but you still got to stop drinking by 2:00 a.m.
author: Bert N.

description:
I'm kind of obsessed with this place. The menu is decent, with a good selection of standard items alongside more nontraditional "party food." While you won't find some of the amenities you'd expect from a Korean restaurant, most notably in-table or portable grills for cooking meat, certain things about this place make it unique and keep me coming back for more:

1) The fried chicken with tangy sauce. Korean fried chicken has been gaining fame stateside due in part to write-ups in major publications like The New York Times and the SF Chronicle. Cocobang's fried chicken comes in a variety of flavors, and a $13 whole order could easily feed two people, though I tend to order one just for myself and bring home the leftovers (half orders are also available). Items like this, while decidedly nontraditional, make Cocobang unique among Korean restaurants in San Francisco, which tend to stick to the old staples, and remind me of trendy food spots in Seoul. If you or your friends are looking to try Korean for the first time, this place has a number of menu items like this that provide an easy introduction to a rather complex flavor palate.

2) The homemade white radish pickles...especially as a compliment to the spicy chicken.

3) The atmosphere. This place, while small, is over-the-top, and is sure to give your friends lots to talk about. Most notably, K-pop music videos are projected onto a large screen at the back of the restaurant while loud music plays. Kind of intense.

I admit that San Francisco has a somewhat dismal selection when it comes to good Korean food, but if you are looking for somewhere fun and a little bit different, definitely give Cocobang a try.
author: Brian E.

description:
kbbq+yogurt soju+kpop songs=yes i love this place.!

and i get to see some oppa's lol 

i love cocobang :)
author: Enah N.

description: Legit late night Korean food. Definitely one of those "after the club" joints. I recommend the fried chicken, kimchee soup, and the kimchee fried rice.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
Ohhh fried chicken , Why do you torment me so? Why do I search far and wide for your deletable goodness? Why? Why? Why? 
Because everybody has weaknesses and mine will forever imprison me into the stretchy pants. Woe is me ! 
So of course I had to try the fried chicken. We got a whole chicken , half plain and half with hot and tangy sauce. Crispy and juicy but lacking the hotness I was craving. It tasted like it was coated in kochujang which gave it a more sweet than tangy or hot taste.
author: Sophia C.

description: too expensive for a hole in the wall & the portions aren't huge if you're ordering family style but the haemul paejon was good
author: Cailin H.

description:
Last night we randomly parked right in front of Cocobang and saw the fried chicken sign.  We decided to give it a try.  We peeped inside and saw alot of peeples so we figured it should be pretty good.  We ordered the fried chicken, kimchee soup, rice cake ( my fav).

The fried chicken came out first and  I really didnt care too much for them.  It was pretty bland.

However the rice cake and kimschee soup was awesome.  I want to try the soft tofu kimchee soup next time.  

The vibe is pretty cool...they play K-pop videos the entire time. :)
author: Sandy L.

description: Bad service, and pretty lame food. The fire chicken was not that great -- fairly spicy, but hardly any flavor to back it up. The rice was fine but you could have done better with a rice cooker. The pork was definitely nice, but it's hard to go wrong bathing sizzling fat in a sugary sauce -- nothing remarkable about this place; go elsewhere in the city for korean bbq.
author: David B.

description:
I was so excited to find this 24 hour Korean restaurant right by my apartment, but when I finally stopped by I was a little disappointed.The dukbokki was a little stale, the bibimbap did not come in a hot stone bowl, and is there no place for Korean fried chicken in SF?!? Seriously?!? Not one Bonchon or Kyochon!?!

Regardless, none of the food was bad, just not particularly amazing. It is 24 hours though so I'm sure their food mind-blowing orgasmic at 4am after a night of heavy drinking.
author: Tian X.

description:
This place is great.  I arrived in SF late on a Sunday hungry and this place looked interesting.  Great food, very laid back vibe.  Food came out fast and very tasty.

The restaurant itself is rather small, so seating is a bit limited.
author: John P.

description:
Coco bang's food content is about the same as PosangMacha that serves cart food can be easy quickie food but cocogang is too expensive than it deserve to be as for the place of that function.  
The quality is a bit less than Arang and less selection.  But two places shares something in common: not that much of authentic genuine Korean food and something quickie style.  Overall it's more like night life Sojubang rather restaurant so don't expect too much to getting Korean ethnic food as it as.
author: bluemoon p.

description:
This is a bit of a hole-in-the-wall except for the K-pop projected onto a ginormous screen overhead. Thankfully, there was no audio to detract from the dining experience.

Was there on a Friday night and the place was crowded but we were able to find a table quickly. Lots of Asian faces and conversations in Korean could be heard. A good sign.

We had the spicy tofu soup, binbimbang and super spicy chicken. The tofu soup was good with lots of tofu, an egg and clams. Binbimbang, a kind of meal-in-a-bowl with rice, beef, sprouts and boatloads of other stuff thrown in. Spicy chicken was a bit overwhelming with the chili powder but was otherwise good.

The prices are reasonable so if you're in the area and don't mind K-pop overhead, head to Cocobang.
author: Norman S.

description:
Cocobang is great. Here are a few highlights: the fries were awesome, the waiter was fast, friendly and efficient (he seemed to be holding down the tiny crowded restaurant with very little effort), the food is delicious, the price is agreeable. 

I went with a group of friends, one who swears by this spot but doesn't know the name and calls it simply Korean BBQ. 

The burning spicy chicken was not really spicy, but I guess it was just an off night because my friend said it's usually burn your mouth spicy and he's usually the only one who can handle it.

There was an interesting Korean alcohol selection. We had something that tastes like a mild vodka.

The lighting and atmosphere was really comfortable. And there were Korean music videos projected on the wall over the kitchen. It was all very charming.

We split 4 meat dishes and a plate of fries between 5 people and it was a little too much food, I should have taken the leftovers for later.

I'll be back.
author: David K.

description: Great Korean atmosphere and tasty food. Every time I've been here the staff has been super kind and friendly. I especially recommend the fried chicken with tangy sauce. Avoid anything with "spicy" or "fire" in the name unless you have an asbestos tongue. This place is very popular; it would often be full even if it were twice the size. Friday and Saturday nights are not the best times to come here if you're in a hurry.
author: David M.

description: I'm going to be honest I have only been here after midnight. Needless to say I have been inebriated 100% of the time. That being said, this place is awesome for late night drunchies. They provide good food and let you get pretty rowdy, within reason. The fried chicken is spectacular and if my memory serves me right it is yes indeed boneless. Basically, they are big ass chicken nuggets. The kimchi fried rice is always a must have and usually one order is not enough. Other than that, get ready to drink hard, eat hard and stumble home with a full belly. The only downside of this place is that it is small. If you are planning on coming with a group larger than 4 you are probably in for some waiting. But, if you are lucky you are in for a treat that will satisfy all your drunchie needs. I will try to return someday while not under the influence, but it will forever remain as one of my favorite late night spots.
author: Alex L.

description: We decided to try this place because we liked the name, it was close to our hotel, and it got good reviews on Yelp. We really enjoyed this place.  The service was great and the staff has a good sense of humor too.  The Jap Chae (glass noodles) were delicious, along with the kalbi beef ribs and beef bulgogi. But our favorite menu item was the garlic fried chicken - YUMMY.  This place is small so be prepared to wait if you arrive during peak dinner hours or if you don't want to wait you can order food to go.  Cocobang does a fantastic job making and packing to go orders.
author: Raquel A.

description:
If you like watching projector screen-sized music videos of 12-year-old pop stars from Korea while chowing down on your bibimbap, then Cocobang is the place for you!  (Ok, the pop stars MIGHT be 16 years old . . . regardless, they make me feel old.  And hideously obese, considering the majority of them are stick thin and plastic-surgeried up the wazoo!)

I enjoy coming here for food on occasion with my friends.  We get the firey fried chicken wings, bibimbap, kimchi jjigae (kimchi soup), and pajeon (Korean pancake, which i adore).  The duk bukgi (a spicy, sticky rice-cake dish) is pretty good, too.  

Like most Korean food in the City, Cocobang is pretty expensive.  Soju is, of course, over priced, and the dishes aren't cheap.  But when you have a late night craving for Korean food, and you're downtown and don't feel like traveling to Japantown for your Korean fix, Cocobang is the place to go!
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
So far the best korean late night eat out I have experienced since being back from SoCal. 

I came across this place because I was pretty drunk and needed some food in my system. Before throwing up outside of Cocobang (don't worry i cleaned myself up) I had some of their food. it was soooo good! maybe it was the drunkness talking, but it was good.

From what I remember the rice cake, fried chicken (not the spicy one), and pancakes were really good. 

They also had a really big tv to showcase korean music videos.
author: Dorris W.

description:
Must Order:
Fried Chicken w/ Tangy Sauce

Don't Order:
Kimchee Fried Rice (no flavor)
Miso Clams Soup (very salty)
author: Tina N.

description:
This is an important place in my arsenal of go-to restaurants in San Francisco, having just spent my 30th birthday party gala here last weekend.
I was introduced to this place by a fellow pharmacy student going to UCSF back in 2009.
Anyway, since this is an update review I had to chop a star. I'm doing this out of principle and the fact that I placed a lot of importance on service as well, although the prices are relatively reasonable. The main head guy, a Korean dude with glasses and usually a hat, has left the building. His replacement told me that he left to pursue some business curiosities or something, which makes me sad. The service now is "ok" but nothing like the guy prior, although we'll see what happens in the next few months.
Old waiter: you did Korean BBQ a huge service and your tireless 7 days on/365 days a year has probably exhausted you tremendously. Easy guy to get eye contact, and get glasses refilled without more than just a glance. Good luck to the new guy, you have big shoes to fill!
author: Davey R.

description:
Fried chicken is so so. 
Bulgogi has more vegetables (onions and bell peppers) than there is meat. 
Bibimbab was pretty good though. 
Not a bad option from room service for the price.
author: Cydney V.

description:
This is my go-to places at late nights after clubbing.  It opens till 4am, and the spicy chicken hits the spot and the clam soups can help you sober up.  They also makes a pretty good seafood pancake.  However, unless you want to wait at least half an hour, you should try to get here before 1am. 

The place is slightly small and crowded, and I don't understand what MV is being played in the background most of the time.  But the food is great, and if you show up with Korean friends, even better experience.  (I don't know what was being said between them, but the water does get refilled more often)
author: Jim H.

description:
The first time I tried this place, I couldn't get my mind off their fried chicken and light salad. Everything here is good. I can't complain.

Although the wait for this place is ridiculous if you go on a busy night, WITH ALOT OF PEOPLE. So I guess it's better to go on a day when it's not busy to get the REAL cocobang experience because it does get busy, and you will have to wait.

The soju is good too. I like the fact that when you get it, it's slushy and fruity, so drink fast if you can't handle the alcohol flavor. Soju wasn't meant to be savored, it's not wine. The little dishes they give you on the side are okay, I liked the kimchi but the radishes were too tarte. 

Anyways, love this place && would def go back, one bad thing is that you have to walk all through Tenderloin, JUST to get to this place, because it's located right in between Tenderloin bordering Nob Hill which sucks if you're a girl, so ladies...bring a body guard or some guy friends if you're traveling at night. 

alright, happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description: Perfect food for a late night, post-drinking meal. Great place to stop in after checking out the new TL bars. Chicken is awesome and the fried rice cake is awesome. Probably one of the only places that I actually like dukboki!
author: Caroline D.

description:
It's been a month since I visited, but it was quite good.  I lived in Korea long ago, so I always find a local Korean restaurant when I am in a new city.  Got there at 5, I think when they open for dinner. By the time I left the place was filled with Koreans.

A little loud as they play Korean music videos on a big projection screen.  Makes it fun.

I had a mix of beef and pork bulkogi, very good.  Service was timeline and food came to me fast.  Will definitely return.

My only complaint is they don't server dukpoggi, which I really like.
author: Brandon P.

description:
First of all, this is a great place to go late night, great food, great music. Everything is just awesome except the service and the price...the waiter is freaking rude, he throws food on the table, and everything we ask for his help, he stares at us like we are giving him troubles. And the price, omg 10% tips on the bill even we only have 3 people, I asked the waiter to show me how to get to the total amount, he calculates 10% of the tips BEFORE he do the tax, means you pay some extra...then he stares at like I'm going to ditch the bill and he shows some disrespect to us.
I took a pic of the bill has the waiter mark on it how to calculate the bill, wish I can show you guys...
author: Karl N.

description:
A nice hole in the wall with the best...best... CHICKEN:):) 

The sweet chicken w/salad (lettuce) combo (its on the door of the restaurant) + soju.... freakin amazing and HEAVEN. 

It tastes so much like home, yes im korean :) .. and its not TOO sweet which is the best part about this dish. My friends (chinese, mexican, filipino....) love it. I think if you love chicken in general, this is a MUST TRY!!! 

And yes, i know you're thinking... "lettuce? salad" Oh yeah.. something about it w/ the 1000 island dressing sauce makes everything just perfect. 

The place is a little on the "not-so-clean-looking" side.. but other than that, service is good and you can easily wave down a server since the restaurant is so small to begin with:)
author: Hanna K.

description:
Fried chicken w/ hot&tangy sauce: the chicken was hot and juicy. The Koreans always knows how to fry their chicken. I would order it w/o the sauce next time though. The sauce was neither spicy nor tangy. It was sweet in my opinion. 

Assorted Seafood pancake: I've tried this dish before somewhere else and vowed I'd never eat it again. Due to peer pressure I went back on my words and ate a seafood pancake at Cocobang. Surprisingly I liked it! It didn't taste like raw seafood like the one I had originally. I liked it!

The place is small and tight with that "I'm in Asia" feel. Korean pop on tv and through the speakers. We stumbled in here after a night of drinking. So glad I did.
author: Alice S.

description: Everything we ordered was fantabulous. The corn cheese, the friend chicken, the spicy chicken and oh god the pahjan (seafood pancake)... All washed down with Korean beer, yes please! Def coming back here, service was super legit too, the guys were all very nice to us!
author: Nadia I.

description: Late night delight! While it's not a five star spectacular, it is a top pick for that 3AM craving
author: Mike P.

description: wow i got the 1/2 hot and tangy chicken and brought it back to my room and devoured it boneless dark meat greatness
author: Rich L.

description: This place gets 4 stars for what it is. Late night drunk cheap Korean bar food. If your looking for a nice sit down meal then well you're at the wrong place. It's tiny and there's usually a bunch of people waiting late at night. I couldn't tell you what it's like during normal dinner hours. The food is relatively cheap and tasty. The fried chicken was awesome. the kimchee pancake was good and the portion on the Bul Go Gi was pretty big. The staff isn't going to be your refined level of service BUT they're super nice about dealing with drunk people. You may have to track one of them down as they race back and forth but if you do they're real cool about getting what you need.
author: Hyung L.

description: This is a place to go on a late night hang out. Food are great so is they're sojo drinks. Great staff, so that's a plus. It's a drag when it is a full house, i hate waiting. But overall this is a recommended place to go.
author: Vincent B.

description: Yummy place! Friendly service. Cool Korean videos on the wall! Fun place to have a beer.
author: Howard C.

description:
Fire chicken better than expected, service nice and about as expected.  The lemon soju slushy is worryingly and possibly criminally good. 

Seriously, this can't be legal.
author: Michael G.

description: I go here because its close. Fried chicken with tamarine and Da Best!!  ther stuffs are ok.   If u want a late night dinner with soju here is a place to be down town
author: Eric B.

description:
Not sure if we got hooked up due to my limited Korean chops, but we got a super deluxe version of kimchi chigae the other night, complete with spam, hot dogs, ramen noodles, and dduk. Trust me, you will appreciate this at 3 in the morning. 

The daeji bulgogi (spicy pork) was pretty good too.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I hate to say this. It's something I've always suspected but never wanted to admit: I don't think I like Korean food. 

But I swear I'm not racist. One of my friends is Korean!

Anyway. 

I came here last night after an evening of free drinks at a mixer in Nob Hill. After hob-nobbing with my roomie and some new friends, we headed down the hill for ramen. Upon seeing the wait at Katana-Ya, we walked around a few blocks until someone recognized Cocobang. Due to our starving bellies and low attention spans, we headed inside and only had to wait a few minutes for a table. 

Throughout the course of our meal, we thought we were going to have either 4, 5 or 7 people at the table. As we let our server know of each of our changes, they were extremely accommodating with different set up combinations of tables and chairs. I would have been annoyed by us, but luckily our waiter was not me. Also good since I wouldn't have understood what we ordered and served us fried chicken and hashbrowns.

We went family-style and ordered a plethora of dishes: the hot pot tofu, spicy chicken with cheese (temporarily thought I was at Chevy's), an assorted seafood pancake, kim chi fried rice and a bowl with many things I didn't recognize. Although I only liked half of the things on the table, the things I did like were well flavored and cooked without feeling greasy. The chicken was the highlight (I sound so white-washed saying this... of course I liked the spicy chicken the most) but I really enjoyed the pancake too. 

Would I come back here? Probably not. But that has nothing to do with Cocobang. The food came out really fast, the servers were patient will all our seating and food changing requests, my friends who like Korean food really enjoyed themselves, and it's a cute, cozy place for a cold Friday night.
author: Jared S.

description:
Depending on whether you're sober or not, this place is either a 5-star "greatest place ever!" restaurants or 1-star "WTF mate?" places. I have definitely leaned more towards the first, hence the 4-stars, which also reveals my state when coming here. At 2AM, when there's a craving for Korean food in a social atmosphere, Cocobang the spot to be. 

The key is having the patience to wait for a table and also the tolerance for obnoxious drunkards which are the only cons to the Bang. Other than that, the food is quite solid and at an affordable price. They have the typical Korean hits like Kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, Bipbimbop, etc. My favorite is the spicy fried chicken that comes with the a cabbage slaw. Stuff hits the spot.

The place is located in a semi-shady area with like "massage parlors" around but the Bang holds its own with its flashing window display enticing people to come in for some real comfort.
author: Ed L.

description: This is our go-to spot after a night of drinking. The food here is pretty good and definitely satisfying. Favorites include the dukbokgee, tofu soup, spicy chicken, and bulgogi. My night is always made better when I end with some Cocobang. Plus, they play videos of hot Korean girl groups. Hot Korean girls + hot Korean food = success.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I really wanted to love this place. 

I have walked past it for about a year & a half & just dreamed of spicy chicken & bi bim bap. Unfortunately it is only open for dinner so I can't go for lunch during work hours. 

So we finally hit it up last Friday night after a marathon 5 hour happy hour excursion. I was glad to see mostly Koreans inside...must be authentic! Our waiter was super nice & we started with a large OB beer (in a plastic bottle, like a 2 liter coke!) & yogurt soju. It doesn't really explain on the menu but the price for a "soju cocktail" is really for a carafe of soju that you can share with your table. Great idea! I liked the yogurt soju & never would have thought to order it if it weren't for Yholl. Kinda reminded me of unfiltered sake. 

For dinner we ordered potstickers, bi bim bap, & fire chicken. I had read all the Yelp raves about the fire chicken so we had to get it. The potstickers were just ok. I liked that they were crispy but the flavor wasn't quite there. The bi bim bap was better, in fact that was my favorite dish. Squeeze some hot sauce on it & you're good to go! The fire chicken was a disappointment. You know how things can be spicy, but not really have much flavor? That's the fire chicken. Plus it had these rice noodle logs mixed in so they looked like chicken but when you bite into them you realize it ain't chicken. I dunno, that was just a weird touch. 

Also, no little plates. I don't know what those things are called but some Korean restaurants give you an assortment of little side dishes to have with your meal. Maybe we didn't order the right dish, maybe they just don't do that here, maybe it was cuz we were a bunch of white girls. 

I hate to say but there's a little Korean place by my house in Concord that has way better food. I think I'll go there for my Korean cravings from now on.
author: Erin S.

description: Grabbed a quick bi bim bop yesterday from this place and it was really good. I think they have dishes that would be even better than this. I went in here because it seemed convenient but I think I found a new favorite place. The guys that seemed to own it were really nice. There were videos playing on a big projector, everything from K Pop to Jay Z. Count me in.
author: Mark R.

description:
Since the wait at Katana-ya was an hour long, we decided that the best thing to do was to wander around tender-nob for a shorter wait. I stumbled upon Cocobang and decided it had to be the best name for a restaurant since Pho shizzle. 
The waiter recommended the fried chicken with hot and tangy sauce. Since it was on every table, I figured it was the best bet. The chicken was very moist but how can you go wrong with dark meat. The sauce didn't live up to the promised "heat" but was definitely tangy. 

We also got the grilled octopus with somen. I think the octopus was sauteed and a bit tough. There was just too much sauce and threw the dish off balance. 

The pan chan consisted of some turnip pickles, kimchee (good), bean sprouts (eh) and tofu (decent). I would have liked to see some roasted fish, silver noodles, etc. given the price point. 

However, this place is legit. K-pop videos on a huge wall, cute Korean girls in too tight, too short dresses, and soju everywhere. This place is probably a good place to sober up after a night of excess since it is open until 4:00 AM.
author: Monica L.

description: I like Cocobang's food. Their bulgogi salad is amazing (and yes I get made fun of for getting salad as my drunken munchie -_-), cheesy corn is good, kalbi is delicious, dukkboki is really really good and spicy. I just can't stand the wait and their sometimes preferential treatment of some customers over others. I know I'll be back because their food and prices are more reasonable than Wonmi's, but tip to yelpers: get take out! We ordered paid and were out of there in 15 minutes after being told the wait at 2 am would be "hours" (hours? really?).
author: Joyce H.

description: Escape sf to ktown in this tiny restaurant. Pricier than other LA places of the kind. Fire burning chicken is mildly spicy n too garlicky.  Nothing spectacular except that it's not skeevy looking like the other korean bars around here
author: Kasey H.

description:
I went there many times, they used to be good but not anymore. 
Today is the worst. Bad to go food, bad manner.  

I ordered to go and paid at the cashier with my credit card. They didn't give the card back to me and blame that I lost it.  Then we started to look on the floor and everywhere in front of the counter. 
We couldn't find it and they told me to wait outside.

Later, a guy came to me with my card and said they found it on the floor where I stand and blamed that it was all my fault and give me an ugly face.

My sister told me later that she kept an eye on them and the card wasn't found from the floor. They just don't want to admit their fault. 

This is my last time at this place.
author: J K.

description:
Typical cheap Korean eatery/drinkery.  In other words...

...the food isn't amazing, but it's still soul-satisfyingly familiar, albeit on the almost microwave food level.  Skimpy on the banchan.

...the service isn't terrible, but you still feel like slapping the "hip-hop" out of the staff's crooked hats to get attention more frequently.

...the place isn't dirty per se, but you still have the urge to inspect everything before you touch it.  Bathroom was clean enough to drop your kids off at the pool in a "pinch."

I'd probably only come back if I was drinking in the area and was craving Korean food.
author: Patrick C.
