description:
+Spicy Korean Fried Chicken
+Divey feel
+Quick service
+A sizeable menu serving up modern Korean diner classics

-Not very good kimchi
-Service is spotty and not consistently attentive
-Had to get up for water refills
-The cook is not Korean; for any other food you could wing it; for Korean food, if your cook is Mexican it's going to be wrong.
-- the Soft Tofu soup was by far the least authentic thing I've ever tasted. It had an almost sweet, leeky flavor and served in a regular bowl; normally it should taste like hot, peppery beef buillon, be very savory (no sweet additives whatsoever) and be full of crumbled silken tofu, served in a stone bowl.
author: Y K.

description:
Hopefully the rest of the things in their menu is not so average...They are 4 blocks downhill from my house so I figured YAY I have a KFC near my place!  It was a disappointment.

I guess I had high expectations since I went to Bon Chon in NYC all the time.  I was expecting a hard shell, extra crispy, yet super flavored chicken as I had in Korean town on 32nd street.

So the consensus is that the chicken is soggy and non crispy, but the radish and salad that came with the meal is pretty good.  

It's like if you see a really cute guy from far away and then you talk to him...and sadly, he doesn't know who Condoleeza Rice is.
author: Katrina N.

description: This place is one of a kind, very popular among the 20-something Asian crowd; it can get crowded; its not a really big place. They are open several hours later than most other restaurants in the area and serve tasty Korean favorites prepared with their own flair. My favorites are the thick noodle soup and a squid dish I can't remember what they call it but it rocks! The giant beers rock too! The interior decor is sort of a SF Industrial Korean hybrid, really cool, really kick back, mostly dark with Lady Gaga and Korean pop videos projected overhead. I really love this place, the hours are great,  the food is really tasty and reasonably priced for the area, and the crowd is really cool too. It's all good IMO at Coco Bang!
author: Daniel G.

description: SOB... I got talked into eating at this craphole after getting wasted... Easily persuaded is my main fault when I drink too much... My friend told me the chef here got into it with the owner and told him to f** off and quit.  They now run Aria.  WOW, Aria is WAY better than this place and I can see why!
author: Bobby K.

description: Excellent value for Korean BBQ at a quaint hole-in-the-wall. Not the best I've ever had, but solid dishes with quick service. Fire chicken is excellent, and spicy BBQ pork is great as well. The chicken bulgogi left a little to be desired. The fried spiced/garlic chicken is really good. Paid $100 between five people with beers and ample quantity of food. Not too shabby. Would definitely return.
author: Nishant G.

description: This place is okay. Its small and open up really late. I had better in Oakland. It doesn't satisfy my food craving. I'll leave this review short like the amount of staff.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
Best place for Korean food in San Francisco. I hate to be the one to drop the hammer, but Brothers sucks. Why it's become the de facto place for non-Koreans to Get They Bulgogi On, I'm not sure... maybe it's because it has an English name and they always give you a free plate of their supergross chewy chap chae? Their incredible ability to recommend exactly the same three dishes that all honkeys get when we go for Korean food? Whatever the case... meh. I promise. Next time you're in there, look around. Those Asians aren't Koreans. And if they are, they're there because their non-Korean pals suckered them into playing "wise-and-all-knowing Korean speaker who can introduce us to your country's wondrous customs and delights". Hell, I'd play host at Burger King in Pyongyang if I ever get the chance.

Anyway, any consideration of the Best Korean Place always comes with an asterisk at the end of it, because the places are just not very good overall. The quality of the beef is poor, or the soondubu is too oily, or the kodeungeo gui is just not right because no one's ordered it for a week and the guy is just totally out of practice, or the waitress looks afraid to talk to you because you aren't Korean.

THEN I FOUND MY SWEET SWEET COCOBANG.

The food is exactly correct, the dudes that work there are in their early 20s, they serve all different kinds of latenight grub alongside requisite beer and soju, they play Korean music videos on a giant screen, they are open until 4am. 

I lived in the Hongdae area in Seoul (think Berkeley, in Seoul... or rather as Berkeley as Seoul could get). I commented to my friend that Cocobang could have been airlifted directly out of the Hongdae University area of Seoul... turns out the owner graduated from Hongdae and based this place on the area. Home sweet home!

I have NEVER had decent ddukbokki (spicy ricecake) outside of Korea - and that includes Ktown in LA. These guys got it on lockdown. The budaechigae is great, the chicken is great, be sure to eat the corn first because the cheese gets cold quickly.

And if you can't speak Korean don't worry about it, you'll have no issues at all.
author: Mark B.

description: Hotspot bulgogi has water too much. And also there are too much cabbages and less meats. The atmosohere and service was good.
author: Hyesun L.

description: its hard to find parking around here. it's also kinda small. their soju is not bad tastes a little like juice lol could use more alchy. but their chicken wings! it's hard to find good korean chicken wings in the city. cocobang has some decent chicken wings. i liked their pancakes as well that was yummy. tried their kimchi fried rice -its alright. i wish they opened during lunch hours so i can eat it during lunch since i work around there.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Always good, rich korean dishes
- Squid with veggies over somen noodles - Spicy, sweet and very saucy
- Spicy sauced fried chicken - My fav., dark meat, still crunchy on outside
author: Steve M.

description:
My two girlfriends live in this neighborhood and we decided to stop into Cocobang for dinner on a Friday night. It was past 7:30pm and there was no wait. The place was relatively empty for a Friday night but I guess this place is more crowded later in the night. 

We ordered the fried chicken, kimchi pancake, and the housemade soup noodles. The fried chicken had a lot of flavor and the sauce it came with was good too, although it was a little bit overfried for my taste. But my girlfriends did mention that the fried chicken has been better the other times they were there. The kimchi pancake was good, but nothing special. The housemade soup noodles, however, were really good! The noodles were the perfect amount of chewiness and the broth was amazing. The guy who was working there was really nice. He offered to hold our food for us there, since we didn't finish it and we didn't want to box it because it would be a hassle to carry. We didn't end up boxing up the food, but it was nice of him to offer!

Would definitely go back!
author: Jessica S.

description: Cocobang holds a special place in my heart.  There are K-pop videos played on a projector, delicious kalbi, fried chicken and the kimchi pancake.  The giant bottles of OB beer don't hurt either.
author: Ben G.

description: You should the fried chicken with cabbage salad, awesome. Really good portion for the price you pay for. And they open late too. Love it.
author: Suabot J.

description:
Fire Chicken!  I love this place.  It's a little dark, it has videos playing on the wall.  There are things on the menu I have never seen before.  I like that.  And I always get a lot of great food to eat and really friendly service.  

I usually order the bibimbop because it is so satisfying, but once in a while I have to try an appetizer as well or, of course, the Fire Chicken.  Ouch!  And yum!
author: Tapedeck B.

description:
One of the best spots after 12AM to get your munch on or casually keep drinking.

Love their menu. Top Picks for me.  1. Kimchijiggae, 2. Spicy Fire Chicken 3. Kimchi Side dish followed by bowls of rice. Prices range $11-14 dollars for a personal dish. Free sides of kimchi, and goodies. 

Just totally satisfies your beer-hunger.

Pros: Great Food! Good Selection! Polite Service sometimes.

Cons: Busy packed! expect to wait at least 20-45 minutes for a table if you go in after 12. Make sure the waiter knows how many people are in your group. 

Still one of my favorite spots in town.
author: arif q.

description:
Yes to Coco Bang! I love it. Serve food to 4 am? Yes! Current K-pop videos energizing the back wall? Yeh! Such friendly service and succulent soju (go peach).

Total fan of the relaxed atmosphere and huge plates of homestyle snacky Korean food. No, it isn't fancy or complex. Yes a plate of cheese corn is just that - cheesy corn. But you know what? It's good.

Spicy enough to ignite a slow burn. The chicken wings are absurdly large. Kimchi pancake or mixed seafood pancake could easily feed four people. 

It's fun. It's unique. I'm glad it's here. I like the name. Bang on!
author: wendella a.

description:
I've never actually been to this restaurant, but it caters food for the Korean club at my school. I'm not Korean either, but that's another story. There's always a huge spread at the meetings that includes fire chicken, bulgogi, vegetable pancake, mandoo, chap chae, among other things. A feast for poor law school students, I tell you.

The fire chicken is finger-licking good. The Colonel has nothing on this hot, crispy, saucy, yummo Korean creation. The vegetable pancake is also tasty--you forget you're eating veggies. The chap chae is one of the better versions I've had in SF. I love Korean comfort food because it reminds me of my hanabata days in Hawaii, and this is just what Cocobang offers. 

I'll probably come here for the first time soon, if only to judge if the food is good because it's actually delicious or good because I've actually never had to pay for it. =)
author: Liz T.

description: What a waste of calories. Too bad it's the only Korean restaurant open after 2am. Don't order the fire chicken - it's basically inedible red chilli flakes with some chicken pieces peppered in there for decoration.
author: T. B.

description:
i dare you~!~!!!....no..no...i double dare you~!......no..no..no....i super duper triple quadruple panties on fire sign your will don't sue me dare you to finish an order of the "super spicy fire chicken"....i'll have my phone ready to dial 911.....

let me have a moment..as i wipe this drop of tear from my left eye....not from the chicken....well...that too...but from joy....that finally there is a true korean watering-hole in the heart of the city.....oversized 1.6-liter (54-ounce) bottles of o.b. beer...yes..they have....pitchers of draft beer....soju cocktails for the ladies...soju for the men.....blood sausages...sea snails....small plate bbq....korean soups galore.....dried "anju" (drink snacks)....stir-fried plates....ack~!...i've died, and gone to hell and back......

small korean style sit down..table seating korean style old fashion bar....dim lighting....simple minuscule red interior...projector and sound system quietly thumping u.s. and korean music videos in the background........dingy bathrooms......ahhhhh.....i feel like i'm back in high school hangin' in garden grove...
author: Hen A.

description:
Went on a Wed night craving Korean food, near Union Square. I'm thinking...."wait theres no place that serve Korean food around here".....but lo and behold, Coco Bang appeared out of nowhere as if to correct me. Now from the outside it looked like a small bar. Went inside and it definitely could have been a bar, but instead you see tables lined up on each side of the brick walls with few dividers between the tables with pictures of Korean ladies jockin Soju drinks. The lighting is almost as dim as a typical bar/lounge, but enough so that you can actually see what you're eating. So the overall setting suits a nice urban ambiance. Lastly they play both korean and american music videos on a projector screen at the middle end right below the ceiling. It is loud enough that you can still hold a conversation over it, and if you run out of things to say you can always look up and be visually entertained...or not. 

Now lets get to the food. This isn't your typical Korean family restaurant. This place is mainly for those who have a quick hunger for some fairly fast korean food that especially cater to the after hour clubber/ barhoppers in the area. Therefore, it is open late. This is not to say the food is bad, but you definitely will not get the usual amount of side dishes (only 3). The food in general is pretty good, and from what other yelpers have stated, they are pretty much on the dot. I had the Pork Cutlet which was very savory and the dukkbokkie (spicy rice cake) was mouth watering. The waiter was prompt and attentive and made sure my water cup was always filled up. Yea I drink lots of water. Great place with friends and having drinks. Cheers!
author: Jin C.

description:
the first and only time i came here was after some pretty heavy drinking. the chicken was delicious, the kimchee fried rice came out with that fried egg just like it should, and the kalbi was yum!

we had a pitcher of OB to wash it all down.
author: Ameer N.

description: Four years since my last review and nothing has changed, except it's more crowded, the menu is bigger, and the food is tastier.  It's still mostly couples and groups of young Korean-American adults, they've got an endless parade of Korean pop music videos.  Prices are still reasonable, the service is completely helpful with no attitude, and the food is fresh, spicy, and hearty.  For a late snack or after-the-club dinner you can't beat it - fire wings, soup noodles, meat salads (the bulgogi salad is a crowd pleaser), bibimbap, shared appetizers, roast chicken, seafood pancakes.  This all might get lost on you if you've been drinking and it's not fine dining, but the preparation is actually very careful and the flavors well balanced.  So I'm the guy in the corner reading on a computer, I like the food.
author: Gil S.

description: Been coming here late night over the past few years I've lived downtown. Good alternative to the shitty diners on Mason and Jbox,(yuck!). Place is open late and has always been packed. Can't really remember what I ate as the Soju and Hite can be a nasty combo but is always hot and tasty. Last time I was in was taking shots w/ the owner, nice guy. Lightweight blacked out, only remembered by the note i left on phone, "My lil slice of Asia."
author: I D.

description:
Korean food late night? This is the spot.  Fire chicken is BOMB, and plentiful.  It does however come with a lot of salad with thousand island dressing, but I LIKE THAT.  the rest of the food is good, not anything worth going an extra mile for, but not bad at all.

What truly makes this place shine though is the soju slushies.  Affordable, delicious, and easy to drink for everyone: this is what makes cocobang a great place to take a small group of friends.  $12 gets you a "pitcher" of this delicious flavored soju enough to get the job done and get a good buzz for 3-4 people.

Oh and get lucky with parking
author: Antonio C.

description:
Place is open late, service is typical which is not great, but not bad. 

Food is pretty good, prices are typical for a korean place. 

I recomend the wings.
author: Steven C.

description:
I have been searching endlessly for a real soju place and I finally found this hidden treasure while walking to the car after the Redroom at the Clift Hotel. There it was seducing me.... a menu stating "Yogurt Soju" and the price. Then there were other flavors on the list. My mind  tells me, "You must have restraint, F$%^&* will be so mad that you left the Clift hotel and stopped somewhere along the way home. You can try this next time!!" But as usual my heart says, " Oh hell no!!! How long have you been yearning for a carafe of peach-flavored yogurt soju? You haven't had it since college and haven't stopped thinking about it since. Go in!!! So what if it is completely Korean!!!" As a true Leo, there was no way that I could go against my heart.

My friends and I go in to have a yummy carafe of fruit-flavored soju. We originally order the mango yogurt soju but they ran out and so we order the peach-flavored yogurt soju. B/c I know the effects of soju on my state of mind (As I recall my slurred speech and blurred vision from years before), we order food as well. The menu is limited, but definitely filled with original Korean dishes. Since I cannot handle Korean spicy very well, I ordered the Beef Bulgogi for $10.95. My friends originally ordered the spicy chicken, but they ran out of that as well and so they order the spicy tofu. He also asked if we wanted rice and so we ordered 2 small bowls. 

The restaurant is rather dark and you can't really see the people around you. You do almost feel like you are in a K-town bar in LA sans the funky decorations, fluorescent lights, and trendy clothing. THe background music is all Korean which I totally love.... How can you not love Korean pop music or hip-hop? Who cares if you can't understand a word in the song except for the occasional English catch phrase?

The carafe of Peach-yogurt soju is presented to us with the 3 shot glasses. My friend pours it for us and we all take our shots..... YUMMY!!!!! The drink is a little frothy, but WHOOOOOEEEEE!!!! I loved the taste of it again in my mouth. Though this soju is not as strong as what I had originally in K-town LA, it sufficed and conquered my every tastebud in  my mouth. 

Our food arrives and the Beef Bulgogi is presented in a sizzling skillet. The waiter said that the portions were small. This portion was actually pretty good-sized. We couldn't finish it and I also don't eat much rice so that says a lot. Compared to other Korean places, the Bulgogi was perfectly cooked. It was not salty at all. The spicy Tofu was pretty tasty as well. Surprisingly, it was accompanied with beef or pork in the dish (or so we think????). It had a kick to it, but I wasn't going to devour it. 

In the end I was very happy and the bill wan't too much...I am definiely returning to this place because where else can I have original soju...not just cocktails....
author: Lorna D.

description: I'm giving it five stars for its hot and tangy chicken  - AMAZINGGGG and we weren't even drunk. :D My friends and I were in SF for winter break and we went there 3 times just for the chicken and the beer. The other food is average (3 star)...bibimbap is okay, bulgogi in hotpot is okay, but i've had better. Wouldn't recommend the spicy chicken because its all chili and no real taste. Service is good though - the people are nice and work efficiently. The place is small but its definitely worth a try if you want a cheap meal and casual environment to drink and eat with friends.
author: Shan K.

description:
The Good:
- Yogurt Souju (it tastes like spiked-yakult, i kid you not)
- Kimchee Hot Pot (if you are a fan of SPAM & Hot dog like me...)
- Fire Chicken (LOVE chicken.)
- Short Ribs
- music videos projected on back wall
- open for late night 
- chewy white rice. i dont know. i love rice.
- nice servers that I bossed around. sorry.

The Bad:
- eating here under the influence of... yes
- can be pretty salty (side dishes....and hot pot)
- confusing business hours (don't know if they open for lunch. on their front door only says "Dinner - 5:30 -......................." and it gets cut off. so i'm going to assume they never close.)
- dirty bathroom


Let's just say....I only visited SF for 4.5 days, and I've eaten at Coco Bang twice for dinner..............
author: Christina C.

description:
Cocobang!!!!  What a great, catchy name!

Ok, it's exactly what everyone says.  Only been here when NOT sober..and it's not bad.  It's not LA korean food good either.  But it's not like we're in a k-town.

To throw a familiar analogy..this is like a Korean New Sun Hong Kong (north beach's infamous drunk chinese food joint)!  Although, I bet this place would be ok sober.  If you ever try Sun HK sober..OMG.  I could make better chinese food myself.  Side dishes are nil compared to traditional korean places and the fried chicken isn't terrible.  It's no KFC!

Overall, service is so-so.  Place is small.  I'm still waiting for the servers to bust out into their b-boy stances because they look like those Korean b-boy crews.  At least a head spin for your loyal patrons!  

I roll with the korean roommate, and man..gotta work that korean connect!  Ya heard.  We got 10% off and we were able to score reservations about 20 minutes before we even got there.  Yea boi!!!!
author: Yup S.

description:
The food here is all reasonably good, but nothing to write home about. Their Korean Fried Chicken with Spicy Tangy sauce has a great crispy shell but the sauce is way too sweet. The Spicy grilled chicken (cooked like bulgog) was overcooked and tasteless. The Bibimbap was decent, but not being cooked in a clay pot, the temperature was inconsistent.

The yogurt soju is great. It tastes like a combination of asian yogurt (think of those small little snack bottles of drinkable yogurt).
author: Andrew H.

description:
I came here after eating dinner at hard knox, and most of you know the portions are hard knox are quite huge. But for some reason, my friend ordered a a whole bunch of food (Jap Chae, Bulgolgi, Duk Bok Ki, Spicy Fried Chicken Wings and another dish that i don't remember)..... once those plates came i couldn't resist! I mean can i never resist korean food, especially with the liter of OB in my hand, and the 3 soju cocktail we ordered. The food good, but they over cooked the rice cakes and the ramen in the Duk Bok Ki. I mean how do you over cook the rice cakes... they were like mush! GROSS!! Other than that... make sure you order the Jap Chae, It was soooo freakin good! It came out piping hot and the noodles were cooked to perfection! 

Overall a nice hang out spot if you want to get away from the clubs and bars, and just indulge yourself in korean goodness! The place is clean, but parking can be a BIATCH!
author: Brian P.

description:
This is a hole in the wall drinking and eating place. You don't come here for the food unless you plan on drinking soju and beer, or if you have a craving for their fire chicken which is good on its own, but more amazing when you have a couple of beers and shots of soju in your belly. This place is a great alternative if you and your friends want to sit down and just drink, eat, and chill with one another. It's your typical Korean dive bar. 

Food - 3 stars (4.5 for the chicken, but the rest imo is just okay)
Service - 4 stars (just holla at the servers when you need something)
Ambience - 3 stars (dim lighting, sits about 24 people total, they play hip hop or Korean videos on the big screen, not too noisy so you can actually have conversations with your friends)

Overall a good place to come with your friends if you just want to eat, drink and chat.
author: Richard K.

description: Great place to start your night off before hitting the bars/lounges. They had a large flat screen playing korean music videos. It's a small and cozy little resturant. I loved their Ddukbokki !!! It was soOoo good !!! lol Also it's a great place to try different flavor of soju. The only ones i'd remember was orginal,apple, lycee, watermelon, strawberry and some few others i'd forgot lol Last night i had the strawberry soju. It was quite sweet ^ ^ Will definitely come back for some more Ddukbokki and Soju ^ ^
author: Trina M.

description:
First of all, it's probably not the best idea to review places when you're completely drunk at 3am.  Having said that, this place hits the spot when you're craving for some late night munchies to cope with the binge drinking.  Best of all, it's open till 4am, impeccable service, and coyly disguised water bottles filled soju served till closing (those sneaky koreans...) makes this spot a  must have on everyone's late night routine albeit the dingy and cozy atmosphere.   

I had Paul (great watier) help with ordering DokkBokki (chewy rice cakes marinated in hot, peppery paste) and SoonDae (traditional korean blood sausages) alone with a bottle of soju.  I've had better sausages before so only order it if you never had it before want to give it a try.  It's a bit bland and thicker than usual.  However, the dokkbokki is definitely a good choice.  Maybe macju (beer) would have been better companion to wash out the spiciness but it definitely made me gasp for air and cool off my tongue. 

This place is isn't on the same league as some of the late night bars in ktown in LA but I'm definitely coming back next time!
author: Sony P.

description:
Weeknight. Past midnight. Not tired. Stummy rumblin'. Need good food now. Somewhere in the 'hood. Cocobang!

NCM (me): Whole order of fire chicken to go, please.
CCB (them): Total is 14.05
NCM: I can pick it up in 10-15 minutes, right?
CCB: Yes.
NCM: Dope. 

This may become so routine that I fear I will one day end up sleepwalking to this mug.
author: Chiu Man N.

description:
I had this place on my list for over a year but finally tried it out and will never go back again. 



I went there sober on a Saturday night around 10 pm and was one there in addition to a couple who seemed to know the waiter pretty well. The (asian) customer dude was picking at his toes in the booth. 

Is bimbimbap bimbimbap without the stone bowl? I'm not sure but this is the only place I've been to where it was served in a plastic bowl. There wasn't much flavor and the beef seemed to be low quality. The veggies and rice were mediocrely warm. It seemed more like a bunch of fried rice ingredients lazily placed into a bowl.

Also had the garlic chicken which had way too much batter and the chicken was overcooked.

I was the oldest guy there and I'm not even that old.

The service was great but the food just plain sucks.

The place did fill up with a bunch of young Korean hipster douchebags when I was halfway through my meal.

---

Redwings has higher quality food at similar pricing.
author: Evan W.

description:
Was stoked to find late night Korean in this 'hood.  Okay here's the scoop:  really small joint, usually a wait.  The service wasn't great, and there were only 2 waiters for the place.  Our waiter was obviously irritated, and seemed quite uninterested in impressing us with his mad waiter skills.  When we asked for more Daikon, he looked irritated, and then never brought it out.  Also, water refills were hard to come by.
  
So now the good:  it's open late!  Also, the food was pretty damn good, and not just because it was 2 a.m., and I was hungry.  We ordered a lot of food for 4 people:  spicy fried chicken (yum), chap chae, kim chee chigae, and this chicken/potato dish.  We had leftovers for days (okay, maybe I am exaggerating a bit).  There were quite a lot of Korean people there, and the "fobby" kind.  So, that's a good sign.  Also, they project videos on the wall, and I enjoyed watching Korean singers, American singer, and Korean t.v. shows.  I'll be back, that is, if my drunk ass can find this place again.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This place was delicious!!! Or maybe it was the fact that I headed over there around 3 a.m., post an open bar extravaganza at Apt. 24. Anyway, again my friend who is addicted to Polk Street brought me to this location. He does usually know the good spots (but only east of polk). 

Some good things about this place: 
(1) The red chicken it is spicy and sweet. Next time I am going to try the     HOT. Mild just did not burn my mouth at all. 
(2) It is open late
(3) It is filled with Korean people (good sign) 
(4) Prices 

Only bad thing it is in Nob hill, which requires a lot of effort to get to..
author: Penelope S.

description:
How we chose this place over late-night pizza is beyond me. The food served here was neither good nor cheap.  It's like we forgot that we weren't in anywhere near k-town (LA). I'm sorry, but the only decent korean bbq in SF is Brothers (which isn't cheap either).

So disappointing.

The "small plates" served were pitiful at best- only three items. To make the start of this late-night meal worse, all we asked for was some hot tea, and our server couldn't provide any. His answer was because there wasn't any more hot water. 

Um. You have a kitchen, don't you? Is it THAT impossible to use a pot to boil some water? Our three items + beer + small pitcher of soju came out to $75! Our server graciously added something like 25% to the bill for gratuity. That's just dandy.

One thing did happen that made this disaster of a post-club meal worthwhile. Coco's table/booths were plastered with korean beer ads, and one of our inebriated chums waved at the wall to the girl in the ad, thinking she might be real. Priceless.

First star: They serve beer and soju (illegally) after 2am.
Second star: Coco is located just around the corner from Le Colonial and Sugar. (This is only if you're famished and aren't able to cab it somewhere else)
author: Elaine T.

description:
The next time I'm drunk off my ass at 3:30AM, I will definitely stop in this joint for the super spicy version of their Fire Chicken just to make completely sure that I will *completely* screw over my lower digestive tract.

There is a huge vegas-like blinky sign out front that scrolls messages like "Open till 4AM" and "Try our Fire Chicken".  Not being able to resist, I came here for dinner at around 7 on a Thursday night.

The first thing you notice is the blasting Korean techno music--and a disco ball.  Then you see tons of posters of YOUNG korean girls in school-girl outfits trying to sell you beer.

Not that there's anything wrong with that.

Our waiter got us some drinks and a little appetizer of these pickled radish things.  My friend and I both tried it and grimaced almost simultaneously.  He leans over and whispers "I need to eat some hot garbage to wash the taste of this out of my mouth".  To me they smelled and tasted like some type of rotting fruit.

We almost left, but decided to be adventurous and give it a shot.

I'm glad we did.  I got the extra spicy version of the fire chicken, and my buddy got a seafood dish.  His looked pretty good, but there was definitely lots of squid and octopus and all kinds of wierd asian crap in it, so it wasn't for the squeamish.

The fire chicken came out on this sizzling hot plate.  It was super flavorful and spicy.  Usually these ethnic resturants don't believe me when I ask for super spicy, but these guys did.  It was awesome--I love being in pain while I eat.

A word of warning.  We went out to the bar a few hours later, and the surly bartender at the place we were at hands me a few mints, and says "make sure you have a few of these if you are planning on talking to any girls tonight".

I guess Korean's like garlic!
author: Rocco B.

description:
They had a Korean variety show playing on the flat screen TV in the back, which was a lot of fun.

We split a scallion pancake and then a stew and some bibimbap. My Korean friend was really pleased with the authenticity of the food.

My Latina friend and I couldn't speak to the authenticity, but we were really pleased with the quality. ...though it was maybe a little more expensive than we would've liked.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I liked this place, but  It's nothing like the typical Korean bbq's you've been to on Clement St. or in suburban malls.  You need to be a little adventurous if you go here - expect some surprises.

The site is the former Le Quiche (and, after that, it was  a tapas place whose name escapes me.)  Most of the patrons when I was there were young, hip and Korean.  My partner and I are none of those things, but we immediately felt welcome.  The vibe is laid back, with dark brick walls and Korean hip-hop and pop tunes played at a reasonable volume.

A lot of the signage inside the restaurant is Korean, but the menus they gave us were in English.  The menus have little or no descriptions of the dishes - if you don't know what, say, beef bulgogi is, you'll have to ask.  And even if you think you know what you're ordering, you  can't be too sure.

The "fried tofu with kim chee" turned out to be kim chee with beef, with cold (un-fried) tofu arrayed around the edge of the platter.  Aside from the naming problem, the dish was terrific.  I've never been a fan of kim chee, perhaps because I've only had it served as a condiment.  Here, the kim chee was mixed with the beef for a peppery, garlicky stir fry.  And the cold tofu on the side was a brilliant touch - a cool and subtle contrast to the somewhat fiery kim chee.

The beef bulgogi was just what we hoped for, barbecued thinly-sliced beef in a slightly sweet and smoky sauce.  The sweetness made for a nice contrast with the kim chee dish.

The barbecuing here is done in the kitchen, not at your table as at many Korean restaurants.  This place also doesn't bring you the customary Korean spread of little dishes of pickles, kim chee, etc.  (It may be on the menu, but I wasn't looking for it.)

The only disappointment was the "sizzling rice soup", which is nothing like the version you'd get in a Chinese restaurant.  This was a very bland broth with sizzling rice floating in it - period.  No seafood, no vegetables or anything else to add interest.  When I asked, our waiter said this was a typical version of Korean sizzling rice soup; and that it was best eaten by spooning it over the top of your steamed rice (in an individual bowl on the side).  I've eaten a lot of Asian food and I like rice, but I just couldn't see the point of this very bland dish.  I can only assume that there's a better version of it in other Korean restaurants.

They have beer - Heineken and something domestic - but the waiter said you can only order it by the pitcher.  [At another table, a group of Korean men was drinking from a giant 2-liter plastic bottle of Korean-brand beer.  How did they get it?  Did they bring it themselves?  This place is full of the unexplained.  Go with it.]  

They also have a selection of shoju, a clear whiskey that's one or two steps stiffer than sake.  I rarely see shoju on menus in SF (even though every restaurant in Japan and, I imagine, in Korea would have it), and it's worth a try.  Wine is not available.

Our tab for two, including a pitcher of beer, came to $42.  Darn reasonable, in this neighborhodd.

If you have set expectations about Korean food, this place may disappoint you.  But if you want a hint that Korean cuisine - or any ethnic cuisine, for that matter - is more diverse than what they serve at the "international" food court at the shopping malls, you will find this place to be an adventure.
author: Bob D.

description:
The food itself is just 3 stars, but there's something to be said about a cheap divey, hits just the spot, type of grubbin. Ya know? For that Cocobang gets bumped up to 4, because I would definitely come back - under the right circumstances (e.g. inebriation).

We were able to score a comfy booth for the 4 of us. It's a big deal cuz the total size of this place probably doesn't seat more than 30 or so.

Here's what we indulged with:
- Corn Cheese Appetizer ($6.95) - yellow corn niblets served  on a sizzling plate topped with melted white cheese. You can't go wrong with corn but I only see this on truly Korean bar menus. +1 for that!
- #12 Rapoggi ($11.95) - this is the dokpoggi (tubular rice noodles) but with ramen. Spicy, saucy, with a few pieces of cabbage and tempura tossed in, it's classic bar food. We liked the ramen touch.
- Fried Chicken -  Half ($8.95) / Whole ($13.95) - This is what we came for - the fried chicken. 2 flavors - Original which really is similar to big batter type fried chicken - and Hot & Tangy, which is fried then sauced up with a sweet tomato based concoction and sprinkled with sesame seeds. Both were good in terms of tender pieces of chicken, but the Hot & Tangy had a lot more flavor. Unlike BonChon chicken, the pieces here have heavy batter. So you should know that going in. Still good though. It hit the spot.

This place gets packed so expect a wait during the later hours. Fun though. Good vibe, and fast turnaround on food.

I like!
author: Cindy W.

description:
i dragged my friends to this place on a saturday nite before everyone actually showed up to drink... i got lambasted afterwards because of this was purely a suljip and not a resturant. everyone left hungry and sober. 

i had a BLAST. the bul dak burnt on the way in and raped me on the way out. read an article which complained buldak bangs proliferated in Korean during the tech bust because the PAIN from the chicken took away the pain of unemployment. we need one of these in Chicago...

the best part? it's 2 doors away from a "massage" parlour...
author: Tony C.

description:
Location, location, location.  We checked into a hotel right nearby, and it was already 11pm, so our options were limited.  Fried chicken and draft beer sounded great, and that's what we got.  And budae jige , the "GI stew" with instant ramen noodles, kimchi, spam, and sausages all thrown in a spicy-salty broth.  They didn't have draft beer like the menu promised, but instead had Korean Hite and OB beer jugs (refrigerated, but not on tap).

At 11:30 or so on a Tuesday night, we had to wait about 30 minutes for a table.  Poor waiter guy -- he was alone, busing tables, seating people, ringing up the cash register, carrying out food, taking orders, all by himself.

All in all, it was fine.  I wouldn't say I was impressed or anything, but for this kind of drink-y, junk-y, fast food-y, and late-night-y food, it hit the spot.  (I think they should lower the price for everything on the menu by a buck or two, though.)
author: J H.

description: Their chicken stew with potato is amazing (think it's called the chicken hot pot with potatoes on the menu). I dream about it when I'm far from home and have to have it each time I'm back in the Bay Area. Skip the fried chicken wings and greasy kimchi fried rice next time you're here. The chicken stew takes 20 mins to make but is well worth every second and comes in a serving large enough to feed 3-4.
author: Wan H.

description:
When I party, I usually like to party to the end.  2, I mean 1:30am doesn't do it for me.  That's where Coco's comes in.  4am baby!!!

Also, they have my favy, bok boon ja joo (Korean blackberry wine).
author: Sheryl S.

description: Whoever the waiter was who was working tonight- he was rude. Totally patronizing. The owner should fry him up in a kimchi pancake-- that kind of 'tude is unacceptable in the hospitality industry. Even if it is a Korean BBQ dive. However, Samantha and I liked our dinners. The portions are generous. I'm not super experienced with Korean BBQ joints as I've only been to a few- I'm sure there are better in this city. I'd say this is a good place to soak up the booze after a late night if you're in the Union Sq/ Loin area.
author: Lianne S.

description:
I love Korean bbq, and Korean food in general - I've never been to Korea, so perhaps all I love is merely an Americanized facade of the truth.

I had the fire chicken - it was hot - no other flavor, just hot.  I would say "spicy" but that would connote a "spicy" flavor, and this had no real flavor, just "hot" - and I like both "hot" and "spicy" - together.

So perhaps this place isn't for me, I don't do sochu shooters, or drink beer by the pitcher at 2:00 a.m. with blaring Korean techno-pop.

I can see this place filling a niche in the community - just not for me.
author: Nathan W.

description:
Chicken was the best! Enough said.

Have been craving it ever since I first went here. The only disadvantage with eating here is the crazy parking in SF.
author: C P.

description:
I'm glad my friend brought me to this place.  It definitely did bring me back to memories of 32nd street in NY except for those random dividers between tables.  Did not try 'Fire Chicken' but the yang nyum chicken was dang good.  This is my SF 'Baden Baden'.  I'll definitely be back..

How I miss thee NYC Ktown..
author: Allen S.

description:
Oh wait, you mean this is a korean restaurant? Talk about false advertising...

When I see bang in the name, it can only mean one thing.

Damn good chicken and a rip roaring good time with the boys.  Feel free to draw your own conclusion
author: Jeffrey L.

description: This place doesn't bang.  Its pretty dull actually.  The fried chicken here is overrated.  Its the worst one that I've had in the city.  I've been to all the other fried chicken korean places cuz im fat.  This was differently not that great.  The tofu soup was probably one of the worst I have ever eaten anywhere. I don't think its that hard to make but they definitely got it wrong here.  They have a big projector TV.  woot.
author: Fatty A.

description: Fun place. The spicy chicken wings are superb, not spicy to the point of melting the roof of your mouth.  Japchae was also delicious, best i've had in SF so far... KPop live music show was playing off their projectors; coupled with yogurt soju, makes for a great evening.  MUST COME BACK!!!
author: Ethan L.

description: The food here is pretty good, gets kind of loud though with all the chatter and the music. I think the plus side is they are open really late. So it can get crowded at times.
author: Terry S.

description:
My girlfriend used to live in So-Cal and I guess over there, they're really big on Korean food/restaurants. So imagine our surprise when we discovered this place at around 3 in the morning! And they were still serving dinner! 

Although it doesn't have the best interior in town, the place kind of grows on you. It becomes real homey as you keep going back, compared to the previous visit. I like the Fried Chicken, the Kalbi beef and the little assortment of stuff they also serve on the side. It's a very young crowd too and...they don't card for drinks like Soju which is the Korean equivalent of Sake. 

My overall experience here is always good!

Word to the wise: I wouldn't recommend this for a romantic dinner date but rather, for a chillin' time with your loudest group of friends!
author: Pia C.

description: Not bad for Korean food.  We ordered the tofu with clam soup mildly spicy which didn't even taste spicy at all.  Along with that we had the tangy and spicy chicken which even for me was not even that spicy.  Its weird that they had seafood tofu soup and kimchee soup on the menu but the guy said they only had tofu soup with clams???  I guess his english wasnt very good since my gf asked him if he could rush it so we can catch our musical and he didnt quite understand what we were saying.  The place is tiny and dark inside like most korean bars/restaurants.
author: Ha T.

description: I had the bimbab (spelling?) and that was really tasty. I also tried some kind of sticky rice/pasta dish that came with fish cakes; I wasn't thrilled by this, but mostly because I'm not a fish fan (although I didn't know it came with fish cakes when I ordered it, my bad for not doing enough research). I WISH I had tried one of the chicken dishes, as it seems like that gets a lot of good reviews on here. The service wasn't great; I don't think they refilled our water or checked in us after bringing the food. The atmosphere was very cute though and I could see why some people frequent this place.
author: Ryan G.

description:
DUDE!

Korean Star Search and Cheese Corn. What else do you efin need?

I admit it looks shady but it's well worth the risk.
author: Miles C.

description:
From what I know, I believe this is the only one Korean bar that you could find near downtown San Francisco and it is probably why there is usually a wait. The first time I went there because my friend who usually goes there wanted to go. He is the one who ordered all the food that night. We had a Chicken, which I highly recommend. It is a must if you come here, pork feet , seafood pancake and a spicy ramen with seafood. (The last one, I'm not sure about the actual name)
I went again a week later because I fall in love with their chicken. There was one group of 4 people before my group. My friends and I, total of 5, we waited for almost 1.5 hours for a table. It was very strange that we had to wait that long because it wasn't even a weekend, it was on Monday night around 7.45-8.00PM.

Overall experience:
* I would go back only because of the chicken. 
* Keep in mind that it is not a restaurant restaurant type, it is more like a pub/ bar with a food. 
* It has only about 8 tables. So, may be you need to wait very long time because they won't rush customer who already done to leave like other places which has pro and con.

Service:
It was ok. I would say 50% that I was there, there was only 1 guy there while other time were 2. So, you might need to wave your hand a lot of if you need something. Plus, they often have a difficulty to understand owing to a loud music and their limitation of English. But it doesn't really matter if you don't need something special. 

Food:
* I really like their Chicken a lot and I would recommend it. Other food is so so, nothing stands out or special.
* Yogurt soju is ok. I don't think their mixture is consistency. Someday it was nice while the others weren't. There was one time that I got it with all ice was already melted which made it taste a little bid weird.  
* You also get one free rice per dish. 

Cost:
* After about 10 times there, I would say that a price range is between $15-$20 per person if you don't' order alcohol drink. The first time I was there, it was around $30/person (out of4) because we order 4 dishes + a big bottle of OB beer. 
* They accept credit card but they won't separate more than 2 bills per table.
author: Alex J.

description: Loved the place, food and people that work there! Kpop on the wall!! Just great!:)
author: Ana M.

description:
Our party of three, set on Korean but unable to decide between Cocobang and another nearby and more or less equally well-reviewed $$ option, ended up here by virtue of an actual coinflip. Great success! I had been expecting a less authentic, fluorescent-lit atmosphere, but the place was dark, strangely high ceiling, packed, and we remarked upon arrival that I was the only white person on the premises. The bibimbap and japchae: solid. The soju concoctions: decent, a little pricey, but there is $2.50 draft OB beer, so no points are subtracted from the final score. The banchan was somewhat anemic, but then again, at these prices I'm cool with it. Especially since the main event, namely the spicy chicken, was plentiful and really quite excellent. (That cabbage with dressing on it though...what?) Patronage late at night tends towards rowdiness, but that also adds to the flavor of the experience.

So I'll be honest: if a few friends and yourself are looking to get some drinking on with decent Korean noms, under the everpresent light of projected K-pop visuals (I'd make a joke here about the Bat-Signal but whatever), you'll love this place.
author: Peter B.

description: We went back for takeout, and the food was much better this time.  We tried the wings and the beef short ribs, and everything was delicious.  It's also more enjoyable eating their food in a hotel room than in the restaurant, where you have to get up every few minutes to shut the door.
author: Nadine F.

description: Good choice for a late night dinner with a large group.  The spicy crispy chicken and spicy pork are winners!
author: Honeya O.

description:
Cocobang wasn't bad, but it also wasn't something that I would go out of my way to get. We got the chicken wings in the signature red spicy Korean sauce and wings that were fried. They were served with a heaping pile of cabbage doused with thousand island dressing -- sorta like coleslaw funkified. It didn't look that good and no one really touched it except for the birthday girl, but she did say she loves cabbage...

We also got this fried pancake thing with veggies in it -- that was ok. My favorite dish was the rice and fish cakes in the signature red sauce. The sides that run so plentiful in LA's K-Town (where I am used to eating my Korean red sauce covered foods) were not so great. 

My vegetarian friend ordered the bibimbap and it wasn't served in those piping hot stone bowls which I think makes bibimbap taste as good as it does. 

Anyway, we drank some good beer and had some tasty sake along with these "street" foods so it was good overall. I just don't think I'll go back anytime soon.
author: Sobrina T.

description:
This place is perfect for midnight snacks / after going out food.  This is a hole in the wall place (with a somewhat unclean bathroom) so if you are looking for a fine dining experience then this place is not for you. The definite plus about it is that it opens late, it's one of the few places that open until 4am in SF. They also play Korean music videos in the background which is quite entertaining. The food is decent although not super authentic but the portions are pretty generous. However, the side dishes are a bit too salty. 

My recommendations are:
-Fire chicken
-Fried chicken with sweet tangy sauce (supposedly their signature dish)
-Kimchee stew w/ hot dog and spam and lots of kimchee (yum)
-Soon-dubu
-Chap-chae
-Flavoredt soju. They have all kinds of fruity flavors, but get the yogurt soju - that one is the best 

This is one of my favorite hole in the wall places in SF - decent food, cheap, large portion, and it's always there for you no matter how late. That's why it's got me coming back, every single time...
author: Melody L.

description:
Like a Korean college bar, near Union Square.  Popular with college students. Very few people over 30. Most of the tables in the (very small) restaurant get pushed together for large groups that drink a lot, so if there are no tables when you arrive I wouldn't recommend waiting (there's not much turnover). 

I'm not an expert in Korean food but I've been several times now, and always enjoyed what I've been served.  Especially the seafood pancakes.  I also liked the yogurt soju cockail, which surprisingly (to me, anyway) is served in a jug for serving among friends. Convenient! And yes, there are Korean music videos (with the occasional Britney Spears thrown in) displayed on the wall. I would also agree that the washrooms are terrible, and down a steep narrow flight of stairs, but I never take washrooms into account when rating a restaurant.
author: K. B.

description:
Okay I feel bad saying I wasn't impressed but I have to be honest, I wasn't! I read all the reviews and thought I would try this place mainly because they were close and open super late... I have a feeling this place is only good after a few drinks not if your just looking for good food. I had the spicy BBQ beef short ribs (not that good), and the spicy pork which was better then the ribs. 
All in all I won't be coming back I think next time I need to eat real late I'll try the play ground they seem to have pretty good reviews too. Otherwise that hans hibachi place has some real good bip m bop!
author: erika l.

description:
the food here is pretty good, although i've never been here before 1:30am and sober so maybe that has something to do with it...   the fried chicken is good and the kimchi friend rice is the bomb - i'm pretty sure they taste good when sober too.  The seating policy in the wee hours of the morning can be a bit confusing.  I think they sometimes seat fellow Koreans (or at least anyone speaking Korean) first... so try and bring a Korean friend if there's a line.  

note to self:  must try this place for lunch someday.
author: Toby C.

description:
eh.

i don't think soondubu jjigae is suppose to be made with chicken broth...
author: Corliss L.

description:
So you all should be aware of a few things...when places are able to give me late night eats, I'm a little more lax on how tasty things are then I would be if I was eating it at a less ungodly hour. 

Anyways, I went here for the first time last night and ordered the spicy tofu soup. Pretty standard tofu soup with a small portion of well-cooked rice, but pretty damn delicious at 3am in the morning. My friends got the fried chicken and fire chicken which they said were "okay" but hard to complain too much when you have good service and really entertaining korean music videos playing on the wall above you. Not too many banchan though which is a bummer since I love me my banchan! 

Um, another thing you need to know about me is that I like korean dramas. =P
author: Minh-Chi T.

description: The food service was really slow. Although the food was tasty, it was hard to digest, I assume this was due to the way it was cooked. The staff is really friendly though, i will give this place another shot later and see what s up.
author: Ismail S.

description: Small intimate place. Good food, good service. May get a bit loud toward the end of the night
author: Sinan M.

description:
Great late  night find!  I love korean food and they had amazing fried chicken! and Kai Bae... can never spell my Korean food names, chop chae was very flavorful! I always eat Korean food with someone who speaks Korean so I never order it, but This place is open till 4AM on Fridays and Sats. But you have to remember it is a small place, and people tend to eat and drink there all night, so they may say 20 mins, but good luck if you see a bunch of people there. I still recommend it. 
Not bad for the price too!
author: Judi K.

description:
My friends and I love this place! We probably go about 1-2 times a month take out or order in! The price is not inexpensive but I sure as hell will pay whatever they're asking for, for this food. 

My favorite is the Spicy rice noodle with ramen, Dunno the name exactly but its no. 12 on the menu! :- )

I LOVE IT.
author: Sueann W.

description: Good Korean food and clearly liked by the locals (I was in the minority). The waiter was very helpful in making recommendations that were delicious. Got a large portion for the price. Very casual place. The large screen TV plays Korean music videos, which are a hoot!
author: Erik G.

description:
My girlfriend introduced me to Korean food and, more recently, to soju.  She's spent time in Korea and in LA and Seattle where there's lots of Korean food, and she always looks for good Korean eats in the city.  There's not much in this neighborhood, and it's cool that Cocobang serves pretty good food in this drinking hole atmosphere (although I wouldn't recommend it as an introduction to Korean food).

I really like the fire chicken, the beef-and-kimchee dish, and the barbecue.  All of the flavored soju choices are good, there's beer on tap too if you want that.  Service is generally good (probably a little better if you speak Korean beyond "chowa heh").  The clientele is almost all-Korean, and the atmosphere is lively, with plenty of conversation and laughter mixed with the K-pop music from the videos being projected on the wall in the back.
author: Joseph N.

description:
I never thought it was possible to have bad Korean food until I came here. After we ordered, we were presented with the banchan (korean side dishes). I was surprised to see the LACK of banchan you receive! We got 3 (I KNOW!) but they do not come in their own dishes; they came together in a trio dipping sauce-type dish. Think the sauce-size dish you get to put your sauce in from pho restaurants. Yes, that's it. My friend's bibimbap came in a regular bowl...no hot stone pot in sight (Now, I understand that this dish could be served cold but that was not stated on the menu). I ordered the spicy tofu hot pot, which had a very watery broth consistency nor was it spicy nor was I asked to what level of spiciness I wanted it. I asked for an egg to crack in my soup and the waiter informed me that it had already been added. I was slightly crushed. A couple of other friends also ordered the bulgogi, which they was very salty. They kept commenting to each other: "wow, they must have added so much MSG". 

Honestly, if I could give no stars, I would.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This place is very good.  The korean food is super tasty and delicious.  The dishes are very good size.  This place is nice to go wtih your friends and have a great time during dinner.  It's a good size space to go with your friends. It's a fun young atmosphere.  Everything i have tasted there is very good (usually order a bunch of dishes and we all have a bit of everything)

Drinks are very good too!
author: Erika C.

description: Great place for a late night dinner.  Kalbi and tofu soup were tasty.
author: Kris B.

description: 3 star food but an extra star for being 24 hours, and the Korean music videos playing in the background. The only thing is this place can get packed late night, so you might show up at 1am and have to wait to be seated.  Fried chicken is decent - in my opinion, not at the level of NYC's Korean fried chicken spots, but let's be honest - at 1am any fried chicken tastes delicious.
author: John H.

description:
I have too many memories at this place.

I have gotten trashed here too many times.

I've gotten friends trashed here.

Soju = FUN for you and your friends.

It's expensive, yeah... but if you are tired of the normal bar atmosphere (getting HIT ON by JERKS), come here... you can eat, drink, and everyone stays at their tables unless they know someone or the owner comes out and knows you (which probably won't happen).

Having a Korean friend with you to explain the foods and drinking culture is a fun experience too.

A lot of Korean AAU students frequent and work here...

What else can I say about this place?  DON'T be put off by it's sparse-looking dining areas... because when you're drunk off soju and can't see straight (it hits you like a ton of bricks when you least suspect it) what does interior really matter?

Be careful going to the bathroom after a few drinks; it's DOWN a flight of semi-steep stairs.
author: Kitty O.

description: WHAAAAT?? I can't believe i haven't written a review for this place! Where do i even begin what level this place is in. Cocobang is probably one of the only places that is able to capture the taste and essence of food from LA's Koreatown and most of all, KOREA. The banchan, as little as it is, is always on point with the flavor (well at least for my taste), don't even get me started with their fire chicken...aaaaamaazzzinggg (especially with the soju slushies~), Kimchi pancake is always delicious, and my all time favorite, Kimchi fried rice~~~ NOMNOMNOM. Just thinking about it is making me super hungry. I'm on a mission to try their stews and soups...we'll see if they can pass my taste test. will update soon~~~
author: Suzan L.

description: I'm giving it 4 stars because of the fire chicken. Other than that, I was disappointed with the marinated and fried chicken. Thought it would have a familiar taste like how they make it in Korea, but alas, I was faced with disappointment. Also, I'm not a big fan of dark meat, and when we got our chicken, it was all dark meat, no white meat. I do like the fact that they are open late.
author: Lo L.

description:
My favorite late night restaurant, tied with Vietnam.

Everything I've had here hits the spot-- fire chicken, ddukbokki (even better if you add ramen), bibimbap, even the cheese corn.  Portions are pretty big, 1 dish per person is already way more than enough food, unless you're eating an actual meal.

And if it's past 3AM and you're too out of it to make decent conversation, just turn your head and be mesmerized by the SNSD videos being projected on the wall.

Only big negative is that it's painfully unbearable to smell everyone else's food while you're waiting for a table during the post-clubbing rush.
author: S L.

description:
My friend and I stumbled upon this place while searching for a Ramen place in the city. Good thing we eyed it from the window because one day we ended up coming back for it and fell in love!

Ambiance: Small hole in the wall. They use their wall as a screen to project Korean music videos. One side of the wall is brown bricks! 

Food: We ordered tofu soup, their seafood pancake, and their fire chicken! OMG! It was bomb. Their portions were big and obviously we couldn't finish, but with some soju to help wash it down, we did finish as much as we could eventually and took the rest home. 

Service: Super friendly and quick.
author: Jennie N.

description: My friends and I decided to go to this place on the spur of the moment.  We didn't want to spend too much but still have a place where we could sit and chat for awhile.  The food came out pretty fast and is good.  It won't blow you away, but there is a comfort to eating their bulgogi/bibimbop/spicy chicken.  The staff was polite but a bit slow on refilling the water.  Still it's a great place to hang out with friends.  I will return if I am in need of some comfort, but know I won't over eat or if I just need somewhere around the Union Square to hang out and simply enjoy the company of others over some decent food.
author: John C.

description:
Just got back from dinner there and it was good. I will break down each entree. 
Kimchee Fried Rice - Good but greasy
Beef Short Ribs - Sweet and tasty
Seafood Pancake - Yummy and like the menu said...a fried seafood pancake
Fried Chicken - Tangy and spicy a nice twist
Bulgogi - Simple stir fry beef and veggie dish

Plus dont forget to get the 1600mL bottle of Hite beer!

Overall:
Good Food
Cheerful but slow service
Ambiance - Korean Soju Posters and music videos playing on the wall....enough said.
author: Madeline T.

description: Decent Korean fried chicken at a decent price is unheard of in Northern California or anywhere else in the United States.  The dukkboki is actually really good, especially with I suck some Nuts and ramen. The little rice cakes are amazing. The prices are quite good also for food that is not widely served. .
author: Min P.

description:
my friend raved about this place so i really wanted to try it.  we walked in and it was pretty dark inside.  they kept playing brian mcknight and love songs like one sweet day from boys to men and mariah carey and leona lewis.  i dont know whos playlist it was. but it was darn sappy.

we ordered jap chae, homemade (or handmade?) noodles, soon du boo, and the hot and tangy whole chicken.  it isnt really a whole chicken but just more pieces.  maybe they should just say 20 pieces instead of whole and helf.  yes its says helf on the menu.  maybe they mean order.  the chicken wasnt all that great.  the sauce wasnt spicy.  it was more like something from panda express.  i did take the skin off one piece and the chicken inside tasted kind of funky.

their jap chae was actually really good.  on the chewier side.  the noodles were not visibly handmade.  maybe homemade?  not sure.
author: claudia y.

description:
Went in for a quick dinner on a rainy night last week.  Dark and narrow, odd little booths plastered in soju posters, I get the feeling it's a place where one can get drunk and have a few nibbles while doing it (the drunkening, the dominant purpose), but really it's like something odd is going on in here --- the food is not un-pricey, the drinks are super pricey and really I just don't get it.

The food isn't so bad, but it's also a bit strange --- they have the mochi in hot sauce thing I really like, but the sizzling rice soup is exactly that, some hot water with sizzling rice in it.  More of a rice tea than a soup, yet strangely tasty.

The best part of the experience were the Korean music videos projected above the bar, but they to were also off in some way, all of them seemed to be dolorous ballads about love gone wrong and ending for the young female protagonist in tragic and often violent death.

There's nothing wrong with this place, but there's seriously some bit I'm not getting in here.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Really pleasant and kind service. I needed beer to go and they did offer a big handle of OB for $13 but if you don't care much for Korean brew then there's a liquor store across the street with Racer 5 for $11 a six pack. The spare ribs were satisfactory but the real surprise was the kimchi. I'm not the biggest fan of this fermented dish but either I'm getting a taste for it or this kimchi is really good (inclusive or).

Either way, an overall good experience.
author: eric m.

description: Love this place!!! Great drunk or was drinking fatty meat eating experience. Great atmosphere. I recommend this place to all my alcoholic coherts!
author: Chick M.

description: This place was absolutely phenomenal.  My wife and I came for dinner twice in the span of 4 nights (1st time randomly stumbled on it, 2nd time was bc the 1st time was so damn good).  We got the kimchi pancake, and a mix of spicy bbq pork and a couple of chicken dishes.  Both times everything was delicious.  The place was crowded both nights (a Thursday and a Sunday), the first night we lucked into a table right when we got there, the other time we called in an order and picked up, both turned out to be delicious.  If anyone likes korean food (or if you haven't tried it like myself until this past weekend), the dishes we had were excellent, the prices were good, and the atmosphere and service was friendly.
author: Zac C.

description:
I have to say, this place is pretty awesome. Apparently, from reading the other reviews, Koreans really know how to party.

It's unfortunate that it's located in such a small place ,but the food is pretty good! I've been there three nights in a row before - although it's only a block or so from my place. :)

The service is pretty good, and the wait isn't too bad. The times I have been there, mostly Koreans were eating there. That has to be a good sign, right? and considering that I have a major thing for Korean guys, I really enjoy going here.;) 

All my friends will agree that the food is delicious!
author: Aryn B.

description: Been hitting up my roommate Lisa's grandma's house for amazingly ace home-cooked Korean food so I feel like I know a thing or two, aside from growing up in Hawaii where Korean food is like Mexi food is here. Cocobang is like the Osha of Korean food. It's greasy, fast, has huge portions and tastes like it has drugs in it (aka really really good). Got the kim chee fried rice (hot dogs in it!!!), bi bim bap (i've had better but still dece), a HUGE bottle of Hitebeer (nice and light, maybe the best beer with food i've ever had) and a giant sizzling platter of kal fucking bi. jesus. i'm mostly a vegetarian and i was wolfing that stuff down. plus they were projecting Korean Idol on the wall. what's not to love?
author: Laura M.

description:
I love this place have been there numerous amount of times.

Soju is great and the beers are $2.50

The korean music videos playing on the wall is what makes this place!!
author: Matt L.

description:
I've walked by this place numerous times and am so glad I tried it with a friend recently.  We had the fire chicken, soon tofu chigae, and the kimchi pancake, which was bigger than a charger platter and had a great crispy and chewy texture.  The flavors were fresh, spicy, and bold and the service was welcoming.

I loved the relaxed atmosphere and the Korean pop videos projected on the wall.  It reminded me of Foreign Cinema except the images were in color and were happy instead of sad.

This is a great late night place to eat in the city.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Daniel N.

description: Good food. Just pay attention to the bill at the end... I think we overpaid, as they included the tip and didnt inform us. Review the bill carefully!
author: Liane N.

description: Yang Nyum Chicken is YUMMY!!! Not quite what you would get in Korea but a close second. I have been CRAVING this forever and was stoked to have found a place to scratch my itch! Yey!!!
author: Mina L.

description:
I tried their fried chicken and requested the spicy/tangy sauce to be served on the side. The fried chicken alone tastes OK (nothing extraordinary) but the sauce is not that great. We also tried their tofu soup which is just mediocre. 

The one nice thing about Cocobang is that they have a big screen projection which was showing World Cup live at the time which was kind of nice. Plus the waiter was really friendly.
author: jen n.

description:
so i had a hankering for fried chicken, but didn't want to walk far. followed fellow yelpers to cocoBang. i loved it. 

the sweet and spicy wings were just that. they came with coleslaw which you need to cut the fire. i also recommend ordering fries. it completes the meal.

perfect for the day following a night on the town... kills  the hangover.
author: jamie b.

description: This is one of my favorite Korean fried chicken places in SF. The neighborhood is iffy, but cheap rent means affordable food. The staff are very friendly and they're open late. Check it out and try the fried chicken with hot and tangy sauce.
author: Eric M.

description: I'm going to go out on a limb and say that this place is the coolest place on Nob Hill. Dark, edgy, crowded little restaurant showing Korean pop music videos on the wall. The servers are super cool; they look like Korean ex-skaterboarders. The food is also definitely pretty solid. The bibimbap rice bowl rocks, as well as the glass noodles appetizer. They also serve you Korean beer (OB?) in 1 liter bottles. This is definitely the scene come Fri -Sat as big crowds of Korean kids chill into the after hours. It's especially hilarious when a clearly lost family from the midwest shows up, or you find yourself next to a passed out businessman in a suit.
author: Aaron F.

description: I was totally impressed with the excellent customer service provided by server, Maven.  He was extremely efficient, friendly, and courteous.  He also recommended a really good dish which was their special Fried Chicken.  Let me tell you, I was really happy with it and surprised to say the least.  Portions were generous as well.  I highly recommend this place and do ask for Maven as your server.
author: Lorraine B.

description:
hit or miss man, hit or miss.

sometimes the food is awesome, other nights it's sucked. typical korean joint, loud, lot of people, lot of drinking, korean music videos projected onto a large screen.

dont get too drunk or u will hurt urself going down the stairs to the bathroom. i forget if they have a handrail or not, but that stairway is freaking steep.

finding street parking is hard, so u might have to walk a few blocks to get to it.
author: Simon C.

description:
had a wonderful time, i love small places and this place is small. they have korean music and videos on the wall, so its entertaining as well. 
the food was a little pricey for a little resturant,  but well worth it. I will be goin back...
author: Steve M.

description:
two spontaneous korean fried chicken and soju outings in 3 days?   bad for the arteries and liver but fun for me.  

last night, i met up with some people at cocobang and we had japchae, fire chicken, a kimchee jigae that had a lot of stuff in it, half an order of the plain fried chicken, half an order of sauced chicken and the seafood pajon.  of course we also had soju (because i'm korean), apple and yogurt flavors, and pitchers of ob.    

as stated by other people, you don't go here for the food.  the service was good and they kept the drinks coming but there are only two things i would order again, the plain fried chicken and the pajon.  everything else was just not that good and kind of weird, like cheese and weiners in stuff i would never put them in. 

in the end, the bill was pretty low considering how much we got and it's open until 4am so i could see myself coming back late night if i'm downtown or in the loin and not in the mood for osha.
author: Seong P.

description: Sometimes you don't want to drive ALL THE WAY out to J-town for Korean. This is a small Korean restaurant in Union Square with all the essentials. Open late until 4 am. Fulfills your Korean Craving.
author: Sandy C.

description:
order the FIRE CHICKEN. for the extremists, i suggest the BURNING FIRE CHICKEN. im a big fan of spicy---not tabasco sauce spicy, but make-you-poo-blood-the-next-morning spicy. as proof, you can see my smiling face on the WALL OF FAME at OROCHAN in little tokyo LA. yea dudebro, it's that serious.

anyhow, COCO BANG is HELLA GOOD CHICKEN. the streaming K-POP isn't bad either.
author: Ivy R.

description:
I keep finding more and more late night eateries throughout this city. It's so unlike my home city (Boston) where there is only one or two late night food joints in the whole city. Cocobang! I live down the block from this place and I've always been afraid to walk in. It's intimidating when you walk by and you keep imagining that the 10 Korean guys smoking outside are in the Korean mafia. So to get over my fear (because I had always heard such good things about this place, and that they keep serving past 2) I got my closet Korean buddy to bring me. 
I think it might have been only the second time I've eaten Korean when I came here for the first time. The first thing you notice is the K-pop that is being broadcasted onto a white sheet in front of you and the monstrous ceilings (serious, you can fit a giraffe in there.) The second thing you notice is the small amount of seating in this place. I've never had to wait, but you can pretty much hear every one's conversation (and if you know Korean, you can understand it.) If sit to close to the door, you always get an uncomfortable draft. It might be cold air, it might be cigarette smoke... depends on the night. But if you are lucky enough to get a seat closer in, you will be able to smell the kitchen. Yummmmm. Good dim sum, good fried chicken, good barbecued beef. Some of their dishes are fucking HOT. Like "ouch ouch ouch I'm dying, help... sweet merciful crap, end my life already" hot. But you can get almost every dish "less hot" or as my friend Mikal says "no spicy."
Okay, the catch with the Soju: do not buy their flavored soju. It has almost no actual soju in it. A baby couldn't get drunk off it. BUT if you just buy their regular soju (which I think is a dollar less) you can get fucking wrecked. If they don't know what you mean by regular soju, just point to the soju ads (usually the hot chick holding a green bottle) that should be next to you or within 5 feet of where you are sitting.
Most of the time when I'm dealing with a "late night" place o' eat I expect to pay a little more than I would... but this is a bit on the bullshit side. 16 bucks for some of their dishes... 12 bucks for soju? fuck me this is expensive. The service isn't anything to rant about either... or the decor. Very plain. It's cleaner than it is dirty... but I wouldn't call it clean. I guess you could call everything about average... but since the food is good, and it's open really late on the weekend, it gets that 3rd star. I wish I could give it a 3.5, but I can't (or can i?)

Open Late with some really good flavor. COCOBANG!
author: Zane C.

description:
fun place to go to late nite after going out in town.

i got the dduk mandu ggook (rice cake and Dumpling soup) and it wasnt very good but the rabbokki and the yumyum chicken is AWESOME!!

very young atmosphere
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: This place is a little small, only had one waiter on a Sunday night. There is a projector that plays korean music videos on a screen at the front of the restaurant. Even though the waiter was constantly busy, he was very nice and still got everything out in a timely manner. My friends and I ordered, rice cake with ramen which was sweet and spicy. The rice cake was very filling and the sauce was thick. The ramen was just a cube that looks like they got it out of a package and boiled it up and put sauce over it. Fried chicken with tangy sauce was okay. The chicken pieces were pretty big, some had bones in it still; the breading was drenched in sauce which  made it soggy. The chicken itself was juicy and more sweet and tangy than spicy, comes with a side of cabbage that I didn't touch. The food was very heavy, wanted something refreshing and green after it. Thinly sliced pig feet tasted like it was duck with a crunch. It came with three sides, a chili paste to dip, anchovies and kim chi. The anchovies were extremely salty, just a little taste of it would make you feel thirsty. They gave a lot of food and you wouldn't leave here still hungry.
author: Lyly T.

description:
This place is a haven for mostly korean folk who come in after a late night out
clubbing and want to wash their sorrows down w/more alcohol(soju) and some late
night korean based snacks.  

Checked this place out twice in a week.

I had to come back for the chicken!

I dunno WHAT it is..but the chicken cutlet(fried chicken filets)
are so succulent, so juicy and the batter is done so crisp
and light.

They also sprinkle a ketchup like sauce as seasoning.
It just hits my pallet so right!

They're also known for their trademark "coco" chicken
w/their regular batter and their spicier batter w/sesame seeds.

Both are VERY good and they are great fast food snacks on your way out of a bar.

But their chicken katsu is something else!

Their chicken is so tasty that lots of non-korean folk come in too.
They are all treated to very dark colored amenities, wooden chairs and wooden
desk dividers, and also a projector on the top wall...displaying lots of korean
pop music videos (cheesy but fun!).

I recommend all their dishes.
DOn't expect gourmet and don't expect the best korean food you ever had.
Just expect good fast food that hits the spot when you have your late night outs
in the city!

Dinner for two can be 10 bucks! Of course if you had the soju and other alcohol,
the cost will get up significantly.

Order the chicken cutlet!
author: Michael L.

description:
This is the absolute worst Korean restaurant that I have ever been to (out of maybe 10-15, so this is in the bottom 10% for sure) 

1.  Terrible atmosphere, the lights are dim and the people in the restaurant always leave the door open even when it is freezing outside
2.  Horrible food: they pretty much only serve non traditional dishes that are downright ripoffs, the firechicken is too spicy and the rest of their meat dishes, such as the bulgogi which is burnt
3.  No tofu soup dishes: the only thing that comes close is extremely bland with barely any seafood with the noodles for more than $10
4. Extremely limited side dishes, only 3 side dishes

The only plus for this joint is that they do play a lot of trendy K pop music, which may be good for people in the 15-25 age range, but I wouldn't go to the restaurant just for this, if you want trendy k pop, just go to some internet websites or youtube
author: C H.

description: What does a white girl from Ohio know about Korean food?  Nothing.  I actually like Hahn's (gasp!).  This place left me full and unsatisfied.  I had the BBQ Beef (too sweet) and my beau had the Korean sausage (sauce was like ketchup).  The place was close to full with mostly Korean folk.  I am sure they know something that I don't.  Maybe you do, too?
author: T-Bone L.

description: Good Korean spot near downtown. Great neuvo Korean and some typical Korean dishes. So fun if you go with a group of Koreans for a late dinner and drinks.
author: Lily K.

description:
